4-5B-8: Storage Of Barrels And Drums
4-5B-9: Protection Of Property
4-5B-10: Approval Of Plans
4-5B-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this Article, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this Section:
CLASSES OF FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS: Class I liquids. Liquids with a flash point at or
below twenty five degrees Fahrenheit (25°F) (-4°C) closed cup test.
Class II Liquids. Liquids with a flash point above that of Class I and at or
below seventy degrees (70°) Fahrenheit (21° centigrade) closed cup test.
Class III Liquids. Liquids with a flash point above that of Class II and at or
below two hundred degrees (200°) Fahrenheit (931/2° centigrade) closed cup
test.
The flash point shall be determined with the Elliott, Abel, Abel-Pensky or the
Tag closed cup testers, but the Tag closed cup test (standardized by the United
States Bureau of Standards) shall be authoritative in case of dispute. All
tests shall be made in accordance with the methods adopted by the American
Society for Testing Materials.
Representative examples of the classes of flammable liquids are:
CLASS I CLASS II CLASS III
CLASS I           CLASS II       CLASS III
Ether             Alcohol        Kerosene
Carbon bisulphide Amyl acetate   Amyl alcohol
Gasoline          Toluol         Turpentine
Naphtha           Ethyl acetate  Fuel oil
Benzol            Methyl acetate
Acetone           Methyl alcohol
Collodion
 
GENERAL STORAGE: Storage of Class I, II or III liquids other than for retail or
service station storage.
General storage tanks located in a bulk plant may be connected by piping to
service station underground tanks if, in addition to valves at the general
storage tanks, a valve is also installed within control of service station
personnel.
PUBLIC HALL: Any place which is used at any time for public meetings or the
assembling of people for amusement, instruction or religious worship. (Ord. 0-
80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5B-2: LOCATION OF TANKS:
   A.   Restricted Classes of Property: No storage tank shall be less than
three hundred feet (300') from any mine shaft, air or escape shaft for any
mine, nor from any schoolhouse, church, hospital or public hall. The distance
shall be measured from near edges of tanks in all directions to near point of
shaft or building.
   B.   Property Lines and Buildings:
      1.   The minimum distance from individual tanks to line of adjoining
property which is or may be built upon shall be not less than the following:
         a.   For tanks of fifty thousand (50,000) gallons or less:
 
Tank Capacity (Gallons) Minimum Distance  (Feet)
3,000 or less           20
21,000 or less          25
31,000 or less          30
45,000 or less          40
50,000 or less          50
 
In case of tanks for the storage of crude petroleum, the foregoing minimum
clearances shall be doubled.
         b.   For tanks of more than fifty thousand (50,000) gallons to be used
only for the storage of refined petroleum products or other flammable liquids
not subject to boil over:
            (1)   Group A Tanks: If tank is equipped with (1) an approved
permanently attached extinguishing system or (2) an approved floating roof, the
distance shall be not less than the greatest dimension (diameter, length or
height) of tank, but such distance need not exceed one hundred twenty feet
(120').
            (2)   Group B Tanks: If tank is not equipped either with (1) an
approved permanently attached extinguishing system or (2) an approved floating
roof, the distance shall not be less than one and one-half (11/2) times the
greatest dimension (diameter, length or height) of the tank, but such distance
need not exceed one hundred seventy five feet (175').
         c.   For tanks of more than fifty thousand (50,000) gallons to be used
for the storage of crude petroleum or other flammable liquid subject to boil
over:
            (1)   Group C Tanks: If tank is equipped either with (1) an
approved permanently attached extinguishing system or (2) an approved floating
roof, the distance shall be not less than twice the greatest dimension
(diameter, length or height) of the tank, but such distance need not exceed one
hundred seventy five feet (175').
            (2)   Group D Tanks: If tank is not equipped either with (1) an
approved permanently attached extinguishing system or (2) an approved floating
roof, the distance shall be not less than three (3) times the greatest
dimension (diameter, length or height) of the tank, but need not exceed three
hundred fifty feet (350').
      2.   These distances shall apply also to other buildings on the property
except those necessarily connected with the installation (such as oil
warehouse, pumphouse, and garage).
      3.   In particular installations, these distances may be increased at the
discretion of the Village President after consideration of such special
features as topographical conditions, nature of occupancy and proximity of
buildings on adjoining property, height and construction of such buildings,
capacity and construction of proposed tanks and character of liquids to be
stored, degree of private fire protection provided and facilities of fire
departments to cope with oil fires.
      4.   Location of tanks with reference to railroad tracks over which
passenger trains are moved shall conform to the regulations of the Bureau of
Explosives of the Association of American Railroads (formerly American Railway
Association), 30 Vesey Street, New York City.
      5.   When general oil storage is maintained in connection with a filling
station, the distance from general storage tanks to filling station building,
tanks and equipment shall be the same as that required to property lines.
   C.   Distance Between Tanks: The minimum distance from tanks to adjacent
tanks shall be as follows:
Tank Capacity (Gallons) Minimum Distance  (Feet)
Tank Capacity (Gallons) Minimum Distance  (Feet)
300 or less             3
500 or less             3
1,000 or less           3
8,000 or less           3
12,000 or less          3
18,000 or less          3
24,000 or less          5
30,000 or less          10
48,000 or less          10
75,000 or less          13
100,000 or less         15
Over 100,000            One tank diameter
 
If tanks are of different capacities, the capacity of the larger tank shall
govern its distance to adjacent tanks.
   D.   High Water: Tanks shall be located so as to avoid possible danger from
high water.
   E.   Streams: When tanks are located on a stream without tide, they shall,
where possible, be downstream from burnable property. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5B-3: TANK SPECIFICATIONS:
   A.   Materials and General Construction:
      1.   Factory assembled tanks shall bear the label of Underwriters'
Laboratories or meet equivalent specifications. Field erected tanks shall meet
the specifications of the National Fire Protection Association, as published in
N.F.P.A. Pamphlet No. 30, in 1958, or those of the American Petroleum
Institute. No open tank shall be used.
      2.   Tanks shall be covered with asphaltum or other nonrusting coating or
paint.
      3.   All pipe connections shall be made through flanges or reinforcements
securely riveted, welded or bolted to the tank and shall be made tight.
      4.   All openings shall be made liquid and vaportight, except breacher
vents. Gaskets used shall be such as are not affected by heat or the contents
of tanks.
      5.   Covers for manholes, handholes and gauge holes shall be made tight
fitting and normally kept in place.
   B.   Venting of Tanks:
      1.   Normal Vents: Each tank over one hundred (100) gallons in capacity
shall have vent openings, except safety valves, provided with approved,
noncorrodible flame arresters so attached as to completely cover the openings.
Vent openings shall in no case be less than one and one- fourth inches (11/4")
in diameter, and where a power pump is used in filling tanks and a tight
connection is made to fill pipe, vent shall not be smaller than fill pipe.
      2.   Special Safety or Emergency Relief Vents: Additional vent openings
or safety valves adequate to relieve any excessive pressure due to external
heat shall be provided, of a type which shall be self-closing when pressure is
relieved.
The total area of vents shall be not less than twenty four (24) square inches
for tanks of twenty one thousand (21,000) gallons' capacity or less and not
less than seventy eight (78) square inches for tanks of more than twenty one
thousand (21,000) gallons' capacity. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5B-4: INSTALLATION OF TANKS:
   A.   Setting of Tanks:
      1.   Tanks more than one foot (1') above the ground shall have a firm
foundation and supports of noncombustible materials, bases of which shall be
below the frost line.
      2.   Unprotected steel as a support for tanks shall not be permitted.
      3.   No combustible materials shall be permitted under or within ten feet
(10') of any storage tanks except stairways to and walks on top, these
preferably to be of iron or steel.
   B.   Grounding of Tanks: All tanks shall be grounded electrically and
effectively to permanent moisture.
   C.   Materials and Design: Piping, valves and fittings for flammable liquids
shall be designed for the working pressures and structural stresses to which
they may be subjected. They may be of steel or other materials suitable for use
with the liquid being handled. Pipe-wall thicknesses, determined in accordance
with Section 3 of the American Standard Code for Pressure Piping (A.S.A. B31.1-
1951), shall be deemed to comply with this subsection; except, that carbon
steel pipe shall not be thinner than standard wall thickness listed in the
American Standard for Wrought-Steel and Wrought-Iron Pipe (A.S.A. B36.10-1950).
   D.   Pipes:
      1.   Runs: Piping shall be run as directly as possible and proper
allowance made for expansion and contraction.
      2.   Aboveground Pipes: Piping, when aboveground, shall be protected
against mechanical injury.
      3.   Underground Pipes:
         a.   Pipes shall not be surrounded or covered by cinders or other
material of corrosive effect, but preferably should be laid in sand, and where
carried in conduit, the openings of such conduit must be fully protected to
prevent escape of liquid under dangerous conditions.
         b.   Pipelines buried on railroad property shall be laid at a depth of
not less than three feet (3'); where they pass under tracks, they shall be laid
at least four feet (4') below bottom of ties.
         c.   Piping buried in Village streets or other areas where other
pipelines are carried shall be sealed in conduit. Joints of conduit shall be
sealed to prevent leakage and pitch shall be toward tank yard.
         d.   Underground piping shall be coated with asphaltum or other
corrosion resisting material.
      4.   Joints: Joints may be welded or of the ordinary screw type; if of
the screw type, they shall be made up with litharge and glycerine, lamp black
or shellac.
      5.   Tests: Piping, after installation, shall be tested at a pressure
fifty percent (50%) in excess of the working pressure and shall be proven
tight. Tests shall continue for thirty (30) minutes.
   E.   Valves:
      1.   Normal Valves: Each pipe attached to a tank shall be provided with a
valve at the tank, with no branches nor outlets between the tank and valve.
In case two (2) or more tanks are cross-connected, there shall be a valve at
each tank in each cross-connection. Tanks with different classes of liquids
shall not be cross-connected.
      2.   Emergency Internal Check Valves: In addition to any normal valves,
there must be an extra valve at each pipeline connection to any tank below
normal liquid level (regardless of when installed), which valve is effective
inside the tank shell and is operated both manually and by an effective heat
actuated device which, in case of fire, will automatically close the valve to
prevent the flow of liquid from the tank even though the pipelines are broken
from the tank. These extra valves are not required in crude oil tanks in oil
fields, on tanks in refineries or on tanks at terminals which are equipped with
a swing line or where facilities are provided to transfer the contents of the
tank to another tank in case of fire. On tanks installed prior to the effective
date of the heretofore applied regulations of the State Fire Marshall of the
State of Illinois, emergency check valves may be external if the size of the
opening makes it impractical to use an internal valve; provided the valve
incorporates a shear section and is so installed that any undue strain beyond
the valve will not cause failure between the valve and the tank; and provided
further, that when an opening on a previously installed tank is enlarged, an
internal valve be installed.
   F.   Diking:
      1.   Diking Required:
         a.   Individual tanks or groups of tanks, where deemed necessary by
the Village President on account of proximity to waterways, character of
topography or nearness to structures of high value, or to places of habitation
or assembly, shall be diked or the yard shall be provided with a curb or other
suitable means taken to prevent the spread of liquid onto other property or
waterways. Where a diked enclosure is required under this paragraph, the
volumetric capacity of the diked area shall be not less than the aggregate
capacity of the tanks within the diked area, except where approved fire control
equipment is provided, the capacity of the diked area shall be not less than
the capacity of the largest tank within the enclosure.
Sufficient distance shall always be allowed for the building of a dike at such
time as a dike may be required.
         b.   Tanks or groups of tanks containing crude petroleum or other
liquids which have a tendency to boil over shall be diked.
      2.   Capacity: Dikes surrounding tanks containing crude oil or other
flammable liquid subject to boil over shall have a capacity of not less than
the capacity of the tank surrounded and in addition shall have a suitable
coping or deflector pointing inward, so designed and constructed as to minimize
the effect of the boil over wave. Dike shall be not less than fifty feet (50')
from the shell of the tank surrounded.
      3.   Materials and Construction:
         a.   Dikes shall be constructed on earth, clay, solid masonry or
reinforced concrete not higher than one-half (1/2) of the height of the tank or
tanks enclosed, so constructed as to afford adequate protection.
         b.   Earthwork embankments shall be firmly and compactly built of good
earth or clay from which stones, vegetable matter and other foreign material
have been removed. They shall have a flat section at the top not less than two
and one-half feet (21/2') wide and a slope of at least one to one forty five
degrees (45°) on both sides.
         c.   Masonry or concrete dikes shall have footings below the frost
line.
         d.   If a concrete floor covering is provided for the area enclosed by
a concrete dike, a sump shall be provided at some convenient place, attached to
which shall be a pump of approved design so that any accumulation of water or
oil may be removed immediately.
      4.   No Openings Permitted: Embankments or dikes shall be continuous with
no openings for piping or roadway.
   G.   Pumps:
      1.   Enclosed Pumps and Motors:
         a.   Motors and pumps shall be located in a separate building not less
than ten feet (10') from tanks, loading docks, warehouses, garages and property
lines, except as provided in paragraph G2 herein. Any pumphouse hereafter
erected shall be of noncombustible construction.
         b.   Motor shall be of the polyphase, nonsparking or explosionproof
type, and shall be grounded to permanently moist earth.
         c.   If pumphouse is electrically lighted, lights shall be of the
vaporproof type, wiring shall be in sealed conduit, and the light switch shall
be of the explosionproof type, oil bath type or shall be placed outside the
building.
         d.   Motor starting switches shall be of the explosionproof type or
oil bath type if in a hazardous area.
         e.   Screened openings of not less than sixty four (64) square inches
each shall be constructed in opposite corners of floor line to provided proper
ventilation.
         f.   All doors of pumphouse shall open outward.
         g.   Doors shall be left open at all times when pumps are in
operation.
      2.   Unenclosed Pumps and Motors: If pumps and motors are located
entirely in the open, with no enclosure whatever, they may be located at or
under the loading dock. Motors and electrical equipment shall comply otherwise
with the provisions of paragraph G1 herein.
   H.   Pumps and Pipelines Associated With More Than One Flammable Liquid:
      1.   Gasoline and naphtha shall never be handled through the same pump
and pipelines as kerosene and fuel oils.
      2.   Pipelines shall have a definite color scheme for painting to
indicate the product which is being carried by the respective lines. The color
shall be red for gasoline and naphtha. Valves on lines to pumphouse shall be
tagged to denote the product handled and controlled by each valve.
      3.   Pumps delivering to or taking supply from tanks or tank car shall be
provided with valves on both suction and discharge of pump. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-
13-80)
4-5B-5: STORAGE BUILDINGS:
   A.   Warehouses:
      1.   Any warehouses hereafter erected or converted for the storage of
flammable liquids shall have noncombustible walls, roofs and floors and shall
be so constructed that refuse cannot accumulate under the floor.
      2.   Storage of liquids of Class I shall not be permitted. Storage of
liquids of Class II shall not be permitted except in original sealed containers
and no transfer of liquids in such containers to other containers shall every
be made inside the warehouse.
      3.   Warehouses shall be kept clean, neat and orderly, and free from
accumulation of grease and oil spillage.
      4.   The National Electrical Code as published in N.F.P.A. Pamphlet No.
70 in 1962 by the National Fire Protection Association, shall govern the
electrical installation.
   B.   Garages:
      1.   Floor of garage shall be of concrete or other noncombustible
material laid directly on the ground or on a well tamped and puddled fill.
      2.   Adequate ventilation shall be provided to carry off any inflammable
gases which may accumulate.
      3.   No connection to any house drainage or to any sewer system shall be
made from any garage waste basin, sink, floor drain or waste, unless an
adequate grease trap is provided ahead of such connection. This does not apply
to lavatories, toilets or wash or personal use, nor to downspouts carrying
surface water from the roof.
      4.   The National Electrical Code, as published in N.F.P.A. Pamphlet No.
70, in 1962, by the National Fire Protection Association, shall govern the
electrical installation. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5B-6: TANK TRUCKS AND TANK WAGONS:
   A.   Bulkheads: Compartment tanks shall be constructed with double bulkheads
unless they always carry the same class of liquids in the respective
compartments (Class I, II or III).
   B.   Separate Pipelines and Meters Required: Compartments of tank trucks
carrying different classes of liquids shall not be manifolded together.
Separate pipeline and meter shall be provided for each class of liquid to
eliminate hazard of mixing.
   C.   Distinguishing Numbers; Tags: Each compartment of tank shall be
numbered and the same number shall appear on pipeline at rear of truck
connected with that compartment. A serviceable metal tag shall be fastened
securely to each faucet, designating the contents of the compartment it
controls by lettering not less than one-fourth inch (1/4") high. Tags shall be
painted according to the same color scheme as the pipelines, 1  red always
indicating gasoline or naphtha.
   D.   Valves and Faucets:
      1.   Faucets shall be of the self-closing type.
      2.   All outlets of each cargo tank or compartment used for transporting
Class I or Class II flammable liquids or used for transporting Class III
flammable liquids having a viscosity less than forty five (45) second Saybolt
Universal at one hundred degrees (100°) Fahrenheit shall be equipped with a
reliable and efficient shutoff valve located inside the shell or in the sump
when it is an integral part of the shell, and designed so that the valve must
be kept closed except during loading and unloading operations. The operating
mechanism for the valve shall be provided with a secondary control, remote from
the fill openings and discharge faucets, for use in the event of accidents or
fire. The control mechanism shall be provided with a fusible section which will
permit valves to close automatically in case of fire. In every case there shall
be provided between the shutoff valve seat and discharge faucet a shear section
which will break under strain unless the discharge piping is so arranged as to
afford the same protection and leave the shutoff valve seat intact.
      3.   The outlets of each cargo tank used for transporting liquids having
a viscosity equal to or greater than forty five (45) seconds Saybolt universal
at one hundred degrees (100°) Fahrenheit shall be equipped with a suitable
shutoff valve, located internally, designed so that the valve will remain
operable is the external connection is sheared off.
   E.   Bumpers: Heavy bumper shall be provided across rear adequate to protect
all faucets in case of a rear-end collision.
   F.   Static Protection: Cargo tanks and vehicle chassis shall be
electrically bonded. Provision shall be made in the tank structure and vehicle
for the bonding of the vehicle to the fill page during the truck loading
operations. (Drag chains and straps, formerly specified for the purpose of
eliminating static charges, have been shown to be ineffective and their
elimination is recommended.)
   G.   Fire Extinguishers: Each tank truck or tank wagon shall carry an
approved fire extinguisher suitable for extinguishing gasoline and oil fires,
such as carbon tetrachloride, carbon dioxide, foam or powder.
   H.   Retail Sales from Tank Trucks Prohibited: No retail deliveries from
tank trucks or tank wagons shall be permitted in any public way or from
commonly used private roads in the Village, except in extreme emergencies for
relief purposes, and then only in quantities not to exceed two (2) gallons.
(Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection 4-5B-4H2 of this Article.
4-5B-7: LOADING AND UNLOADING OPERATIONS:
4-5B-7-1: LOADING AND UNLOADING DOCKS:
   A.   Location:
      1.   Unloading Docks: Location of unloading site with reference to
railroad tracks over which passenger trains are moved shall be subject at all
times to the regulations of the Bureau of Explosives of the Association of
American Railroads, and all amendments thereto, (formerly American Railway
Association), 30 Vesey Street, New York City.
      2.   Loading Docks: Truck loading docks and platforms shall be located
not less than twenty five feet (25') from storage tanks, plant buildings and
property lines, except existing installations, which shall be not less than ten
feet (10').
   B.   Electrical Equipment: All electric lights at loading and unloading
docks shall be of vaporproof construction. Electric wiring shall be in sealed
conduit at docks and switches shall be of the explosionproof type or placed at
some point remote from the docks. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5B-7-2: TANK TRUCK UNLOADING OPERATIONS:
   A.   Grounding: Before unloading operations are started and before any
connection or contact is made with piping or other unloading equipment, the
tank car shall be electrically grounded in an effective manner. Permanent
electrical connection of not less than No. 0 copper cable shall be made between
the rails on which tank cars stand and the piping system of the storage plant.
Note: This connection may be accomplished in two (2) ways. The rails may be
bonded by means of standard rail bonds and connected to the permanent piping
system with No. 0 electric cable connections at each end of the loading or
unloading sections; or a similar connection may be made between each rail on
which cars stand and the permanent piping system.
   B.   Prohibited Methods of Unloading:
      1.   Unloading by Gravity: The withdrawal of liquids from tank cars
through bottom outlets shall not be permitted. Tank cars shall be unloaded
through dome (manhole) only. Pumps required to accomplish this shall be of
approved type and securely installed. However, fuel oils may be unloaded by
gravity.
      2.   Use of Compressed Air: The use of compressed air to discharge
contents of tank cars is prohibited, but this shall not be construed to prevent
the use of a standard system employing an inert gas, such as carbon dioxide or
nitrogen, as pressure generating medium for this purpose.
      3.   Unloading to Portable Containers: Unloading from tank cars to tank
trucks or to any other portable container shall not be permitted.
   C.   Dome Covers: After unloading pipe is inserted into dome of tank car and
before any pumping is done, dome shall be tightly covered with wet burlap or
some other type of cover equally effective. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5B-7-3: TANK TRUCK LOADING OPERATIONS:
Before loading operations begin, tank trucks shall be electrically bonded to
pipeline by means of a bonding device at loading dock. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5B-7-4: OTHER RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   All connections between tank cars and pipelines shall be in good
condition and not permit leakage.
   B.   Tank cars shall not be left connected to pipelines except when loading
or unloading is going on, and during all such times a competent man shall be
present and in charge.
   C.   The presence of flame lanterns, flame switch lights or other exposed
flame lights or fires during the process of loading or unloading is prohibited.
   D.   Sidings used in connection with tank car unloading operations shall not
be common to other users, or they shall be provided with necessary derails or
with warning signs in accordance with section 4, paragraph 697 (b) of the
Interstate Commerce Commission Regulations on the Transportation of Explosives.
   E.   The unloading of tank cars and all operations in connection therewith
shall be in full accordance with the Rules and Regulations of the Interstate
Commerce Commission (See section 4, paragraph 697, Interstate Commerce
Regulations for the Transportation of Explosives effective October 1, 1930) and
all amendments thereto. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5B-7-5: PRESENCE OF COMPETENT PERSON REQUIRED:
During loading and unloading of tank trucks and tank wagons, a competent person
shall be present and in charge at all times. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5B-8: STORAGE OF BARRELS AND DRUMS:
   A.   Barrels and drums used for Class I liquids, whether full or empty,
shall be stored in the open or on open platforms in plant yard. Platforms may
have roofs, but all sides shall be open.
   B.   No open lights shall be permitted in such storage yard.
   C.   Caps, bungs and plugs shall be closed tightly immediately after
container is emptied.
   D.   Gasoline and naphtha shall be handled only in barrels or drums painted
red and properly labeled and no other liquids shall be handled in such red
barrels or drums. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5B-9: PROTECTION OF PROPERTY:
   A.   Fencing: Apparatus dispensing Class I flammable liquids into the fuel
tanks of motor vehicles of the public shall not be located at a bulk plant
unless separated by a fence or similar barrier from the area in which bulk
operations are conducted.
   B.   Maintenance: Property shall be kept free from weeds, high grass,
rubbish and litter, and shall be kept neat, clean and orderly throughout.
   C.   Fire Protections:
      1.   Open light or flame shall not be permitted on the property.
      2.   Approved chemical fire extinguishers, foam generators or other
smothering agents for extinguishing oil fires shall be provided. (Ord. 0-80-
151, 3-13-80)
4-5B-10: APPROVAL OF PLANS:
Drawings or blueprints made to scale shall be submitted in triplicate to the
Village President and shall be approved by him before any new installation,
addition or remodeling is undertaken. Drawings shall:
   A.   Show the plot of ground to be utilized and its immediate surroundings
on all sides; the complete layout of tanks, loading and unloading docks,
equipment and buildings; the capacity of each tank, kind of liquid to be
stored; type of tank supports; type of construction of each building; and all
clearances as provided in subsection 4-5B-2B and C, 4-5B-4G1 and 4-5B-7-1A2 of
this Article. In addition, the dimensions of any tank with a capacity of more
than fifty thousand (50,000) gallons shall be given.
   B.   Show the name of the person proposing the installation, the location
with respect to the Village, and shall name adjacent railroads and streets.
   C.   Designate passenger, freight, passing and side tracks and shall show
the clearances between tracks at the point where tank car will be placed for
unloading and nearest passenger tracks, and between unloading dock and closest
passenger tracks.
   D.   Be accompanied by an application for approval made out in triplicate on
blanks furnished by the Village President. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-1980)

4-5C-1: PURPOSE:
It is the intention of the Village President by this Article to grant permits
for self-service stations in the Village under conditions providing maximum
safety from fire and explosion hazards to the owners of said station and to the
customers thereof and the public generally. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-1980)
4-5C-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Article, the terms specified in this Section have the meanings
ascribed to them as follows:
APPROVED SELF-SERVICE DISPENSING DEVICE: Any device for the dispensing of Class
I, II or III liquids into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles as approved by the
Village President pursuant to this Article.
ATTENDANT: The owner or any person who is paid wages by an owner of a service
station to dispense motor fuel at such service station.
OWNER: Any individual(s) or legal entity holding title, lease, license or any
interest in a service station or self- service station. The legal name,
residence and address of any individuals who are owners shall be filed with the
Village President.
SELF-SERVICE STATION: That portion of property of a service station where
flammable and combustible liquids used as motor fuels are stored and
subsequently dispensed from fixed approved dispensing equipment into the fuel
tanks of motor vehicles by persons other than the service station attendant.
SERVICE STATION: Any place of business where Class I, II or III liquids are
sold or offered for sale at retail, and dispensed into the fuel tanks of motor
vehicles. This definition shall also include the private storage and dispensing
of such products for the same purposes as those served by a service station,
whether the storage is maintained for the use or benefit of the owner, lessee,
agents or employees of either, or of any others.
The requirements covering service stations shall also govern underground
storage maintained at general storage plants and places other than service
stations, so far as applicable. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5C-3: APPROVAL OF PLANS:
Drawings or blueprints made to scale shall be submitted in triplicate to the
Village President and shall be approved by him before any new construction,
addition or remodeling is undertaken. Drawings shall carry the name of the
person proposing the installation, the location with reference to the Village,
and shall in addition show the following:
   A.   The plot to be utilized and its immediate surroundings on all sides;
all property lines to be designated and adjacent streets and highways to be
named.
   B.   The complete installation as proposed, including tanks and their
capacities, class of liquids to be stored, pumps, buildings, drives and all
equipment.
   C.   Clearance from tanks to property lines as required by this Chapter.
   D.   Type of construction of service station building or buildings, with
clear showing that there will be no basement, cellar or excavation under any
portion.
   E.   Location of basements, cellars or pits of other buildings on the
property or on adjacent property, and location of tanks with reference thereto
as required by this Chapter. If a building has no basement, cellar or pit, make
note to that effect.
   F.   Location of sewers, manholes, catch basins, cesspools, septic tanks,
wells or cisterns (whether on the property, on adjacent property or in
adjoining streets, highways or alleys), and location of tanks with reference
thereto as required by this Chapter. If there is no sewer, manhole or catch
basin in a street or alley, or no sewer, cesspool, septic tank, well or cistern
on a property, make notation to that effect in proper place.
   G.   Location of vent pipe outlets as required by this Chapter and location
of fill pipes as required.
   H.   Ventilation of greasing pit as required by subsection 4-5C-13C of this
Article, if greasing pit is located within a building or an enclosure.
   I.   A complete showing of type of heat and heating arrangement as required
by subsection 4-5C-12B2 of this Article.
   J.   Drawings shall be accompanied by an application for approval made out
in triplicate on blanks furnished by the Village President. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-
13-80)
4-5C-4: UNDERGROUND STORAGE AND STORAGE LIMITS:
   A.   Service station storage shall be underground and the combined capacity
of the storage tanks of Class I and Class II flammable liquids shall not exceed
thirty thousand (30,000) gallons.
   B.   Class III flammable liquids storage at service stations shall be
underground and shall not exceed thirty thousand (30,000) gallons.
   C.   Underground fuel oil tank connected to the station heater and
underground tank for receiving crank case drainings need not be counted in
computing the combined capacity.
   D.   The underground storage limit may be increased at industrial plants
where a larger storage is required for manufacturing operations and also at
airports, bus and truck terminals and installations where operating
requirements make a larger storage necessary and in segregated locations. (Ord.
0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5C-5: TANK SPECIFICATIONS:
   A.   Tanks shall bear label of Underwriters' Laboratories or meet equivalent
specifications.
   B.   Tanks shall be thoroughly coated on the outside with tar, asphaltum or
other suitable rust-resisting material.
   C.   Tanks shall not be surrounded or covered by cinders or other material
of corrosive effect. If the soil contains corrosive material, special
protection shall be provided. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5C-6: TANK LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Distance to Basements: Individual tanks of a capacity up to two
thousand (2,000) gallons shall be buried so that the tops of the tanks shall be
lower than all floors, basements, cellars or pits of buildings within ten feet
(10'), on or off the property, or tanks shall maintain a full clearance of ten
feet (10') thereto; for individual tanks of a capacity of more than two
thousand (2,000) gallons and up to six thousand (6,000) gallons, the distance
shall be twenty feet (20'); for individual tanks of a capacity of more than six
thousand (6,000) gallons and up to twenty thousand (20,000) gallons, this
distance shall be twenty five feet (25').
   B.   Distance to Sewers and Wells: Individual tanks of a capacity up to two
thousand (2,000) gallons shall be buried so that the tops of the tanks shall be
lower than the bottom level of all sewers, manholes, catch basins, cesspools,
septic tanks, wells or cisterns within ten feet (10'), on or off the property,
or tanks shall maintain a full clearance of ten feet (10') thereto; for
individual tanks of a capacity of more than two thousand (2,000) gallons and up
to six thousand (6,000) gallons, the distance shall be twenty feet (20'); for
individual tanks of a capacity of more than six thousand (6,000) gallons, the
distance shall be twenty five feet (25').
The term "sewer" includes a sewer line out of service station buildings;
provided, however, these clearances shall not be required to a sewer line out
of a service station if such sewer line is constructed throughout of cast iron
with leaded joints.
   C.   Distance to Property Lines: Individual tanks of a capacity up to two
thousand (2,000) gallons shall maintain a ten foot (10') clearance to property
lines; for individual tanks of a capacity of more than two thousand (2,000)
gallons and up to six thousand (6,000) gallons, the distance shall be twenty
feet (20'); for individual tanks of a capacity of more than six thousand
(6,000) gallons and up to twenty thousand (20,000) gallons, the distance shall
be twenty five feet (25'); provided, however, that these clearances on the side
adjacent to a public street, alley or highway may be waived by consent of the
authorities having immediate jurisdiction over the public street, alley or
highway if it can be shown that the required sewer clearances can be
maintained.
   D.   Distance to Special Classes of Property: Tanks and pumps shall maintain
a clearance of not less than three hundred feet (300') to any mine shaft, air
or escape shaft for any mine, and eighty five feet (85') to any schoolhouse,
hospital or church. The distance shall be measured from the nearest points of
tanks and pumps to the nearest points of buildings or shafts. (Ord. 0-80-151,
3-13-80)
4-5C-7: INSTALLATION OF TANKS:
   A.   Where tanks are not subject to being driven over, they shall be buried
so that their tops will be not less than two feet (2') below the surface of the
ground or beneath twelve inches (12") of earth and a slab of reinforced
concrete not less than four inches (4") in thickness; slab shall be set on a
firm, well tamped earth foundation and shall extend at least one foot (1')
beyond the outline of the tank in all directions.
   B.   Where tank site is subject to traffic by heavy vehicles, the total
coverage above the top of the tank shall be not less than three feet (3');
provided, however, that where the area over tanks is paved with reinforced
concrete not less than six inches (6") in thickness, the total coverage may be
reduced to two feet (2').
   C.   Where necessary to prevent floating, tanks shall be securely anchored
or weighted.
   D.   Tanks shall be set on a firm foundation and surrounded with fill sand
well tamped in place.
   E.   Tops of tanks shall be below the level of any piping to which tanks may
be connected.
   F.   Tanks installed under the floor of a building or structure shall be so
located with respect to building foundations and supports that the loads
carried by the latter cannot be transmitted to the tank. Fill openings and vent
pipes must be outside and the installation must comply with all other
requirements established in this Chapter. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5C-8: PIPES:
   A.   General Requirements: Piping shall conform to the requirements set out
in Article B of this Chapter.
   B.   Vent Pipes:
      1.   Each tank shall be provided with a vent pipe, connected with the top
of the tank and carried up to the outer air. Pipe shall be arranged for proper
drainage to storage tank and its lower end shall not extend through top of tank
for a distance of more than one inch (1"); it shall have no traps or pockets.
      2.   Upper end of pipe shall be provided with a goose-neck or "T"
attachment, or weatherproof hood.
      3.   Vent pipe shall be of sufficient cross-sectional area to permit
escape of air and gas during the filling operation and in no case less than one
and one-fourth inches (11/4") in diameter. If a power pump is used in filling
storage tank and a tight connection is made to the fill pipe, the vent pipe
shall not be smaller than the full pipe.
      4.   Vent pipe shall terminate outside of building not less than twelve
feet (12') above top of fill pipe, not less than four feet (4'), measured
vertically and horizontally, from any window or other building opening, and not
less than fifteen feet (15'), measured horizontally, from any opening into the
basement, cellar or pit of any building, and in a location which will not
permit pocketing of gas. If a tight connection is made in the filling line, the
terminus of vent pipe shall be carried to a point one foot (1') above the level
of the highest reservoir from which tank may be filled.
      5.   Vent pipes from two (2) or more tanks of the same class of liquid
may be connected to one upright or main header. Area of header shall equal the
combined area of the pipes connected to it. Connection to the header shall be
not less than one foot (1') above the level of the top of the highest reservoir
from which tanks may be filled. However, separate vent pipes are recommended.
   C.   Fill Pipes:
      1.   Fill pipes shall be carried to a location outside of any building as
remote as possible from any doorway or other opening into any building and in
no case closer than five feet (5') from any such opening.
      2.   Location shall be in a place where there is minimum danger of
breakage from trucks or other vehicles.
      3.   Each fill pipe shall be closed by a screw cap or other tight fitting
cap, preferably of a type which can be locked. Cap shall be locked at all times
when filling or gauging process is not going on. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5C-9: PUMPS:
   A.   Pumps for Class I and II Flammable Liquids: Class I and Class II
flammable liquids shall be transferred from underground tanks by means of fixed
pumps so designed and equipped as to allow control of the flow and to prevent
leakage or accidental discharge. Supplemental means shall be provided outside
of the dispensing device whereby the source of power may be readily
disconnected in the event of fire or other accident. Dispensing devices for
Class I and Class II flammable liquids shall be withdrawn from tanks by means
of approved pumps equipped with metallic lined hose and nonferrous discharge
nozzle.
   B.   Dispensing Areas: No pump shall be located within a building. However,
approved pumps within garages will be permitted provided the dispensing area is
not below grade, is separated from motor vehicle repair areas, pits and
basements and the dispensing unit and its piping are protected against physical
damage from vehicles by mounting on a concrete island or by equivalent means
and is located in a position where it cannot be struck by a vehicle descending
a ramp or other slope out of control. The dispensing area also shall be
provided with an approved mechanical or gravity ventilation system. A clearly
identified switch, readily accessible in case of fire or physical damage to any
dispensing units shall be provided to shut off the power to dispensing units.
Existing dispensing units located below grade must have independent mechanical
ventilation systems and the entire dispensing area shall be protected by an
approved automatic sprinkler system. The ventilation systems shall be
electrically interlocked with the gasoline dispensing units so that the
dispensing units cannot be operated unless the ventilating fan motors are
energized.
   C.   Electrical Regulations: Wiring of electric pumps and all electrical
equipment in connection therewith shall conform to Article 500 of the 1962
Edition of the National Electrical Code, N.F.P.A. Pamphlet No. 70, published by
the National Fire Protection Association.
   D.   Gravity Discharges: Devices which discharge by gravity shall be so
designed that it is impossible to retain in the gauging compartment materially
more than ten (10) gallons of liquid, and so that it is not possible to lock
the device without draining the liquid.
   E.   Setback Requirements: Setback of pump islands from street lines and
drive-in arrangements are subject to approval of the authorities having
jurisdiction over the street, highway or road.
   F.   Prohibitions:
      1.   Curb pumps or pumps located in any portion of a public street are
prohibited.
      2.   Systems which employ continuous air pressure on storage tank in
connection with gauging or vending devices are prohibited.
      3.   The use of aboveground storage tanks in connection with gauging or
vending devices is prohibited.
      4.   Apparatus for dispensing flammable liquids into fuel tanks of
vehicles shall not be connected to bulk storage tanks. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5C-10: LABELING CONTAINERS AND PUMPS:
All visible containers of gasoline and kerosene and all devices used for
drawing such products from underground storage containers at filling stations,
garages or other places where such products are sold or offered for sale shall
be marked or labeled in a conspicuous place with the name of such product.
(Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5C-11: UNLOADING OPERATIONS:
   A.   Unloading hose from tank truck into underground tank shall be metallic
lined or its equivalent and shall be equipped with a nonferrous nozzle or tight
connection metal nipple.
   B.   During unloading operations, a competent person shall be present and in
charge at all times.
   C.   If underground tank is supplied through permanent pipe connection to an
aboveground general storage tank, filling process may be by power driven pump
or gravity. In addition to valves at aboveground tanks, a valve shall be
installed within control of service station personnel. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5C-12: BUILDING REGULATIONS AND REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Construction Regulations:
      1.   Floor level shall be above grade so as to prevent flow of liquids or
vapors into building and shall preferably be of concrete.
      2.   No basement or excavation shall hereafter be constructed under any
service station building. Existing basements under service stations shall be
provided with mechanical ventilation or eliminated and only nonsparking,
explosionproof motors and compressors shall be permitted in existing basements.
   B.   Heating Systems:
      1.   No furnaces or heaters shall be located in existing service station
basements.
      2.   Heating systems in service stations that have rooms or stalls for
greasing or servicing motor vehicles shall be of a type that will preclude the
likelihood of gasoline gas reaching the heaters. The following types are
acceptable:
         a.   Steam, hot water or warm air furnaces, cut off from the balance
of the building by eight inch (8") masonry walls. The ceiling shall be of two
(2) coats of cement plaster over metal lath or equivalent fire-resistive
construction. The door to heater room shall open from the outside of the
building. No openings shall be permitted on the inside walls except those
necessary for passage of air ducts. If warm air heat is used, no cold air
return shall be taken closer than thirty inches (30") from the level of grease
room floor.
In some instances, it is possible to have heater room door open from the office
room, where heater room door is sufficiently distant from grease room door to
make the travel of gasoline gas to the heater room a remote possibility. Added
safety provided if the floor of the office is higher than the floor of the
grease room, or if a six inch (6") concrete ledge is placed across the door
opening at the floor in the grease room door or furnace room door, or both, as
gasoline gas is heavier than air and these features tend to block its flow.
         b.   The following types of heat are acceptable without enclosure:
            (1)   Suspended, approved type, oil or gas fired, warm air
furnaces. These shall be suspended from the ceiling joists and shall be
approximately eight feet (8') above the level of the grease room floor. Cold
air returns shall be not less than thirty inches (30") from the level of the
grease room floor.
            (2)   Gas or oil fired unit heaters shall be mounted eight feet
(8') above the level of the grease room floor.
            (3)   Electric heating units and equipment located within the
possible path of vapor travel shall be designed and installed so as not to
create an ignition hazard and shall conform with the 1962 Edition of the
National Electrical Code, N.F.P.A. Pamphlet No. 70, as published by the
National Fire Protection Association.
            (4)   In single stall stations, a stove may be used if mounted
eighteen inches (18") above the floor. Oil heat is recommended.
            (5)   Stoves may be used in the office section if they are cut off
by partitions from the grease room and the stoves are mounted above the floor
level.
   C.   Greasing Pits:
      1.   Every greasing pit installed within a building or enclosed by three
(3) or more walls shall be ventilated by a vent duct not less than six inches
(6") in diameter (or equivalent cross-sectional area if a noncircular duct is
used.) Duct shall start within four inches (4") of the floor and shall be
extended on an upward diagonal or by an easy bend over to sidewall, thence
straight up through roof to a height sufficient to draw off gasoline vapors
which may accumulate in bottom of pit. Abrupt bends must be avoided and all
joints must be tight. Floor of pit shall pitch slightly toward corner where
duct is located to facilitate flow of gases to duct.
      2.   Gasoline or naphtha shall never be used to clean out any pit,
whether pit is located within a building or enclosure, or outside in the open.
      3.   No sewer connection shall be permitted from any greasing pit unless
protected with an approved grease trap which will effectively intercept greases
and oils and prevent their entry into the sewer. Trap shall be kept cleaned
out.
      4.   If electrically lighted, globes shall be of vaporproof construction
and wiring in conduit.
      5.   If sewer connection is permitted by the Village, an adequate grease
trap shall be provided to intercept greases and oils. Trap shall be cleaned out
at least every thirty (30) days. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5C-13: SAFETY REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Flammable Liquids Within Building:
      1.   No gasoline, naphtha or other liquids of Class I shall be kept
inside of service station.
      2.   No alcohol or other flammable antifreeze solutions shall be kept
inside of service station except in original sealed containers. No transfer of
such liquids from these receptacles to other receptacles shall be made inside
the service station.
   B.   Ignition to be Shut Off: The fuel tank of no motor vehicle shall be
serviced until motor and ignition have been shut off.
   C.   No Smoking: No smoking shall be permitted on premises at any time.
   D.   Open Flames: No open lights or flames shall be permitted about premises
except in stove within station building.
   E.   Refuse Removed: Premises shall be kept neat and clean, and free from
rubbish and trash.
   F.   Cleaning with Flammable Liquids Prohibited: Cleaning with gasoline,
naphtha, or other highly inflammable liquids of Classes I and II shall not be
permitted in or around the service station.
   G.   Leaking Underground Tanks: Underground tanks which develop leaks or
which are permanently discontinued in service shall be removed promptly or
shall be filled with sand. The sand is to be flushed in with water until a
complete sand fill is secured.
   H.   Fire Extinguishers: Each service station shall be equipped with at
least one approved chemical fire extinguisher suitable for oil or gasoline
fires.
   I.   Fireworks: The sale, use, explosion or handling of fireworks, including
sparklers, toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns and toy pistol paper caps is
prohibited on any service station premises. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5C-14: BULK SALES PROHIBITED:
No motor fuels shall be dispensed at any service station except directly into
the fuel tanks of motor vehicles, when such tanks are connected with the
carburation systems of such vehicles; provided, however, that individual sales
up to six (6) gallons may be made in metal or approved receptacles when painted
or colored red and labeled in full conformity with the Illinois Red Can
Gasoline Law, 1  such individual sales to be limited to six (6) gallons to any
one person. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. ch. 127/2, ¶151.
4-5C-15: SELF-SERVICE REGULATIONS:
4-5C-15-1: SELF-SERVICE RESTRICTED:
Except at service stations which hold current and valid self- service station
permits issued pursuant to this Article by the Village President, no person
other than an owner of a service station, or an employee of such owner, shall
use or operate any motor fuel dispensing equipment at any service station. No
owner of a service station shall permit any person to violate the provisions of
this Article. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5C-15-2: SELF-SERVICE STATION PERMITS:
   A.   Application for Permit; Plans: Application of self-service permits
shall be filed in the office of the Village President. Self-service station
permits may be issued by the Village President upon written application in form
to be established by said Village President, accompanied by complete, detailed
plans, in triplicate, for each service station sought to be used for self-
service. Such plans shall be drawn to scale, and shall include the following:
      1.   Lot lines and dimensions.
      2.   Building lines and dimensions.
      3.   Location and size of tanks and pump islands.
      4.   Location of control station.
      5.   Type, make, model and location of dispensing devices or equipment.
      6.   Fire extinguisher locations.
      7.   Clearances.
      8.   Such other relevant information as may be requested by the Village
President.
No construction of self-service station or modification of an existing service
station to conduct self-service business shall be commenced until such
application and plans are given written approval by the Village President; no
such station shall open for business until inspected and approved by the
Village President, and until the village President issues a self-service
station permit, which must be displayed prominently, at all times, at such
self-service station.
   B.   Term of Permit: Self-service permits shall be initially issued for a
period of not less than six (6) months nor greater than eighteen (18) months,
at the discretion of the Village President.
   C.   Renewal Permits: Renewal permits shall be issued for a period of twelve
(12) months. (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5C-15-3: SELF-SERVICE STATION RULES:
The following rules shall be followed at all self-service stations, and
violation of any said rules shall constitute good and just cause for suspension
or revocation of a self- service station permit by the Village President:
   A.   Public Self-Service Stations; Attendant Required:
      1.   The installation or use of unattended self-service dispensing
devices for motor fuel of any kind is hereby prohibited.
      2.   At all times when a self-service station is open for public use, not
less than one attendant shall be on duty, and no motor fuel shall be dispensed
at any time when such attendant is not at or near the control station or pump
island. The attendant's primary duty shall be to supervise the dispensing of
motor fuels, motor oils and services normally related to such dispensing. Such
attendant shall refuse service to any person who is smoking or who appears for
any reason to be unable to dispense fuel safely, and shall shut off the
dispensing unit if a patron fails to follow instructions in compliance with the
rules. All attendants and other employees of the service station shall be
thoroughly instructed in the operation and use of the communications system,
the control station, the fire extinguishing equipment, the operation of the
dispensing units and safety regulations for the dispensing of motor fuels.
      3.   Approved self-service dispensing devices are permitted at service
stations available and open to the public; provided, that all dispensing of
Class I, II or III liquids by a person other than the service station attendant
is under the supervision and control of a qualified attendant and the
dispensing nozzle is a listed automatic closing type without a hold open latch,
and must be approved by the Village President.
      4.   It shall be the responsibility of the attendant to (i) dispense
Class I, II or III liquids into approved portable containers, (ii) control
sources of ignition and (iii) immediately handle accidental spills and fire
extinguishers if needed.
      5.   The attendant on duty shall be mentally and physically capable of
performing the functions and assuming the responsibility prescribed in this
Section.
   B.   Nonpublic Locations: Dispensing of Class I, II or III liquids at
locations not open to the public does not require an attendant or supervisor.
Such locations may be used by commercial, industrial, governmental or
manufacturing establishments for fueling vehicles used in connection with their
business. However, this shall not include private fraternal clubs or
associations.
   C.   Special Dispensing Devices: Special dispensing devices for motor fuel
are not to be installed or used without prior written approval of the Village
President.
   D.   Dwelling and Sleeping Facilities Prohibited: No dwelling unit or
sleeping facilities of any kind for the owner, attendant or any person shall be
permitted at a self-service station.
   E.   Fire Extinguisher: One type of ABC fire extinguisher with a capacity of
ten (10) pounds shall be provided for each pump island containing four (4) or
less dispensing pumps; on pump island containing more than four (4) dispensing
pumps, an additional extinguisher shall be provided for each additional
dispensing pump or fraction thereof. Such extinguishers shall be located at
points approved by the Village President, away from the dispensing area but
close enough to the dispensing area to be readily available. Such extinguishers
shall be plainly marked, shall be protected from the weather and shall be
maintained in operable condition and available at all times when the self-
service station is open to the public. All employees of the self-service
station shall be thoroughly instructed as to the location and proper use of
such extinguishers, and shall, upon request, demonstrate their ability in such
use to the approval of representatives of the Village President.
   F.   Signs:
      1.   Signs giving instructions for the operation of gasoline dispensing
equipment must be conspicuously posted at each self-service station offering
self-service.
      2.   Signs bearing the following words must be conspicuously posted on
each gasoline pump island where self-service is offered: (i) "Self-Service
Island"; (ii) "Warning"; (iii) "Stop Engine"; (iv) "No Smoking"; (v) "It is
unlawful and dangerous for anyone other than the attendant to dispense gasoline
into approved containers"; (vi) 'It is unlawful and dangerous to dispense
gasoline without an attendant on duty".
      3.   The signs shall be made of all-weather rigid material and the
wording, lettering, size, design, material, mounting and location of said sign
shall be subject to the approval of the Village President.
   G.   Collision Protection: All fuel dispensing units shall be mounted or
protected against collision damage by suitable means in a manner approved by
the Village President.
   H.   Control Station:
      1.   Every self-service station shall maintain a control station in a
location approved by the Village President, equipped in such manner that the
flow of liquid fuel from any or all fuel dispensing units may be stopped from
such control station.
      2.   A master electric switch shall be maintained at such control station
so that electric power and pump lighting to all pumps may be disconnected at
one time and said switch shall be plainly marked and easily accessible.
      3.   The control station shall be located at ground level not more than
one hundred feet (100') from the farthest pump. The control station shall be so
located that the attendant of such control station shall have a clear and
unobstructed view of all pumps.
      4.   The attendant shall at all times be able to communicate with persons
in the dispensing area. The Village President may in his discretion require a
communication system between the control station and each pump island. (Ord. 0-
80-151, 3-13-80)
4-5C-15-4: PERMIT ISSUANCE REFUSAL, REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION:
The Village President may, for failure to comply with these rules, for
violation thereof, or for other good and just cause, refuse to issue or renew
or suspend or revoke a self- service station permit. The Village President
shall serve notice of such refusal, suspension or revocation on the applicant
for or holder of such permit by personal service or by certified or registered
mail. If the applicant for or holder of such permit, within ten (10) days after
notice of such refusal, suspension or revocation is served, shall file in the
office of the Village President written request for a hearing, the Village
President shall grant a hearing. Any order or decision made by the Village
President upon such hearing shall be an "administrative decision" within the
meaning of the "Administrative Review Act" 1 . (Ord. 0-80-151, 3-13-1980)
 
Notes
1 1. 735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.
ARTICLE D. FLAMMABLE GASES
SECTION:
4-5D-1: Prohibition Of Tanks Used To Store Flammable Gases
4-5D-2: Exceptions
4-5D-3: Permits
4-5D-4: Enforcement
4-5D-5: Penalties
4-5D-1: PROHIBITION OF TANKS USED TO STORE FLAMMABLE GASES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, maintain, store or house any
tank used to store flammable gases except as set forth in Section
4-5D-2 of this Article. (Ord. 0-99-571, 5-13-1999)
4-5D-2: EXCEPTIONS:
The restriction set forth in Section
4-5D-1 of this Article shall not apply to the following:
   A.   Tanks with a capacity of less than ten (10) cubic feet of flammable
gas, provided that no more than two (2) tanks are possessed, maintained, stored
or housed on the same property.
   B.   Tank(s) possessed, maintained, stored or housed by any unit of
government.
   C.   Tank(s) utilized by any not-for-profit organization on the premises for
no longer than one week.
   D.   Tank(s) utilized for the construction of any improvement, provided the
capacity of said tank(s) does not exceed five hundred (500) cubic feet and said
tank(s) is permitted in accordance with Section
4-5D-3 of this Article.
   E.   A tank utilized for the operation of an electrical generator, provided
that no more than one tank with a capacity of not greater than five hundred
(500) cubic feet is possessed, maintained, stored or housed on the property for
not greater than one hundred twenty (120) days and said tank is permitted in
accordance with Section
4-5D-3 of this Article. (Ord. 0-99-571, 5-13-1999)
4-5D-3: PERMITS:
Any person desiring to possess, maintain, store or house a tank to be utilized
for the construction of any improvement or operation of an electrical generator
shall obtain a permit from the Village. Prior to the issuance of any permit,
the person shall provide the Village with a completed tank permit application
and accompanying permit fee. The permit fee shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00) for each tank with a capacity of up to five hundred (500) cubic feet.
A permit issued in conjunction with subsection 4-5D-2D of this Article shall
expire on the earlier of completion of construction or one hundred twenty (120)
days from the date of issuance. A permit issued in conjunction with subsection
4-5D-2E of this Article shall expire one hundred twenty (120) days from the
date of issuance. (Ord. 0-99-571, 5-13-1999)
4-5D-4: ENFORCEMENT:
A representative of the Village shall be allowed to inspect any tank permitted
under Section
4-5D-3 of this Article during normal business hours. Any permit issued pursuant
to Section
4-5D-3 of this Article may be revoked by the Village if a Village
representative determines that the tank poses a threat to the health, safety or
welfare of the residents of the Village or any individual in the immediate area
of said tank. (Ord. 0-99-571, 5-13-1999)
4-5D-5: PENALTIES:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be fined not
less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00)
for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day
during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 0-99-571, 5-13-1999)

4-6-1: FINDINGS:
The growth of weeds, the presence of brush piles and dead trees, within the
village harbors pests and nuisance wildlife and poses safety risks which
interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of life and property and tends to
depreciate the value of the property of residents of the village. (Ord. 2016-
1122, 6-9-2016)
4-6-2: HEIGHT LIMITS:
It shall be unlawful for anyone to permit any weeds, grass or plants, other
than trees, bushes, flowers or other ornamental plants, to grow to a height
exceeding eight inches (8") anywhere in the village which is zoned A-2 or A-
3 under the village zoning ordinance excepting those areas authorized by the
village to exist in natural form; any such plants or weeds exceeding such
heights are hereby declared to be a nuisance. (Ord. 2016-1122, 6-9-2016)
4-6-3: NOTICE TO ABATE:
The building officer shall have the authority to serve or cause to be served a
notice upon the owner or occupant of any premises on which weeds or plants have
been permitted to grow over eight inches (8") high or on which dead trees or
piles of brush have been determined to be a safety hazard or nuisance by the
building officer or are found to be in violation of the provisions of this
chapter. The notice shall demand the abatement of the nuisance within ten (10)
days.
If a second notice is needed, the chief of police shall have the responsibility
to serve or cause to be served the notice upon the owner or occupant of any
premises found in violation of the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2016-1122,
6-9-2016)
4-6-4: ABATEMENT BY VILLAGE:
If the person so served does not abate the nuisance within ten (10) days after
such notice, the building officer shall proceed to abate such nuisance, keeping
an account of the expense of the abatement, and such expense shall be charged
and paid by such owner or occupant. (Ord. 2016-1122, 6-9-2016)
4-6-5: WEED CUTTING, BRUSH, AND TREE DEBRIS REMOVAL LIEN:
Charges for such weed, brush and tree removal shall be a lien upon the
premises. Whenever a bill for such charges remains unpaid for sixty (60) days
after it has been rendered, the village clerk may file with the Cook County
recorder of deeds, a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain a
legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, the
date or dates when such bill was incurred, and a notice that the village claims
a lien for this amount. Notice of such lien claim shall be mailed to the owner
of the premises if his address is known; provided, however, that failure of the
village clerk to record such lien claim or to mail such notice, or the failure
of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right to foreclose the
lien for such charges. (Ord. 2016-1122, 6-9-2016)
4-6-6: RECOVERY OF ABATEMENT COSTS:
   A.   Property subject to a lien for unpaid weed cutting, brush and/or tree
removal charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the same and the proceeds of
such sale shall be applied to pay for charges after deducting costs, as is the
case in the foreclosing of statutory liens.
   B.   The attorney for the village is hereby authorized and directed to
institute such proceedings, in the name of the village, in any court having
jurisdiction over such matter, against any property for which a bill for weed
cutting, brush and/or tree removal has remained unpaid sixty (60) days after it
has been rendered. (Ord. 2016-1122, 6-9-2016)
4-6-7: DISEASED AND DEAD TREES:
   A.   Right To Inspect: The officers, employees, and agents of the village
are hereby authorized and directed to enter upon private property where any
dead, diseased or substantially dead trees are located to ascertain whether or
not a public health, or safety hazard, or public nuisance exists.
   B.   Infected And Diseased Trees Declared A Nuisance: Any tree of any
species determined to be infected and/or diseased, by an agent of the village
or by laboratory analysis by the section of applied botany and plant pathology,
Illinois natural history survey or any laboratory approved by same, are hereby
declared to be a public nuisance.
   C.   Dead Trees And Brush Piles Declared A Nuisance: Trees determined by an
agent of the village to be dead or substantially dead, and any piles of brush
determined to be a public health or safety risk by the building officer are
hereby declared to be public nuisances.
   D.   Duty Of Owner/Occupant/Agent To Abate: The owner, occupant, or agent of
a parcel of land on which any dead, diseased, or infected trees exist shall
treat the infected trees with an approved treatment system administered by a
qualified, licensed professional or remove and destroy said tree(s), or cause
the same to occur within ten (10) days of notification to such owner, occupant,
or agent that the tree has been determined to be dead, diseased, or infected.
No chips or other particles resulting from such removal operation shall exceed
one inch (1") in any dimension. All stumps of such dead, diseased, or infected
trees shall be removed to a depth of not less than eight inches (8") below the
ground surface and then covered with soil of the same depth. No ash material or
other diseased or infected tree material shall be removed from any quarantine
zone unless such removal is done consistent with the provisions of the state or
federal quarantine. Notwithstanding any other provisions in this chapter to the
contrary, all removal operations for dead, diseased, or infected trees shall
fully comply with all applicable state and federal statutes and/or regulations.
   E.   Notice To Abate: Should the building officer identify a dead, diseased,
or infected tree or brush pile, and determine that a public health or safety
risk exists or that a public nuisance exists, notice must be provided to the
owner, occupant or agent as follows:
      1.   Notice shall be sent by certified mail or personally served upon the
person to whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes on the property for
the taxable year immediately preceding the removal activities; and
      2.   Such notice shall state that there is a dead, diseased, or infected
tree or brush pile on the premises, shall describe the premises by legal
description or by street address, and shall state that unless the dead,
diseased, or infected tree or brush pile is professionally treated or removed
on or before the date stated in the notice, the dead, diseased, or infected
tree or brush pile shall be removed at the property owner's expense. The date
stated in the notice shall be not less than ten (10) days after the date of the
delivery or mailing of the notice; and
      3.   The notice shall contain a reference to the ordinance codified
herein.
   F.   Failure To Remove Or Treat Dead, Diseased, Or Infected Trees Or Brush
Piles Prohibited: It is unlawful for the owner, occupant or agent to permit any
dead, diseased, or infected trees not being treated, or portions thereof, or
piles of brush which have been declared to be a hazard or nuisance by the
building officer to remain on such premises or to fail to remove same from such
premises.
   G.   Abatement By Village; Lien For Removal Costs: In cases where the owner,
occupant, or agent of the parcel of land on which a dead, diseased, or infected
tree or brush pile is located cannot be found, or if the owner, occupant, or
agent is found and notified in accordance with procedures above and fails to
abate such nuisance, the village may abate the same by removing and destroying
said dead, diseased, or infected trees or brush pile. In such cases, the owner,
occupant, or agent shall be billed for any expenses which may be incurred by
the village in the removal or abatement of the dead, diseased, or infected tree
or piles of brush. If not paid, the expenses may be collected via legal action
along with the fines and penalties provided for below. Such expenses may also
constitute a lien upon the real estate affected in accordance with 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-12 and 5/11-20-15. Such a lien shall not be imposed
unless notice is personally served upon, or sent by certified mail to, the
person to whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes on the property for
the taxable year immediately preceding the removal activities. The notice must
be delivered or sent after the removal activities have been performed, and
must: 1) state the substance of the statutory language permitting the lien and
the substance of this section; 2) identify the underlying parcel, by common
description; and 3) describe the removal activity.
   H.   Permit Required: No person or entity shall treat or remove any infected
tree located on village property without first obtaining a permit from the
village.
   I.   Penalties: Any person or entity violating any provision of this chapter
shall be fined no more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day on which the
violation occurs or continues.
   J.   Severability: If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or
portion of this chapter is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by
any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate,
distinct, and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the
validity of the remaining portions hereof. (Ord. 2016-1122, 6-9-2016)
4-6-8: COMMERCIAL LAWN MAINTENANCE ACTIVITY TIME AND PLACE LIMITATIONS:
Noise emanating from lawn maintenance activities shall be limited in time and
location as hereafter provided.
   A.   Definition: For the purposes of this section, "commercial lawn
maintenance activity" shall mean any work upon any land or appurtenance
thereto, by a commercial contractor, which shall be undertaken with or without
the assistance of machinery or equipment, including, but not limited to, lawn
mowing, lawn trimming, bush and tree trimming, and underground infrastructure
installation and maintenance. Nothing in this section is intended to restrict a
village resident from performing normal lawn, tree, or bush maintenance
activities on their own residential lot.
   B.   Time: No commercial or noncommercial lawn maintenance activities shall
be permitted except:
      1.   Monday through Friday from seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to seven
o'clock (7:00) P.M.
      2.   Saturday from eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to seven o'clock (7:00) P.M.
      3.   Sunday, homeowner performed maintenance only, from ten o'clock (10:
00) A.M. to seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. Commercial activity prohibited on
Sundays.
      4.   Commercial activity prohibited on the following legal holidays:
Memorial Day, July 4, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, and New
Year's Day.
      5.   Exceptions: Bona fide emergency maintenance and repairs.
   C.   Place: The restrictions in subsections A and B of this section shall
apply only to residential zones and those properties located within one
thousand feet (1,000') of any residential unit.
   D.   Penalties: Any property owner, lessee, or any occupant of any property
in the village of South Barrington who allows such noise emanating from lawn
maintenance activities on the property owned or occupied by him or her in
violation of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or
upon which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 2016-1122, 6-9-2016)
4-6-9: TREE PRESERVATION:
4-6-9-1: STATEMENT OF PURPOSE:
This Section of the Code is structured to preserve, protect and enhance
critical infrastructure - the urban forest that is located on public land. The
complete urban forest is comprised of trees across all land uses and ownership.
This Section will regulate public property trees but recognizes that trees on
private property are part of the collective community resource.
The purpose of this Section is to recognize the services and function that
trees provide as a collective asset to the entire community and to state the
goals of the Village with respect to the protection, preservation, care and
planting of trees on public lands.
Specific goals of this section are to:
   A.   Protect, preserve and enhance the quality of life and general welfare
of the Village, its residents, and property owners; and conserve and enhance
the Village’s natural, physical and aesthetic environment.
   B.   Preserve, protect and enhance the urban forest to ensure that trees are
properly planted and maintained within the Village so that trees can protect,
enhance and preserve the quality of life for people within the Village.
   C.   Recognize that trees are an integral part of the infrastructure of the
Village and as such should be preserved, protected and cared for as other
critical Village infrastructure.
      1.   Trees absorb pollution from the air;
      2.   Trees absorb and sequester carbon dioxide;
      3.   Trees absorb and filter pollution from stormwater run-off;
      4.   Trees produce oxygen;
      5.   Trees reduce flooding;
      6.   Trees stabilize soils and reduce erosion;
      7.   Trees cool the surrounding area helping to reduce impacts due to
heat islands;
      8.   Trees reduce energy consumption by shielding structures from harsh
winds and sun;
      9.   Trees provide a buffer and screen against noise, light and
pollution;
      10.   Trees improve property values;
      11.   Trees improve commercial district buyer traffic;
      12.   Areas with trees have lower crime rates;
      13.   Areas with trees have higher levels of community interaction;
      14.   Trees provide important habitat for birds and other wildlife; and
      15.   Trees protect and enhance our quality of life.
   D.   Trees provide the Village collective benefits that extend beyond
property boundaries throughout the entire Village.
   E.   Recognize that larger trees provide larger benefits. When a large tree
is removed and replaced with a smaller tree the benefits and services are
reduced.
   F.   Recognize that some trees may have a condition that constitutes a
threat, danger or nuisance to the public or property within the Village or may
be dangerous to the health of other trees and vegetation in the Village. (Ord.
2023-1365, 5-10-2023)
