4-7-3: MINIMUM PERFORMANCE STANDARDS FOR PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL CONTRACTORS:
   A.   General: All private sewage disposal contractors working in the village
shall be licensed by the Illinois department of public health.
   B.   Installers Of Private Sewage Disposal Systems: Contractors who install
or repair private sewage disposal systems within the village shall:
      1.   Install the system according to the village approved septic design
drawing and in accordance with the rules and practices of the village. Any
deviations from the approved drawing must be approved by the enforcement
officer.
      2.   Notify the village building department at least twenty four (24)
hours before start of construction in order that they may inspect the system
before any portion of the system has been backfilled.
      3.   Not begin installation when the soil is wet or frozen.
      4.   Notify the village enforcement officer if septic area has been
filled and not indicated as such on the approved septic design drawing.
      5.   Minimize the compaction of the soil during installation. Gravel
truck traffic shall not cross the septic area. All equipment (backhoes, front
end loaders, etc.) shall be of low pressure design and shall minimize the
amount of travel on the septic area.
      6.   Upon completion of the installation a sign shall be placed near the
driveway indicating that the system has been installed and that no traffic is
allowed in the septic area.
      7.   Upon completion of the septic field installation, the septic
installer must furnish to the village a detailed as built drawing which shall
contain the following information:
         a.   Installing contractor's name, address, phone number;
         b.   State of Illinois license number;
         c.   Date of installation;
         d.   Location (lot number, subdivision, street number, permit number);
         e.   Weather conditions at time of installation;
         f.   Name of enforcement officer making inspection;
         g.   A general description of the field area (i.e., wet or dry,
excessive traffic and compaction, filled or virgin soil, etc.);
         h.   The as built drawing shall be to scale;
         i.   The location of all components of the system shall be shown in
such a way as to make locating easy and positive at a later date. Dimensions
shown must be referenced from fixed items such as building walls and property
corner stakes. Two (2) dimensions are to be used for each key item;
         j.   Length of each seepage trench line;
         k.   Typical seepage trench detail;
         l.   Location, size and length of curtain drains, downspout drains,
etc.;
         m.   Total linear footage of seepage trench or square footage of
treatment area installed;
         n.   Indicate any deviations that were made from the approved septic
design drawing and reasons for such deviations;
         o.   Description and limits of fill which was placed on the septic
area. (Ord. 0-2015-1044, 2-12-2015)
4-7-4: SEPTIC FIELD FILLING PROCEDURES:
Whenever tests, high ground water, or other site conditions indicate that the
importation of fill will be required, see state code section 905.60 for sizing
criteria, soil criteria, and site preparation. Village requirements are as
follows:
   A.   In any situation where there are failing test results and a septic
design drawing indicating that fill is required on any portion of the septic
area, no building permit will be issued until the fill has been placed and a
new set of tests are performed at the required trench depth.
   B.   If fill is discovered to have been placed without the benefit of a site
development permit and/or proper approval procedures, the following
requirements shall apply before a new set of percolation tests may be performed
and approved by the village:
      1.   If little to no natural vegetation is present in the filled area
then the fill shall consolidate for the full twelve (12) month time period
beginning on the date of discovery by the village.
      2.   If substantial vegetation is present in the filled area then the
fill shall consolidate for a nine (9) month time period beginning on the date
of discovery by the village.
      3.   The village enforcement officer shall determine the status of
vegetation growth for the determination of the required waiting period.
      4.   The property owner may submit other evidence to the enforcement
officer that indicates when the filling work was actually performed. The
enforcement officer may use this information to determine the required waiting
period.
      5.   The property owner shall be responsible to apply for and receive all
proper permits, pay all required fees and penalties and receive all proper
approvals from the design engineer for the work that has been completed.
      6.   In any unique situation that does not fall into one of the above
categories, the enforcement officer shall determine what procedures must be
followed.
   C.   The design engineer shall be responsible to approve the fill material,
set grade stakes prior to initiating the fill operation and approve all finish
grades for compliance with the design drawing after the fill is in place.
Letters of approval shall be submitted to the village enforcement officer.
   D.   The septic field filling procedures are as follows:
      1.   Complete the septic system design or filling drawing.
      2.   Apply for and receive a site development permit.
      3.   Engineer shall stake the fill boundaries for the field.
      4.   Install culvert pipe and driveway across swale (if any).
      5.   Submit sample of fill material to engineer for analysis and
approval.
      6.   Engineer shall submit letter to village stating whether the fill
material is satisfactory for septic purposes.
      7.   Provide twenty four (24) hours' notice to the village prior to start
of importing fill.
      8.   Place fill material at edge of septic area and spread onto the area
with a low pressure machine to the depth specified on the engineer's plan and
as staked by the design engineer. Absolutely no traffic from dump trucks is
allowed on any portion of the septic area.
      9.   Engineer shall submit letter to village stating that the site was
properly prepared prior to fill placement and whether the final grading of the
fill is consistent with the plan and grade stakes.
      10.   If a new set of percolation tests is required due to the
importation of fill, the fill material must be allowed to consolidate as
indicated in the state code.
      11.   A building permit can be issued only when the above listed
procedures and percolation test (if required) have been complete and approved
by the village.
   E.   Removal of existing soil structure in the proposed seepage field area
and its replacement with fill shall not be permitted. (Ord. 0-2015-1044, 2-12-
2015)
4-7-5: PROTECTION OF SEPTIC FIELD AREAS DURING THE COURSE OF BUILDING
CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to construct any building within
the village without first having installed a protective barrier around all
sides of the proposed septic field area which is to be a minimum of ten (10')
feet from the septic field prior to the start of excavation operations.
   B.   Such protective barrier shall consist of a brightly colored rope,
supported by metal fence posts driven into the ground at intervals not to
exceed fifty feet (50'). The use of wooden snow fencing, supported by metal
fence posts at a similar spacing shall also be permitted. The village
enforcement officer may require the installation of wooden snow fencing,
chainlink fencing or other more substantial protective barriers when site
conditions indicate that the likelihood of disturbance to the septic area is
evident.
   C.   Materials expressly not allowed for use are:
         Posts fashioned from construction lumber
         Posts fashioned from electrical conduit
         Plastic tape (whether fluorescent colored or not)
         String
   D.   The protection around the septic field area must remain in place, in a
complete and effective manner, for the duration of the construction process, up
to and including the date of the final occupancy inspection.
   E.   Should traffic or disturbance of the septic field area, whether when
protected or unprotected, be in evidence to the building department, the job
shall be stopped and a new set of soil tests shall be made which shall be used
in lieu of any previous tests. Based on the results of the new soil tests and
site observation, the village enforcement officer will make an assessment of
the entire situation and determine what remedial actions shall be taken.
   F.   Should the proposed septic area, in its natural state of existence, be
of a wooded nature, all clearing operations shall be done by hand, with
absolutely no vehicular traffic being allowed over the field. Immediately after
the clearing operations are completed, the protection required by this chapter
shall be installed.
   G.   If any person fails to install and/or maintain said protection around
the septic field area as provided in subsections A through F of this section, a
stop work order may be issued by the building department and/or the police
department until such time as the necessary protection has been installed in
accordance with this chapter. Violators shall also be subject to a fine of not
less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00)
for each offense; and a separate offense be deemed committed on each day during
which a violation occurs or continues to exist. (Ord. 0-2015-1044, 2-12-2015)
4-7-6: PERMITS REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, fill or make any alterations
or repairs to private sewage disposal systems within the village unless he
holds a valid permit issued by the enforcement officer as indicated below:
   A.   New Construction: The permit is issued as part of the building permit
for the building construction. A separate septic permit is not required.
   B.   Additions/Remodeling: The septic permit issued is in addition to the
required building permit. The septic permit work must be completed before the
permit for the building construction will be issued.
   C.   Septic Repairs: The permit is issued for the septic repairs only.
   D.   Septic Field Filling: A site development permit is required prior to
the importation of any fill in excess of fifty (50) cubic yards.
For repair or modification of individual private sewage disposal systems,
complete application form for permit as provided by the village. (Ord. 0-2015-
1044, 2-12-2015)
4-7-7: DEVIATIONS FROM SEPTIC DESIGN DRAWING:
   A.   Any deviations from the design conditions such as, but not limited to:
      1.   Changing the number of bedrooms,
      2.   Reducing the percolation capacity of the soil due to traffic or
stockpiling building materials or excavated soil on the seepage field area,
      3.   Reducing the effective seepage field area by changing house
location, adding pavement, pools, tennis courts, etc.,
      4.   Diverting groundwater into or over the seepage field,
      5.   Failure to install system as per the design drawing will void all
previously approved design drawings.
   B.   The enforcement officer shall determine what corrective measures shall
be taken such as, but not limited to:
      1.   Requiring a new soil test if the field has been disturbed,
      2.   Requiring the design engineer to field locate all deviations and/or
disturbed areas,
      3.   Requiring that revisions be made to the design drawing to indicate
all changes necessary because of deviations or a disturbed field,
      4.   Issue a stop work order. (Ord. 0-2015-1044, 2-12-2015)
4-7-8: MAINTENANCE OF PRIVATE SYSTEMS:
   A.   Acknowledgment To Village: Immediately prior to the issuance of any
building permit for construction of any principal residence, business or
industrial building which is not an accessory building, and immediately prior
to the issuance of any occupancy permit for any such building, the owner or
contract purchaser, if any, shall acknowledge to the village its obligation to
maintain and keep in proper operating condition any private sewage system
serving the premises which include said building and shall agree to the same.
   B.   Landscaping Requirements:
      1.   Extreme care shall be observed during the final grading and
landscaping to prevent compaction and disturbance to the drop box and
distribution system.
      2.   The seepage area shall be graded to ensure that surface water runs
off as quickly as possible without ponding. Provisions shall be made to
eliminate erosion during and after completion. The methods used shall be
approved by the village engineer.
      3.   Landscaping shall be installed when the ground is dry. Only
lightweight landscaping tractors are allowed on the septic field. Landscaping
over tanks, drop boxes and header lines is to be completed by hand.
      4.   Grades shall be established over the seepage field area prior to the
issuance of an occupancy permit by the village enforcement officer.
      5.   Trees or shrubs shall not be installed in the seepage field area.
      6.   Automatic sprinkling systems shall not be installed over any portion
of the seepage field area or within the village right of way. (Ord. 0-2015-
1044, 2-12-2015)
4-7-9: REPAIRS AND ALTERATIONS TO EXISTING SEPTIC FIELDS:
   A.   Repairs: When conditions exist that the subsurface seepage field is
failing, the property owner shall take immediate steps to repair the system.
      1.   Evaluation By Professional Engineer: Property owner shall contract
with a professional engineer to evaluate the situation and make recommendations
as to a solution to repair the failing condition.
      2.   Pumping Of Septic Tanks: Upon discovery of a failing condition, the
village enforcement officer may require that the property owner secure a
contract with a licensed septic pumping contractor to pump the septic tanks as
required until the corrective measures have been taken so as to prevent further
effluent from reaching the surface. A copy of said contract shall be filed with
the village.
      3.   Septic System Repair Permit Required: A septic system repair permit
shall be obtained prior to the repair of any portion of the septic system.
      4.   Soil Tests Required: A new soil test will be required if the repair
procedures include the addition to, or replacement of the subsurface seepage
field to another area on the property which falls outside of the original
approved septic area.
      5.   Engineered Design Drawing Required: A septic design drawing must be
prepared for village approval.
   B.   Alterations: Whenever a subsurface seepage system must be altered or
extended in any way due to the construction of a building addition, swimming
pool, tennis court, etc., or due to a change in the bedroom count, the
following shall apply:
      1.   Evaluation By Professional Engineer: Property owner shall contract
with a professional engineer to evaluate the existing conditions.
      2.   Septic System Alteration Permit Required: A septic system alteration
permit shall be obtained prior to the alteration of any portion of the septic
system.
      3.   Soil Tests Required: A new soil test will be required if the
alteration procedures include the addition to, or replacement of the subsurface
seepage field to another area on the property which falls outside of the
original approved septic area.
      4.   Engineered Design Drawing Required: A septic design drawing must be
prepared for village approval.
      5.   Relocation: If the alteration procedures include the relocation of
the septic tank(s) or building sewer, the contractor shall review and
coordinate the procedure with the village enforcement officer to ensure that
the building is not without a proper operating septic system for an extended
period of time.
      6.   Alteration Work: All septic alteration work must be completed before
a building permit will be issued for the construction which necessitated the
alteration to the septic system. (Ord. 0-2015-1044, 2-12-2015)
4-7-10: ENFORCEMENT:
The enforcement officer shall be that person designated by the village
president to enforce this chapter and to that end said enforcement officer
shall make such orders, requirements, decisions and determinations as are
necessary with respect to the enforcement hereof.
   A.   Changes To Private Sewage Disposal System: When any private sewage
disposal system constructed prior to the effective date of this chapter is
reconstructed, altered, extended or subject to any change in any condition
affecting its operation or functioning, it shall be made to comply with this
chapter.
   B.   Inspection: Any individual sewage disposal system shall not be covered
or placed into operation until the said installation shall have been inspected
and approval of the said system have been issued by the enforcement officer.
   C.   Soil Quality: If, in the opinion of the enforcement officer, soils
encountered during the installation of the seepage system are of questionable
quality, he may require the contractor to choose one of the following courses
of action:
      1.   Install additional linear feet of seepage trenches or square footage
of the treatment area in an amount determined by the enforcement officer; or
      2.   Have the design engineer make a site visit to review the soils
encountered and make a professional opinion concerning the adequacy of the soil
for the proposed seepage system and recommend solutions if the soils are found
to be not adequate.
   D.   Notice: Whenever the enforcement officer determines that a violation of
any provision of this chapter has occurred, he shall give notice to the person
or persons responsible for such violation. The notice shall:
      1.   Be in writing.
      2.   Include a statement of the reasons for the notice.
      3.   Allow reasonable time as determined by the enforcement officer for
performance of any act it required.
      4.   Be served upon the person responsible for the violation(s); provided
that such notice shall have been properly served upon the person responsible
for the violations either by mail or in person.
      5.   Contain a brief outline of remedial action which is required to
effect compliance with this chapter.
   E.   Legal Action And Fines: The enforcement officer may institute any legal
action in the circuit court or administrative adjudications to enforce any
provision or condition under this chapter; including, but not limited to, fines
not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed for
each and every day during which a violation continues or exists. (Ord. 0-2015-
1044, 2-12-2015)
CHAPTER 8
SANITARY SEWER AND WASTEWATER LAND TREATMENT SYSTEMS
SECTION:
4-8-1: Purpose And Intent
4-8-2: Definitions
4-8-2a: Applicability And Prohibitions
4-8-2b: Installation And Maintenance Requirements
4-8-3: Grease Interceptors
4-8-4: Prohibited Discharges
4-8-5: Approval Discharges
4-8-6: Aquifer Protection
4-8-7: Variances
4-8-8: Conflict With Village Ordinances
4-8-9: Operations
4-8-10: Permit Required
4-8-11: Penalty
4-8-1: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
The purpose of this chapter is to establish the limitations and requirements
concerning the quality of sewage or wastewater discharged to the sanitary sewer
system and the quality of treated effluent discharged to the ground surface for
recycling of any subdivision or commercial development in the village served by
a wastewater land treatment system. These limitations and requirements are
needed for the protection of the sanitary sewer systems, the wastewater land
treatment systems and the water bearing aquifer in order to ensure the
satisfactory performance of the sanitary sewer system, the wastewater land
treatment system and the water quality of private wells serving the residents
of the village. (Ord. 0-88-312, 10-13-1988)
4-8-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter the following words and phrases will have the following
meanings unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
ACT: Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as
amended, 33 U.S.C. 1251, et. seq.
BOD: The value of the five (5)-day test for Biochemical Oxygen Demand, as
described in the latest edition of “Standard Methods for the Examination of
Water and Wastewater.”
COD: The value of the test for Chemical Oxygen Demand, as described in the
latest edition of “Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and
Wastewater.”
DOMESTIC SEWAGE: Water and water carried wastes normally discharged into the
sanitary sewers or septic systems from residential housing. For the purpose of
this chapter, used water generated from commercial office usage, commercial
food processing and commercial restaurant operations shall be classified as
domestic sewage.
EPA: The United States Environmental Protection Agency.
FATS, OILS, AND GREASES (FOG): Organic polar compounds derived from animal and/
or plant sources that contain multiple carbon chain triglyceride molecules.
These substances are detectable and measurable using analytical test procedures
established in 40 CFR 136, as may be amended from time to time. All are
sometimes referred to herein as “grease” or “greases.”
FOG DISPOSAL SYSTEM: A grease interceptor that reduces nonpetroleum fats, oils,
and grease (FOG) in effluent by separation, and mass and volume reduction.
GARBAGE: Solid wastes and residue from preparation, cooking and dispensing of
food and from the handling, storage, processing and sale of food products and
produce.
GENERATOR: Any person who owns or operates a grease trap/grease interceptor, or
whose act or process produces a grease trap waste.
GREASE: Fats, waxes, free fatty acids, calcium, and magnesium soaps, mineral
oils and certain nonfatty material from animal or vegetative sources or from
hydrocarbons of petroleum origins whether liquid or solid; used interchangeable
with the term "FOG" (fats, oils and greases).
GREASE INTERCEPTOR OR GREASE TRAP: An appurtenance or appliance that is
installed in a sanitary drainage system to intercept non- petroleum fats, oils
and grease (FOG) from wastewater. The device is identified by volume, retention
time, and baffle(s). For purposes of this ordinance, the terms “grease
interceptor” and “grease trap” may be used interchangeably.
GREASE WASTE: Material collected in and from a grease interceptor in the
sanitary sewer service line of a commercial, institutional, or industrial food
service or processing establishment, including the solids resulting from de-
watering processes.
INDIRECT DISCHARGE OR DISCHARGE: The introduction of pollutants into a VSS from
any non-domestic source.
INTERFERENCE: A discharge which alone or in conjunction with a discharge or
discharges from other sources inhibits or disrupts the VSS, its treatment
processes or operations or its sludge processes, use or disposal, or is a cause
of a violation of Village, State of Illinois or Metropolitan Water Reclamation
District of Greater Chicago (MWRD) regulations.
MILLIGRAMS PER LITER: This term shall be abbreviated "mg/l", and shall mean a
weight to volume ratio. The figure appearing before the symbol "mg/l" shall be
the number of milligrams to be found in one liter of the substance being
tested. This figure can be transposed to pounds per million (1,000,000) gallons
of water by multiplying the figure appearing before the symbol "mg/l" by 8.34.
pH: The logarithm (base-10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration
expressed in moles per liter. pH shall be determined by "standard methods" as
defined in this section.
PROPERLY SHREDDED GARBAGE: Wastes from preparation and cooking and disposing of
food, exclusive of eggshells and bones, which waste has been shredded so that
the particles are no greater than one-half inch (1/2") in any dimension, and
the particles can be carried freely through the normal conditions in sanitary
sewers.
RECLAIMED WATER: Wastewater which has been treated in aerated lagoons followed
by filtration and disinfection and is judged to be suitable for recycling.
RECYCLING: Slow rate irrigation of reclaimed water on golf courses,
landscaping, agricultural areas, and other appropriate land uses.
SANITARY SEWER: A sewer that conveys sewage or wastewater.
SEWER SYSTEM: All of the sewers and pumping facilities that convey sewage to
the wastewater land treatment facilities.
STANDARD METHODS: Methods approved by the engineering profession of examination
of waste and wastewater. Evidence of standard methods may be submitted by
showing standard methods approved by the American Water Works Association, the
American Public Health Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation.
SUSPENDED SOLIDS: Solids that either float in sewage or are in suspension in
sewage, which are removable by a laboratory filtration device.
TRANSPORTER: A person who is registered with and authorized by the State of
Illinois to transport sewage sludge, water treatment sludge, domestic sewage,
chemical toilet waste, grit trap waste, or grease trap waste in accordance with
current regulations.
TSS: The value of the test for Total Suspended Solids, as described in the
latest edition of “Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and
Wastewater.”
USER: Any person or business, including those located outside the
jurisdictional limits of the Village, who contributes, causes or permits the
contribution or discharge of wastewater into the VSS, including persons who
contribute such wastewater from mobile sources.
VSS OR VILLAGE SEWER SYSTEM: The Village owned municipality as defined by
section 502(4) of the Clean Water Act. This definition includes any devices and
systems used in the storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of municipal
sewage or industrial wastes of a liquid nature. It also includes all sewers,
pipes and other conveyances that convey wastewater to a VSS Treatment Plant.
The term also means the municipality as defined in section 502(4) of the Act,
which has jurisdiction over the indirect discharges to and the discharges from
such a treatment works. For purposes of this ordinance, the terms “sanitary
sewer system” and “VSS” may be used interchangeably.
WASTEWATER: Sewage.
WASTEWATER LAND TREATMENT SYSTEM: The aerated lagoon, storage lagoon,
intermittent sand filters, chlorination facilities, and landscape irrigation
system. (Ord. 0-88-312, 10-13-1988; amd. Ord. 2016-1119, 5-12-2016; Ord. 2020-
1245, 8-13-2020)
4-8-2a: APPLICABILITY AND PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   This chapter shall apply to all users of the Village Sewer System
(VSS), as defined in 4-8-2a of this chapter.
   B.   Grease traps/interceptors shall not be required for residential users.
   C.   The chapter shall apply to both new existing facilities generating
fats, oils, or greases (FOG) as a result of food manufacturing, processing,
preparation, or food service shall install, use, and maintain appropriate
grease interceptors as required in 4-8-2b of this chapter. These facilities
include but are not limited to restaurants, food manufacturers, food
processors, hospitals, hotels, nursing homes, and any other facility preparing,
serving, or otherwise making any food available for consumption.
   D.   No user may intentionally or unintentionally allow the direct or
indirect discharge of any fats, oils, or greases (FOG) of animal or vegetable
origin into the VSS system in such amounts as to cause interference with the
collection and treatment system, or as to cause pollutants to pass through the
treatment works into the environment. (Ord. 2020-1245, 8-13-2020)
4-8-2b: INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Installations:
      1.   New Facilities. Food processing or food service facilities which are
newly proposed or constructed, or existing facilities which will be expanded or
renovated to include a food service facility, where such facility did not
previously exist, shall be required to design, install, operate and maintain a
grease interceptor in accordance with locally adopted plumbing codes or other
applicable ordinances. Grease interceptors shall be installed and inspected
prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy.
      2.   Existing Facilities. Existing grease interceptors must be operated
and maintained in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations and in
accordance with this chapter, unless specified in writing and approved by the
VSS. Existing facilities that are not in compliance with the terms of this
chapter will have one hundred and twenty (120) days from the date of ordinance
adoption to comply.
      3.   All grease interceptor waste shall be properly disposed of at a
facility in accordance with federal, state, or local regulation.
   B.   Cleaning and Maintenance:
      1.   Grease interceptors shall be maintained in an efficient operating
condition at all times.
      2.   Each grease interceptor when cleaned shall be fully evacuated.
   C.   Cleaning Schedules:
      1.   Grease interceptors shall be cleaned as often as necessary to ensure
that sediment and floating materials do not accumulate to impair the efficiency
of the grease interceptor; to ensure the discharge is in compliance with local
discharge limits; and to ensure no visible grease is observed in discharge.
      2.   Grease interceptors shall be completely evacuated a minimum of every
thirty (30) days, or more frequently when:
         a.   Twenty-five (25) percent or more of the wetted height of the
grease trap or grease interceptor, as measured from the bottom of the device to
the invert of the outlet pipe, contains floating materials, sediment, oils or
greases;
         b.   The discharge exceeds BOD, COD, TSS, FOG, pH, or other pollutant
levels established by the VSS; or
         c.   If there is a history of non-compliance.
      3.   Any person who owns or operates a grease interceptor may submit to
the VSS a request in writing for an exception to the thirty (30) day cleaning
frequency of their grease interceptor. The VSS may grant an extension for
required cleaning frequency on a case-by-case basis when:
         a.   The grease interceptor owner/operator has demonstrated the
specific interceptor will produce an effluent, based on defensible analytical
results, in consistent compliance with established local discharge limits such
as BOD, TSS, FOG, or other parameters as determined by the VSS; or
         b.   Less than twenty-five percent (25%) of the wetted height of the
grease interceptor, as measured from the bottom of the device to the invert of
the outlet pipe, contains floating materials, sediment, oils or greases.
      4.   In any event, a grease interceptor shall be fully evacuated,
cleaned, and inspected at least once every ninety (90) days
   D.   Manifest Requirements:
      1.   Each pump-out of a grease interceptor must be accompanied by a
manifest to be used for record keeping purposes.
      2.   Persons who generate, collect and transport grease waste shall
maintain a record of each individual collection and deposit. Such records shall
be in the form of a manifest. The manifest shall include:
         a.   Name, address, telephone, and commission registration number of
transporter;
         b.   Name, signature, address, and phone number of the person who
generated the waste and the date collected;
         c.   Type and amount(s) of waste collected or transported;
         d.   Name and signature(s) of responsible person(s) collecting,
transporting, and depositing the waste;
         e.   Date and place where the waste was deposited;
         f.   Identification (permit or site registration number, location, and
operator) of the facility where the waste was deposited;
         g.   Name and signature of facility on-site representative
acknowledging receipt of the waste and the amount of waste received;
         h.   The volume of the grease waste received; and
         i.   A consecutive numerical tracking number to assist transporters,
waste generators, and regulating authorities in tracking the volume of grease
transported.
      3.   Manifests shall be divided into five parts and records shall be
maintained as follows:
         a.   One part of the manifest shall have the generator and transporter
information completed and be given to the generator at the time of waste
pickup.
         b.   The remaining four parts of the manifest shall have all required
information completely filled out and signed by the appropriate party before
distribution of the manifest.
         c.   One part of the manifest shall go to the receiving facility.
         d.   One part shall go to the transporter, who shall retain a copy of
all manifests showing the collection and disposition of waste.
         e.   One copy of the manifest shall be returned by the transporter to
the person who generated the wastes within 15 days after the waste is received
at the disposal or processing facility.
         f.   One part of the manifest shall go to the local authority.
         g.   Copies of manifests returned to the waste generator shall be
retained for five (5) years and be readily available for review by the VSS.
         h.   Alternative treatment.
   E.   Compliance and Penalties: All testing designed to satisfy the criteria
set forth in 4-8-2b shall be scientifically sound and statistically valid. All
tests to determine oil and grease, TSS, BOD, COD, pH, and other pollutant
levels shall use appropriate tests which have been approved by the
Environmental Protection Agency which are defined in Title 40, Code of Federal
Regulations, Part 136. Testing shall be open to inspection by the VSS, and
shall meet the VSS’s approval.
   F.   Prohibited Practices: No person shall introduce, or cause, permit, or
suffer the introduction of any surfactant, solvent or emulsifier into a grease
interceptor. Surfactants, solvents, and emulsifiers are materials which allow
the grease to pass from the grease interceptor into the collection system, and
include but are not limited to enzymes, soap, diesel, kerosene, terpene, and
other solvents.
   G.   Compliance Monitoring:
      1.   Right of Entry. The VSS shall have the right to enter the premises
of any user or potential user to determine whether the user is complying with
all requirements of this chapter and any wastewater discharge permit or order
issued hereunder. Users shall allow the VSS ready access to all parts of the
premises for the purposes of inspection, sampling, records examination and
copying, and the performance of any additional duties.
         a.   The VSS shall have the right to set up on the user's property, or
require installation of, such devices as are necessary to conduct sampling and/
or metering of the user's operations.
         b.   The VSS may require the user to install monitoring equipment as
necessary such as FOG sensing and alarm devices complying with Plumbing and
Draining Institute Standard (PDI) G-102. The facility's monitoring equipment
shall be maintained at all times in a safe and proper operating condition by
the user at its own expense.
         c.   Any temporary or permanent obstruction to safe and easy access to
the facility to be inspected and/or sampled shall be promptly removed by the
user at the written or verbal request of the VSS and shall not be replaced. The
costs of clearing such access shall be borne by the user.
         d.   Unreasonable delays in allowing the VSS access to the user's
premises shall be a violation of this chapter. (Ord. 2020-1245, 8-13-2020)
4-8-3: GREASE INTERCEPTORS:
   A.   Sizing And Installation Requirements: All grease interceptors shall be
designed and installed in accordance with section 890.510, 520 and 530 of the
Illinois plumbing code, latest edition.
   B.   Location: All grease interceptors must be located in a manner that
provides ready and easy access for cleaning and inspection.
   C.   Maintenance Requirements:
      1.   All interceptors shall be serviced at intervals determined by use
but at a minimum of every three (3) months unless manifest records indicate
intervals more appropriate for the use. All generators with an underground
interceptor must have a maintenance service contract with an authorized hauler.
      2.   Any waste removed from the interceptor shall not be emptied into any
drain, sewer or body of water.
      3.   Maintenance reports and logs must be kept on site for at least a
time period of three (3) years.
      4.   Copies of the manifests to be submitted to the village each time
they are generated.
   D.   Disposal Requirements:
      1.   Disposal and transportation of grease waste must be in accordance
with section 22.30 of the Illinois environmental protection act.
      2.   Grease waste for the smaller, under the sink units, can be disposed
of in the on site dumpster if it is in a solid form, in a sealed container and
does not exceed five (5) pounds in weight. The chain of custody stated in
section 22.30 of the Illinois environmental protection act would still apply in
this case.
   E.   Inspections: The village shall have the right to enter the premises to
inspect the grease interceptors and the manifest reports to determine
compliance with state and village regulations. The inspector shall be given
full access to the facilities and be allowed to review any monitoring, disposal
manifests and transportation records.
   F.   Fees:
      1.   A yearly fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) will be assessed on
each generator.
      2.   Additional fees may be imposed if follow up inspections are needed
due to issues with the grease interceptors.
   G.   Enforcement And Violation Action:
      1.   If the inspector finds violations or if the manifests indicate
problems with the grease interceptors, the generator will be given a written
notice to eliminate the deficiency within ten (10) calendar days.
      2.   If the deficiency or violation is not corrected in that time period,
a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) shall be assessed for each time the
violation or deficiency continues to occur when inspected by the village
representative.
      3.   If after three (3) consecutive inspections the violations or
deficiencies are not corrected, the establishment of the generator will be shut
down until corrective action has taken place.
      4.   Fines may also be assessed to cover any costs associated with
cleaning the public sewer of grease buildup due to the generator not taking
corrective action. (Ord. 2016-1119, 5-12-2016)
4-8-4: PROHIBITED DISCHARGES:
The following substances shall not be discharged into the sanitary sewer
system:
   A.   Free or emulsified oil and grease exceeding an average of one hundred
milligrams per liter (100 mg/l).
   B.   Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty
degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) or sixty five degrees centigrade (65°C).
   C.   Any water or waste which contains wax, grease, oil, plastic or other
substances that will solidify or become discernibly viscous at temperatures
below thirty two degrees Fahrenheit (32°F) or zero degrees centigrade (0°C).
   D.   Liquids, solids, or gases which by reason of their nature or quantity
may cause fire or explosion; or be injurious in any other way to sewers,
treatment facilities structures or to the operation of the treatment
facilities; cause a safety hazard to the personnel operating the treatment
facilities.
   E.   Solid or viscous substances in quantity capable of causing obstruction
to the flow of sanitary sewers or of interfering with the operation of the
wastewater treatment works.
   F.   Any garbage except properly shredded garbage.
   G.   Any noxious or malodorous substance which can form a gas, which, singly
or by interaction with other wastes in the sewage system, is capable of causing
objectionable odors or hazards to health, life or property or which can be
itself or in combination with other substances in the sewage system form solids
and concentrations exceeding the limits established in this chapter or any
substance which creates any other condition harmful to the structure or
treatment processes of the wastewater treatment system.
   H.   Acids or alkalis having a pH value lower than 6.0 or higher than 9.0.
   I.   Any substance or element which will damage the sewer system or
wastewater treatment facilities, is toxic to biological treatment processes, or
is detrimental to the recycling of the reclaimed water.
   J.   All water carried industrial wastes.
   K.   All water carried chemical, either organic or inorganic, wastes. (Ord.
0-88-312, 10-13-1988)
4-8-5: APPROVAL DISCHARGES:
Only domestic type sewage can be discharged into the sanitary sewer system.
Written approval from the village must be obtained before wastewater used in
laboratory operations can be discharged into the sanitary sewer system. (Ord.
0-88-312, 10-13-1988)
4-8-6: AQUIFER PROTECTION:
   A.   A minimum of four (4) test wells located on the perimeter of the
wastewater land treatment system shall be drilled by the owner into the aquifer
commonly used by the residents of the village for their water wells. Water
obtained from these wells should receive comprehensive chemical, mineral and
bacteriological analyses and these analyses should be used as a baseline guide.
Water from these test wells should be subjected to the same type of analyses on
a yearly basis so that it can be determined if any degradation to the aquifer
is occurring.
   B.   The recycled water entering the aquifer should be in conformance with
the United States environmental protection agency quality standards for
drinking water. (Ord. 0-88-312, 10-13-1988)
4-8-7: VARIANCES:
If discharges into the sanitary sewer system are proposed which are at variance
to the provisions of section
4-8-4 of this chapter, the engineer for the wastewater land treatment system
and the facilities operator shall review the proposed variance. The engineer
and operator after obtaining specific written approval from the village shall
have the authority to determine the acceptability of the proposed variances and
to determine the pretreatment requirements that may be necessary to meet the
provisions of section
4-8-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 0-88-312, 10-13-1988)
4-8-8: CONFLICT WITH VILLAGE ORDINANCES:
If the provisions of this chapter conflict with any of the building,
subdivision, zoning or other applicable village ordinances, the provisions of
those other ordinances shall control. (Ord. 0-88-312, 10-13-1988)
4-8-9: OPERATIONS:
The owners of the subdivision or commercial development, as the case may be,
will obtain all required permits and approvals before constructing and
operating the wastewater land treatment system and will cause the land
treatment system to be properly operated and maintained. If there is any
evidence of odors, or evidence of overspray or other collateral consequences
which indicate that corrective action is needed, that are brought to the
attention of the village, the village will notify such owners or their
designated representative of the problem and request correction within seven
(7) days. If the problem is not corrected, the village, through the exercise of
its police powers may move on to the site, cause the problem to be corrected
and assess such owners three hundred percent (300%) of the incurred costs.
Copies of all correspondence between the owners and operators of the wastewater
land treatment system and the Illinois environmental protection agency and all
other regulatory agencies must be sent to the village. (Ord. 0-88-312, 10-13-
1988)
4-8-10: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall install or replace a wastewater land treatment system or any
part thereof in the village without first having obtained a permit therefor
from the village and paid such fees for such permit as provided by the
ordinances and resolutions of the village applicable thereto. (Ord. 0-88-312,
10-13-1988)
4-8-11: PENALTY:
   A.   If the VSS determines that a user is responsible for a blockage of a
collection system line the user shall owe a civil penalty of five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for the first violation, one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for
a second violation, and one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for the
third violation within a two-year period. Continuous violations shall result in
an increase in penalty by five hundred dollars ($500.00) and may also result in
termination of services. Additionally, the user will be responsible to pay for
all repairs related to the blockage.
   B.   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be
subject to a written warning for the first violation, a five hundred dollars
($500.00) civil penalty for the second violation, a one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) civil penalty for the third violation, and a one thousand five
hundred dollars ($1,500.00) civil penalty for the fourth violation within a two
(2)-year period. Consistent violations will result in a five hundred dollars
($500.00) increase in civil penalty and may result in termination of service.
(Ord. 0-88-312, 10-13-1988; Ord. 2020-1245, 8-13-2020)

4-8A-1: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
4-8A-1-100: PURPOSE AND POLICY:
This chapter sets forth uniform requirements for users of the wastewater sewer
system for the purpose of enabling the village to comply with applicable state
and federal laws and regulations, including the clean water act (33 United
States Code section 1251 et seq.), the general pretreatment regulations (40
code of federal regulations part 403) and the rules, regulations and ordinances
of the metropolitan water reclamation district of greater Chicago. The
objectives of this chapter are to:
   A.   Prevent the introduction of pollutants into the wastewater sewer system
that will interfere with its operation;
   B.   Prevent the introduction of pollutants into the wastewater sewer system
that will pass through the wastewater sewer system, inadequately treated, into
a wastewater treatment facility or otherwise be incompatible with the
wastewater sewer system;
   C.   Protect both wastewater sewer system village personnel or agents who
may be affected by wastewater in the course of their employment and the general
public;
   D.   Provide for fees for the equitable distribution of the cost of
operation, maintenance, and improvement of the wastewater sewer system;
   E.   Enable the village to comply with metropolitan water reclamation
district of greater Chicago ordinances, rules and regulations, and any other
federal or state laws, rules and regulations to which the wastewater sewer
system is subject.
This chapter shall apply to all users of the wastewater sewer system. This
chapter authorizes the issuance of wastewater discharge permits; provides for
monitoring, compliance, and enforcement activities; establishes administrative
review procedures; requires user reporting; and provides for the setting of
fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the program
established herein. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
4-8A-1-110: ADMINISTRATION:
Except as otherwise provided herein, the board of trustees of the village shall
administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this chapter. Any powers
granted to or duties imposed upon the board of trustees may be delegated by the
board of trustees. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
4-8A-1-120: ABBREVIATIONS:
The following abbreviations, when used in this chapter, shall have the
designated meanings:
CFR   - Code of federal regulations
EPA   - U.S. environmental protection agency
FOG   - Fats, oil and grease
gpd   - Gallons per day
IEPA  - Illinois environmental protection agency
mg/l  - Milligrams per liter
MWRD  - Metropolitan water reclamation district of greater Chicago
NPDES - National pollutant discharge elimination system
RCRA  - Resource conservation and recovery act
SIC   - Standard industrial classification
TSS   - Total suspended solids
USC   - United States code
 
(Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
4-8A-1-130: DEFINITIONS:
Unless a provision explicitly states otherwise, the following terms and
phrases, as used in this Chapter, shall have the meanings hereinafter
designated:
ACCIDENTAL DISCHARGES: Unplanned release of substances either directly or
indirectly in such magnitude to cause substantial effects on receiving systems
and treatment processes. Release is the result of accident, act or nature of
operational malfunctions.
ACT OR THE ACT: The Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the
Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 USC section 1251 et seq.
ADMINISTRATOR: The Administrator of the EPA.
APPLICABLE PRETREATMENT STANDARDS: For any specified pollutant, the prohibitive
discharge standards, specific limitations on discharge, the State of Illinois
pretreatment standards or the National Categorical Pretreatment Standards (when
effective), whichever standard is most stringent.
APPLICANT: The party applying to the Village for a permit to connect to the
wastewater sewer system.
APPROVAL AUTHORITY: EPA.
APPROVED: An item or procedure which satisfies the conditions of and has been
accepted by the Village of South Barrington.
AUTHORIZED REPRESENTATIVE: A. If the user is a corporation: the president,
secretary, treasurer, or a vice president of the corporation in charge of a
principal business function, or any other person who performs similar policy or
decision- making functions for the corporation.
   B.   If the user is a partnership or sole proprietorship: a general partner
or proprietor, respectively.
   C.   If the user is a Federal, State or local government facility: a
director or highest official appointed or designated to oversee the operation
and performance of the activities of the government facility, or their
designee.
   D.   If the user is a limited liability partnership, limited liability
company, or any other entity not previously described: 1) a person in charge of
principal business functions or any other person who performs similar policy or
decision-making functions for the entity; or 2) any person having written
authorization satisfying the requirements of subsection E of this definition
from such entity.
   E.   The individuals described in subsections A through D of this definition
may designate another authorized representative if the authorization is in
writing, the authorization specifies the individual or position responsible for
the overall operation of the facility from which the discharge originates or
having overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company, and
the written authorization is submitted to the Village.
   F.   If an authorization under subsection E of this definition is no longer
accurate because a different individual or position has responsibility for the
overall operation of the facility or overall responsibility for the
environmental matters for the company, a new authorization satisfying the
requirements of subsection D of this definition must be submitted to the
Village prior to or together with any reports to be signed by an authorized
representative.
BUILDING SANITARY SEWER: A sewer lateral which carries only sewage and
industrial wastes from the building plumbing to the wastewater sewer system.
BUILDING STORM WATER SEWER: A sewer which carries only storm water drainage,
surface water, foundation drainage and roof drainage, but excludes sewage and
industrial wastes from the building plumbing to a public storm sewer system or
natural outlet.
BYPASS: The intentional diversion of waste streams from any portion of a user's
treatment facility.
CATEGORICAL PRETREATMENT STANDARD OR CATEGORICAL STANDARD: Any regulation
containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by EPA in accordance with
sections 307(b) and (c) of the act (33 USC section 1317) which apply to a
specific category of users and which appear in 40 CFR chapter I, subchapter N,
parts 405–471.
COMMERCIAL USER: A nonindustrial user; also any user of the treatment works not
classified as an industrial user or excluded as an industrial user by this
chapter.
COMPATIBLE POLLUTANT: Suspended solids, FOG, pH, and fecal coliform bacteria.
COMPOSITE SAMPLE: Sample of wastewater based on a flow proportional or time
proportional method.
CONCENTRATION LIMITATIONS: The limits imposing the amount of a given substance
in a discrete unit volume of a solution or applied to a unit weight of solid.
CONTROL AUTHORITY: The village of South Barrington, Cook County, Illinois.
COOLING WATER: The water discharged from any use such as air conditioning,
cooling or refrigeration, to which the only pollutant added is heat.
DISCHARGE: The discharge of treated or untreated wastewater to the wastewater
sewer system.
DISCHARGER: Any person, firm, establishment, or institution which discharges
wastewater, excluding inflow and infiltration, to a sanitary sewer which
eventually leads into the wastewater sewer system. Each single connection is a
separate discharge by a discharger. The term "user" is used interchangeably
with the term "discharger".
EASEMENT: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others.
ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY OR EPA: The United States environmental
protection agency or other duly authorized official of said agency.
FOG: Any hydrocarbons, fatty acids, soaps, fats, waxes, oils, and any other
similar or related materials.
GARBAGE: Solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food and
from the handling, storage and sale of produce.
GENERAL PRETREATMENT REGULATIONS: The general pretreatment regulations for
existing and new sources, 40 CFR part 403, as amended.
GRAB SAMPLE: A sample which is taken from a waste stream with no regard to the
flow in the waste stream and over a period of time not to exceed fifteen (15)
minutes.
ILLINOIS ACT: The environmental protection act 1 , as amended.
INCOMPATIBLE POLLUTANT: Any pollutant which is not a "compatible pollutant" as
defined in this Section.
INDIRECT DISCHARGE: The introduction of pollutants into the wastewater sewer
system from any nondomestic source regulated under section 307(b), (c), or (d)
of the Act.
INDUSTRIAL USER: A source of indirect discharge, including, but not limited to,
a manufacturing, commercial or process facility, or other facility engaged in
the purchase or sale of goods, transaction of business or which otherwise
renders services to the public.
INDUSTRIAL WASTES: The liquid wastes from industrial users as opposed to
sanitary sewage.
INSTANTANEOUS MAXIMUM ALLOWABLE DISCHARGE LIMIT: The maximum concentration of a
pollutant allowed to be discharged at any time, determined from the analysis of
any discrete or composite sample collected, independent of the industrial flow
rate and the duration of the sampling event.
INTERFERENCE: A discharge, which alone or in conjunction with a discharge or
discharges from other sources, inhibits or disrupts the wastewater sewer system
and, therefore, is a cause of a violation of any permit of the Village issued
by the MWRD or any State or Federal agency.
MASS LIMITATION: Limits imposed upon a discharger based upon volumes or
concentrations that are converted to weight.
MEDICAL WASTE: Isolation wastes, infectious agents, human blood and blood
products, pathological wastes, sharps, body parts, contaminated bedding,
surgical wastes, potentially contaminated laboratory wastes and dialysis wastes
or other related wastes.
MILLIGRAMS PER LITER: A unit of the concentration of water or wastewater
constituent. It is 0.001 grams of the constituent in one thousand milliliters
(1,000 ml) of water. It has replaced the unit formerly commonly used, part per
million, to which it is approximately equivalent in reporting the results of
water and wastewater analysis.
NATIONAL PRETREATMENT STANDARD: Any regulation containing pollutant discharge
limits promulgated by the EPA in accordance with sections 307(b) and (c) of the
Act, which applies to industrial users. The term includes prohibitive discharge
limits established pursuant to 40 CFR section 403.5.
NATURAL OUTLET: Any outlet into watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of
surface water or ground water.
NEW SOURCE: A. Any building, structure, facility, or installation from which
there is or may be a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which
commenced after the publication in the Code of Federal Regulations of proposed
pretreatment standards under section 307(c) of the Act which will be applicable
to such source if such standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with
that section 307(c), provided that:
      1.   The building, structure, facility, or installation is constructed at
a site at which no other source is located; or
      2.   The building, structure, facility, or installation totally replaces
the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at
an existing source; or
      3.   The production or wastewater generating processes of the building,
structure, facility, or installation are substantially independent of an
existing source at the same site. In determining whether these are
substantially independent, factors such as the extent to which the new facility
is integrated with the existing plant, and the extent to which the new facility
is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source, should
be considered.
   B.   A site at which an existing source is located and where construction
results in a modification rather than a source as defined in subsection A of
this definition, provided the construction does not create a new building,
structure, facility, or installation meeting the criteria of subsection A2 or
A3 of this definition but otherwise alters, replaces, or adds to existing
process or production equipment.
   C.   A site where construction has commenced, including where the owner or
operator has:
      1.   Begun, or caused to begin, as part of a continuous on-site
construction program:
         a.   Any placement, assembly, or installation of facilities or
equipment; or
         b.   Site preparation work including clearing, excavation, or removal
of existing buildings, structures, or facilities which are necessary for the
placement, assembly, or installation of a new source facilities or equipment;
or
      2.   Entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase of
facilities or equipment which is intended to be used in its operation within a
reasonable time. Options to purchase or contracts which can be terminated or
modified without substantial loss, and contracts for feasibility, engineering,
and design studies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this
subsection C.
NONCONTACT COOLING WATER: Water used for cooling which does not come into
direct contact with any raw material, intermediate product, waste product, or
finished product.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation,
association, joint stock company, trust estate, limited liability company,
limited liability partnership, governmental entity, or other legal entity; or
their legal representatives, agents, or assigns. This definition includes all
Federal, State, and local governmental entities.
pH: A measure of the acidity or alkalinity of a solution, expressed in standard
units.
POLLUTANT: Dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, filter backwash,
sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, medical wastes, chemical wastes,
biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discarded
equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt, municipal, agricultural and industrial
wastes, and certain characteristics of wastewater (e.g., pH, temperature, TSS,
turbidity, color, BOD, COD, toxicity, or odor).
PRETREATMENT: The reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of
pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in
wastewater prior to, or in lieu of, introducing such pollutants into the
wastewater sewer system. This reduction or alteration can be obtained by
physical, chemical, or biological processes; by process changes; or by other
means, except by diluting the concentration of the pollutants unless allowed by
an applicable pretreatment standard.
PRETREATMENT REQUIREMENTS: Any substantive or procedural requirement related to
pretreatment imposed on a user, other than a pretreatment standard.
PRETREATMENT STANDARDS: Prohibited discharge standards, categorical standards,
and local limits.
PROHIBITED DISCHARGE STANDARD: Any regulation developed under the authority of
section 307(b) of the Act and 40 CFR part 403.5 as published in the Code of
Federal Regulations, revised as of July 1, 1994, published by the Office of the
Federal Register, National Archives and Records Administration.
PROHIBITED DISCHARGES: Absolute prohibitions against the discharge of certain
substances.
REQUIRED: The tasks stated shall be done.
SWDA: The Solid Waste Disposal Act, 42 USC section 6901 et seq.
SEPTIC TANK WASTE: Any sewage from holding tanks such as vessels, chemical
toilets, campers, trailers, and septic tanks.
SEWAGE: Human excrement and gray water (household showers, dishwashing
operations, etc.).
SHALL AND MAY: Shall is required; may is permissive.
SIGNIFICANT INDUSTRIAL USER:
   A.   A user subject to categorical pretreatment standards; or
   B.   A user that:
      1.   Discharges an average of twenty five thousand (25,000) gpd or more
of process wastewater to the wastewater sewer system (excluding sanitary,
noncontact cooling, and boiler blowdown wastewater); or
      2.   Is designated as such by the Village on the basis that it has a
reasonable potential for adversely affecting the wastewater sewer system's
operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement.
   C.   Upon finding that a user meeting the criteria in subsection B of this
definition has no reasonable potential for adversely affecting the wastewater
sewer system's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or
requirement, the Village may at any time, on its own initiative or in response
to a petition received from a user, and in accordance with the procedures in 40
CFR 403.8(f)(6), determine that such user should not be considered a
significant industrial user.
SLUG LOAD OR SLUG: Any discharge at a flow rate or concentration which
potentially would cause interference with the wastewater sewer system and/or a
violation of the prohibited discharge standards in Section
4-8A-4 of this Chapter. Any discharge of water, sewage, or industrial waste,
which, in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow,
exceeds, for any period or duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes, more than
five (5) times the average twenty four (24) hour concentration of flows during
normal operation of flows during normal operation and in no event more than
five (5) times the allowable concentration of constituents set forth in this
Chapter or the user's permit or any pollutant released in a discharge at a flow
rate and/or pollutant concentration which potentially will cause interference
with the wastewater sewer system and/or violate prohibited discharge standards
in Section
4-8A-4 of this Chapter.
SOLID WASTES: Any trash, ashes, rags, bottles, tin cans, tree limbs, manure of
domestic animals, offal, dead animals or portions thereof, foodstuffs, and
wastes thereof other than normally contained in sanitary sewage and any and all
other solid objects, materials, refuse or debris. The term "ashes" shall
include the residuum resulting from the combustion of coal, coke, wood, or any
other material or substance and shall include soot, cinders, slag and charcoal.
STANDARD INDUSTRIAL CLASSIFICATION (SIC) CODE: A classification pursuant to the
"Standard Industrial Classification Manual" issued by the United States office
of management and budget.
STORMWATER: Any flow occurring during or following any form of natural
precipitation, and resulting from such precipitation, including snowmelt.
SUSPENDED SOLIDS: The total suspended matter that floats on the surface of, or
is suspended in, water, wastewater, or other liquid, and which is removable by
laboratory filtering. Nonfilterable solids expressed in milligrams per liter,
contained in wastewater and measured by the methods set forth in "Standard
Methods For The Examination Of Water And Wastewater" or such other method as
approved by the EPA.
TSS: Solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in,
water, sewage, or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory
filtering.
TOXIC POLLUTANTS: Any pollutant or combination of pollutants listed in
regulations promulgated by the administrator under provision of the act.
USER: A source of direct or indirect discharge to the wastewater sewer system.
VILLAGE: The village of South Barrington, Cook County, Illinois.
VILLAGE ENGINEER: The village engineer of the village of South Barrington who
is designated by the village to oversee the operation and maintenance of the
wastewater sewer system, and who is charged with certain duties and
responsibilities by this chapter.
WASTEWATER: Liquid and water carried industrial wastes and sewage from
residential dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial and manufacturing
facilities, and institutions, whether treated or untreated, which are
contributed to the wastewater sewer system.
WASTEWATER SEWER SYSTEM: The wastewater sewer system and all appurtenances
thereto of the village, but not including building sewers or any portion owned
by the MWRD. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999; amd. Ord. 0-2007-814, 5-10-2007)
 
Notes
1 1. 415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.
4-8A-2: GENERAL USE REQUIREMENTS:
4-8A-2-200: SEWER ENGINEERING AND INSTALLATION:
All sanitary sewer systems shall be engineered and installed in accordance with
this code and other ordinances of the village. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
4-8A-2-201: NO SERVICE OUTSIDE VILLAGE LIMITS:
   A.   All sanitary sewer connections within the corporate limits of the
village shall be at the option of the village.
   B.   Any owner(s) of property located outside the village limits that
desires to connect his or her property to the village's sanitary sewer system
must apply to the board of trustees for annexation to the village. The board of
trustees shall not grant permission to make any such connection(s) to any owner
(s) unless and until the owner(s) files an unconditional petition to annex his
or her property to the village. The village shall not be required to permit
such annexation and may include conditions of annexation in any annexation
agreement.
   C.   The village shall not allow any property outside the corporate limits
to connect to the village's sewer system except in accordance with an
intergovernmental agreement with another unit of government. (Ord. 2006-769, 4-
13-2006)
4-8A-2-210: CONNECTION PERMIT REQUIREMENTS; APPLICATION AND ISSUANCE:
   A.   It is unlawful to make any connection with the building sewer and
wastewater sewer system without first having obtained a permit from the
village.
   B.   Applications for connection permits shall be made on the building
application forms provided by the village. Prior to final approval of the
connection, the applicant must submit four (4) original signed copies of the
MWRD permit application with all appropriate schedules. The village will sign
the permits and then return the permits to the applicant to mail to the MWRD
for its review and for approval.
   C.   No permit for a building sewer and connection to the wastewater sewer
system shall be issued by the village unless it is determined that the
applicant has complied with all applicable ordinances of the village.
   D.   No person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into,
use, alter, or disturb any part of the wastewater sewer system or appurtenance
thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the village and paying
all applicable fees to the village.
   E.   The permit application fee is established by resolution of the village
board.
   F.   No connection to the village owned and/or maintained sewer will be
permitted unless the village approves the connection. The village of South
Barrington may approve or deny the connection in its sole discretion. (Ord. 0-
2015-1072, 5-21-2015)
4-8A-2-220: DISCHARGE OF STORMWATER AND OTHER UNPOLLUTED DRAINAGE TO SANITARY
SEWER PROHIBITED:
   A.   No person owning, or in possession of, real estate shall discharge or
cause or permit to be discharged, any stormwater, surface water, groundwater,
roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water or unpolluted
waters into the wastewater sewer system.
   B.   All downspouts, outside stairwells and roof drains shall discharge onto
the ground or be connected to storm sewers, drainage ditches or storm drainage
systems. Footing drains shall be connected to sump pumps and discharge shall be
made into storm sewers, sewer lines connected to storm sewers, drainage ditches
or storm drainage systems. Sump pumps installed to receive and discharge ground
waters or surface waters shall be connected to a storm sewer or into a drainage
ditch or storm drainage system. Sump pumps installed to receive and discharge
building floor drain flow, laundry tubs or other wastewater shall be connected
to the sanitary sewers pursuant to this Code. Each individual sump pump shall
be used for one function only, either the discharge of uncontaminated storm-
related ground waters or the discharge of wastewater. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
4-8A-2-230: UNLAWFUL USE OR CONSTRUCTION OF PRIVATE SEWER DISPOSAL SYSTEMS:
It is unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank,
cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage except
as provided in Section
4-8A-2-265 of this Chapter. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
4-8A-2-240: CONNECTION OF CERTAIN SEWERS TO PUBLIC SANITARY SEWER PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person owning or in possession of real estate to
connect, permit to be connected or permit to remain connected to the wastewater
sewer system any building sewer which receives roof drainage, foundation
drainage, surface water or ground water. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
4-8A-2-250: CONSTRUCTION OF COMBINED SEWERS PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful to construct combined sewers or other facilities intended to
receive both runoff and sewage. Separate sanitary sewers and separate storm
sewers shall be provided for all buildings within the Village which are served
by the wastewater sewer system. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
4-8A-2-255: INSTALLATION OF TOILET FACILITIES REQUIRED BY OWNER:
The owners of all buildings or properties used for public occupancy,
employment, recreation or other purpose, situated in the Village and abutting
on any street, right of way, or easement in which there is located any part of
the wastewater sewer system, are required at their expense to provide a
building sanitary sewer service line connecting the subject property to the
wastewater sewer system in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter. Said
connection shall occur within ninety (90) days after date of Village notice to
do so, provided the wastewater sewer system is within one thousand feet
(1,000') of the property line. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
4-8A-2-260: UNAUTHORIZED DESTRUCTION OR DEFACEMENT OF SEWAGE EQUIPMENT
PROHIBITED:
No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully, or negligently break,
damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or
equipment which is a part of the wastewater sewer system. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-
1999)
4-8A-2-265: PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS REQUIREMENTS; GENERALLY:
   A.   System Unavailable: Where the wastewater sewer system is not available
under the provisions of this Chapter, as defined in Section
4-8A-2-255 of this Chapter, the building sanitary sewer shall be connected to a
private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this Section.
   B.   Permit And Fee: No construction shall be permitted for any private
sewage disposal system or for any building to be served by a private sewage
disposal system, within the Village, unless a permit for a private sewage
disposal system has first been obtained from the Village. In addition, no
permit will be issued unless the construction is to be done by an Illinois
Department of Public Health licensed private sewage disposal system contractor.
All percolation tests and private sewage disposal system plans shall be
completed in conformance with all County and State regulations, based on
location of property. No criteria shall be less stringent than the criteria of
the Illinois State Plumbing Code, 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 320/1 and the
Private Sewage Disposal Licensing Act, 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 225/1.
Percolation tests shall be conducted and evaluated under the supervision of a
registered professional engineer licensed to practice in Illinois.
   C.   Adoption Of Code: There is adopted by the Village those certain codes,
which are known as the Illinois State Plumbing Code and the Private Sewage
Disposal Licensing Act, the same being hereby adopted and incorporated as fully
as if set out at length herein.
   D.   Inspections And Cleaning: All private sewage disposal systems installed
and operated within the Village limits may be subject to inspection by the
Village, to determine if the system is functioning properly and which
determination shall include, but not be limited to, a finding concerning the
following:
      1.   Contaminated surface or ground water;
      2.   Odorant production;
      3.   Depth of sludge in the septic tank;
      4.   Clogged seepage field;
      5.   Improper draining of the plumbing fixtures as a result of clogged
septic tank and/or seepage field;
      6.   Contaminated footing drain sump water.
If, after inspection, it is determined that the private sewage system is not
functioning properly, the owner and/or occupant shall be notified in writing to
have the necessary work performed to correct the malfunction. If modifications
to the system are required and are allowable, pursuant to the Illinois State
Plumbing Code and the Private Sewage Disposal Licensing Act and Code, both as
modified herein, said modifications shall be done by a licensed private sewage
disposal contractor. The owner and/or occupant shall be given a reasonable
amount of time. It is the responsibility of the property owner and occupant to
have the septic tank cleaned no less than once every five (5) years. The
Village may require the property owner to submit a copy of the paid bill for
such cleaning and services rendered by a licensed private sewage disposal
contractor. The Village may maintain a file system to inform property owners
and occupants of the necessity for cleaning the septic tank.
   E.   Connection To Wastewater Sewer System: In the event the malfunction
cannot be corrected by cleaning and repair and the property is within one
hundred feet (100') of the wastewater sewer system, the private system shall be
disconnected and connection made to the wastewater sewer system. (Ord. 99-586,
9-9-1999)
4-8A-2-270: BUILDING SEWERS; REQUIREMENTS; GENERALLY:
   A.   A separate and independent building sanitary sewer shall be provided
for every building. The sanitary sewer service shall be installed in a location
as approved by the Village. A building having one common wall with another
building is considered a separate building and shall have a separate building
sanitary sewer.
   B.   Existing building sanitary sewers and/or storm sewers may be used in
connection with new buildings only when they are found on examination and test
by the Village to meet all requirements of this Code.
   C.   New building sanitary sewers shall be installed in accordance with the
standards and procedures set forth in this Code, the ordinances, regulations
and rules of the MWRD, and State requirements. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
4-8A-2-275: BUILDING SEWERS; OWNER AND OCCUPANT RESPONSIBILITY FOR COST OF
INSTALLATION AND CONNECTION:
All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the
building sanitary sewer to the wastewater sewer system shall be borne by the
owner and occupant jointly and severally. The owner shall indemnify and hold
the Village harmless from any liability or loss including reasonable attorney
fees arising out of or in connection with the installation of the sewer for a
building, except to the extent prohibited by law. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
4-8A-2-280: OWNER AND OCCUPANT RESPONSIBILITY FOR MAINTENANCE:
The owner and occupant of the premises served by the wastewater sewer system
shall jointly and severally properly maintain and operate a building sewer or
sanitary sewer line to the point of connection to the wastewater sewer system.
Said point of connection shall be the sanitary sewer main. "Maintenance" means
keeping the sanitary sewer connection, sewer lines and other sewer facilities
in satisfactory working condition and in a good state of repair (including, but
not limited to, preventing any obstruction of extraneous material or flows from
entering said facilities, protecting said facilities from any damage and
keeping same free from defects and malfunctions), and making necessary
provisions and taking necessary precautions to assure that said sewer
facilities are at all times capable of satisfactorily performing the services
adequately discharging the facilities are intended to perform, discharge or
produce. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
4-8A-2-285: INSPECTIONS OF BUILDINGS TO BE CONNECTED TO SEWER SYSTEM:
   A.   Upon payment of the permit fee, the Village, or its designee, shall
make the following inspections of each building to be connected to the
wastewater sewer system:
      1.   An inspection shall be made at the time the sewer ditch is opened
and the connection is made to the wastewater sewer system to determine that
there is proper grade and connection.
      2.   An inspection shall be made before the fill is put around the
foundation and while the tile is still exposed around the foundation to see
that there has been no connection of such drain tile with the wastewater sewer
system.
      3.   A third and final inspection shall be made after the eaves troughs,
downspouts and sump pumps have been installed to see that there is no
connection of the aforesaid with the wastewater sewer system.
   B.   The provisions of applicable statutes, ordinances and rules and
regulations relating to excavations in streets shall be complied with in making
excavations in streets and other public places for sewer connections. (Ord. 99-
586, 9-9-1999)
4-8A-3: WASTEWATER TREATMENT RATES:
4-8A-3-300: PRETREATMENT CHARGES AND FEES:
The Village may adopt reasonable fees for reimbursement of costs of setting up
and operating the Village's pretreatment program which may include:
   A.   Fees for wastewater discharge permit applications including the cost of
processing such applications;
   B.   Fees for monitoring, inspection, and surveillance procedures including
the cost of collection and analyzing a user's discharge, and reviewing
monitoring reports submitted by users;
   C.   Fees for reviewing and responding to accidental discharge procedures
and construction;
   D.   Fees for filing appeals;
   E.   Other fees as the Village may deem necessary to carry out the
requirements contained herein. These fees relate solely to the matters covered
by this Chapter and are separate from all other fees, fines, and penalties
collectable by the Village; and
   F.   Fees for all sampling and testing shall be the cost and expense
incurred by the Village plus twenty percent (20%).
Bills for monitoring services shall be sent out monthly for all customers and
