99-586, 9-9-1999; amd. Ord. 0-2007-814, 5-10-2007)
4-8A-8: MONITORING:
4-8A-8-800: MONITORING PROGRAM BY VILLAGE:
The village engineer may create a program for monitoring industrial user
discharges; provided, that any industrial user that has a population
equivalent, as determined by the village engineer, equal to or greater than one
hundred (100) shall be monitored no less than once annually. All other
industrial users would be monitored at such frequency as deemed necessary by
the village engineer. Monitoring shall consist of the taking and testing of
grab samples or twenty four (24) hour composite samples as deemed reasonably
necessary by the village engineer for determination of the population
equivalent of the industrial user. The monitoring data collected shall be used
to determine the population equivalent. In the event that a sampling manhole
does not exist, the "sampling manhole" shall be considered to be the nearest
downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer
is connected, until such time as the sampling manhole has been constructed.
Industrial user shall be subject to fees for sampling and testing of their
discharge as it pertains to the village's monitoring program. (Ord. 99-586, 9-
9-1999; amd. Ord. 0-2007-814, 5-10-2007)
Where required by the village, additional control manholes or sampling chambers
shall be provided at the end of each industrial process within an industrial
user's facility suitable for the determination of compliance with pretreatment
standards. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
4-8A-8-810: RIGHT OF ENTRY; INSPECTION AND SAMPLING:
The village engineer or his/her authorized designee shall have the right to
enter the premises of any user to determine whether the user is complying with
all requirements of this chapter and any wastewater discharge permit or order
issued hereunder. Users shall allow the village engineer or his/her authorized
designee ready access to all parts of the premises for the purposes of
inspection, sampling, records examination and copying, and the performance of
any additional duties.
   A.   Where a user has security measures in force which require proper
identification and clearance before entry into the premises, the user shall
make the necessary arrangements, with its security guards so that, upon
presentation of suitable identification, the village engineer or his/her
authorized designee will be permitted to enter without delay for the purposes
of performing specific responsibilities.
   B.   The village engineer or his/her authorized designee shall have the
right to set up on the user's property, or require installation of, such
devices as are necessary to conduct sampling and/or metering of the user's
operations. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999; amd. Ord. 0-2007-814, 5-10-2007)
   C.   The industrial user may request that the representative of the village
state the purpose of any inspection, and further, may request that such
representative abide by reasonable safety and hygiene requirements. (Ord. 99-
586, 9-9-1999)
   D.   The village engineer may require the user to install monitoring
equipment as necessary in accordance with section
4-8A-6-600 of this chapter. The facility's sampling and monitoring equipment
shall be maintained at all times in a safe and proper operating condition by
the user at its own expense. All devices used to measure wastewater flow and
quality shall be calibrated by the user biannually to ensure their accuracy.
   E.   Any temporary or permanent obstruction to safe and easy access to the
facility to be inspected and/or sampled shall be promptly removed by the user
at the written or verbal request of the village engineer and shall not be
replaced. The costs of clearing such access shall be borne by the user. (Ord.
99-586, 9-9-1999; amd. Ord. 0-2007-814, 5-10-2007)
   F.   Nothing herein shall be construed to limit or restrict any industrial
user from exercising any right it may have to object to the nature and extent
of any inspection access request, or to object to any inspection access request
as not necessary to carry out the purposes of the village pursuant to this
chapter. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
   G.   Unreasonable delays in allowing the village engineer or his/her
authorized designee access to the user's premises shall be a violation of this
chapter. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999; amd. Ord. 0-2007-814, 5-10-2007)
4-8A-8-820: SEARCH WARRANTS:
If the village engineer or his/her authorized designee has been refused access
to a building, structure, or property, or any part thereof, and is able to
demonstrate probable cause to believe that there may be a violation of this
chapter, or that there is a need to inspect and/or sample as part of a routine
inspection and sampling program of the village designed to verify compliance
with this chapter or any permit or order issued hereunder, or to protect the
overall public health, safety and welfare of the community, then the village
engineer or his/her authorized designee may seek issuance of a search warrant
from the circuit court. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999; amd. Ord. 0-2007-814, 5-10-
2007)
4-8A-8-840: CONTROL MANHOLE DEVICE AND SAMPLING REQUIREMENTS; LOCATION,
CONSTRUCTION, MAINTENANCE AND FACILITY MONITORING:
   A.   When required by the village engineer, the owner and/or occupant of any
property served by a building sanitary sewer carrying industrial waste shall
install a suitable control manhole in the building sanitary sewer to facilitate
observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when
required, shall include, but not be limited to, being accessible, safely
located, and provide for one hundred ten (110) volt hookup and shall be
constructed in accordance with plans approved by the village engineer. The
manhole shall be installed by the owner and/or occupant at his expense, and
shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible to the village at
all times.
   B.   When in the judgment of the village engineer there exists sufficient
volumes and/or quantities of contaminants that may interfere with the
performance of the wastewater sewer system, the village engineer may require
the owner and/or occupant of any property and/or an industrial user served by a
building sanitary sewer carrying industrial wastes to install composite
sampling equipment and/or flow measurement equipment. Said composite sampling
and flow measurement equipment shall be installed by the property owner and/or
occupant at its expense and shall be maintained by it as to be functional at
all times, safe and accessible to the village. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999; amd.
Ord. 0-2007-814, 5-10-2007)
   C.   The owner and/or occupant shall be responsible for monitoring its
effluent to ensure that its discharge meets village, MWRD, state and federal
laws and requirements. It is also responsible for having knowledge of the
contaminants in its wastewater and the specific limitations relative to its
discharge. Records shall be kept by the owner and/or occupant of the results of
all sampling and/or flow measurements. Such documentation shall be available to
appropriate village personnel at all reasonable times. Records shall be kept by
the owner and/or occupant no less than three (3) years or longer if required by
state or federal laws prior to discard or if an enforcement action is pending.
(Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
   D.   Where composite sampling equipment is available, the village shall
utilize such composite samples for purposes of calculating surcharges pursuant
to section
4-8A-3-310 of this chapter. The average of all composite samples during the
monitoring period shall be used to determine the multiplier. Should the
composite sampling equipment malfunction or if it does not exist, the village
shall use composite grab samples of not less than four (4) aliquots in a twenty
four (24) hour period, unless the user agrees to less than four (4) grab
samples in a twenty four (24) hour period, to determine surcharges as set forth
in section
4-8A-3-310 of this chapter. The average of all grab samples taken by the
village during the billing period shall be used for the multiplier. Where
nonfunctional composite equipment exists and at such time that a grab sample
exceeds the limitations specified in section
4-8A-4-400 of this chapter for total suspended solids, ammonia, phosphorous or
grease, the village and waste generator shall split grab samples no less than
five (5) samples per week until the composite sampler is once again functional.
Should the composite sampler become functional prior to the end of the billing
period, composite samples shall be taken no less than five (5) per week for the
remainder of the billing period for computing the average of the grab and
composite samples to determine the billing multiplier. The village engineer
shall decide the time when split sampling will be taken. Should there be a
significant discrepancy between the owner's and/or occupant's test results and
the village's test results on split samples, the owner and/or occupant may
request billing to be based upon testing results from an independent testing
laboratory. Upon investigation by the village engineer as to the reasons for
the discrepancy in sample results, the village engineer shall take appropriate
corrective actions and/or authorized in writing the terms of using a certified
independent testing laboratory. The choice of independent laboratory shall be
at the discrepancy of the village engineer. All expenses incurred for
monitoring by an independent certified laboratory shall be at the expense of
the owner and/or occupant.
   E.   Should the village engineer find violations of standards set forth in
this chapter including sections
4-8A-4-400,
4-8A-4-420, and/or
4-8A-4-430 of this chapter, the village engineer may require the owner and/or
occupant to provide access for the use of laboratory testing equipment or to
contract for laboratory testing services and provide the village with a copy of
the test results of the constituent(s) monitored. Upon review of the products
and byproducts of the owner and/or occupant operation and the type of
wastewater that is indigenous to the operation, the village engineer shall also
stipulate what constituents are to be monitored to ensure proper performance by
the village sewerage system in compliance with this chapter, any MWRD
requirement, state and federal law.
   F.   Where nonfunctional or malfunctioning flow measurement equipment
exists, the water generator and/or industrial user shall notify the village
engineer within twenty four (24) hours of his or her knowledge of the
malfunction so appropriate interim measurement arrangements can be made. (Ord.
99-586, 9-9-1999; amd. Ord. 0-2007-814, 5-10-2007)
4-8A-8-850: SEVERABILITY:
If any provision of this chapter is invalidated by any court of competent
jurisdiction, the remaining provisions shall not be affected and shall continue
in full force and effect. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
4-8A-8-860: ADMINISTRATION:
The provisions of this chapter shall be administered and enforced by the
village president or his/her designee. (Ord. 99-586, 9-9-1999)
4-8A-9: PENALTY:
4-8A-9-900: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any portion of this chapter shall be
fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. Each day on which a
violation continues or persists shall be deemed a separate offense. The village
engineer or his designee may issue violation notices of this chapter. (Ord. 0-
2007-814, 5-10-2007)

4-8B-1: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
4-8B-1-100: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used
in this chapter shall be as follows:
APPROVING AUTHORITY: The village administrator.
CLARIFICATION OF WORD USAGE: Shall is mandatory; may is permissible.
CURB STOP: A shutoff valve attached to a water service pipe from a water main
to a building installed near the curb, which may be operated by a valve key to
start or stop flow in the water supply lines of a building. May be referred to
as "buffalo box" or "round way".
EASEMENT: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others.
PERSON: Any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any individual,
firm, company, municipal or private corporation, association, society,
institution, enterprise, governmental agency or other entity.
SERVICE AREA: That portion of the area surrounded by Bartlett Road on the north
and east, Higgins Road (State Route 72) on the south, and Sutton Road (State
Route 59) on the west that is located within the corporate boundary of the
village and the Rose School site at the southeast corner of Bartlett Road and
Penny Road.
SERVICE BOX: A valve box used with corporation or curb cock.
TYPES OF CHARGES:
Basic User Charge: The basic monthly assessment levied on all users of the
public water system for being connected to the system.
Meter Charge: The amount to be paid for the water meter and the cost of
installation.
Water User Charge: A charge based upon water usage that is levied on users of
the water system for the cost of operation, maintenance and replacement.
USER, WATER USER: A customer of the water utility system.
VILLAGE: The village of South Barrington.
VILLAGE ENGINEER: The South Barrington village engineer or another individual
designated by the village. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-2: GENERAL USE REQUIREMENT:
4-8B-2-200: CONNECTION PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE:
The water distribution system for any building located within the service area
that is intended for or used for human habitation or occupancy shall be
supplied by potable water from the village water system only; provided,
however, that no connection shall be made to such municipal water system
without a permit issued by the village engineer and payment of the applicable
connection fee. All industrial, commercial or institutional users of water not
served or partially served by the village municipal system shall be required to
meter its water supply to the same standards, rules and regulations as apply to
the village system. The connection fees for the village water system are as
follows:
Water Meter Size (In Inches) Connection Fee
Water Meter Size (In Inches) Connection Fee
3/4                          $ 1,500.00
1                            2,000.00
11/2                         5,000.00
2                            8,000.00
3                            15,000.00
4                            25,000.00
6                            50,000.00
8 and over                   80,000.00
 
The connection fees set forth herein shall not affect or repeal any specific
valid arrangement for the payment of such connection fees or the connection of
specific properties. (Ord. 2011-946, 9-8-2011)
4-8B-2-205: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
Each application for the permit to connect to or disconnect from a public water
main shall be accompanied by any certificate of insurance covering commercial
general liability insurance in the amount of one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) combined single limit for bodily injury and property damage,
naming the village as an additional insured to hold the village harmless from
any damages and costs which might be caused by accidents. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-
10-2007)
4-8B-2-210: SUPERVISION OF CONNECTIONS; INSPECTIONS:
All water connections shall be made under the supervision of the village
engineer, and no connection shall be covered until the work has been inspected
by the village engineer or his designee. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-2-215: TURNON OF WATER:
   A.   Application For Turnon: Application to have water turned on shall be
made to the village on applications provided by the village and shall contain
an agreement by the applicant to abide by and accept all of the provisions of
this title as a condition governing the use of the village water supply by the
applicant.
   B.   Authority To Turn On: Only after the application for turnon has been
approved by the village shall water be turned on for the premises. No water
from the village water supply shall be turned on for service to any premises by
any person except the village engineer or some other person authorized by him
to perform this service.
   C.   Substandard Plumbing: No water shall be turned on for service in
premises in which the plumbing does not comply with the ordinances of the
village; provided, that water may be turned on for construction purposes in
unfinished buildings, subject to the provisions of this title. No water service
may be turned on without an appropriate water meter. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-
2007)
4-8B-2-220: HYDRANT USE:
   A.   Permit Required; Emergencies: No person, firm or corporation shall open
or draw water from any village fire hydrant or plug or interfere in any manner
therewith without the prior permission of the village engineer, or except in
the case of a fire or other similar emergency.
   B.   Fire Protection Services: The village engineer may issue a permit upon
request to any person, firm or corporation to make special connections with
village water mains in order to obtain a water supply for private hydrants and
standpipes for use in the case of fire. No charge shall be made for such permit
or for water used for fire protection purposes, but all such work in connection
with such fire protection system shall be done under the direction of the
village engineer. The owner of the premises where they are located shall
maintain such private facilities in good working order, and readily available
and open to inspections by the village at all times. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-
2007)
4-8B-2-225: SERVICE PIPES AND CONNECTIONS:
   A.   Installation From Curb Stop To Premises: All service pipes from the
curb stop to the premises to be served shall be installed by, and at the cost
of, the owner of the property to be served or the applicant for the service.
Such installations shall be under the supervision of the village engineer or
his designee.
   B.   Piping Specifications: All water service pipes from the main to the
meter shall be not less than one inch (1") in size. Only type K copper tubing
shall be used to connect the meter with the mains. All fittings and connections
shall be uniform in size and shall comply with specifications established by
the corporate authorities. In all cases where a service pipe enters a building,
it shall be furnished with a shutoff valve placed within twelve inches (12") of
the inside wall where the service enters the building between the meter and the
wall, and a similar shutoff valve shall be placed on the opposite side of the
meter within twelve inches (12") thereof. Such stops or valves shall have a
handle or wrench attached thereto for the purpose of turning same so that the
water may be turned off in case of leaks in the building. Such stops or valves
shall be kept accessible at all times.
   C.   Depth: All service pipes shall be buried at least four and one-half
feet (41/2') deep in the ground.
   D.   Repairs From Curb Stop To Building:
      1.   All repairs to service pipes from the curb stop to the building or
premises served shall be made by and at the expense of the owners of the
building or premises served.
      2.   The village may, in case of emergency, repair any such service pipe,
and if this is done, the owner of the premises served shall repay the cost of
such repair work to the village.
      3.   In the event that a leak or break occurs in that portion of the
service pipe to be maintained by the owner of the premises, the village may
close the curb stop and discontinue the service of water to the premises until
the required repairs have been made by such owner.
      4.   The village shall not be liable for any damage caused by leak or
break in any service pipe, or for damage caused by a failure to repair the same
promptly; nor shall the village be liable for any damage caused by the repair
or installation of such pipes or resulting therefrom.
   E.   Excavations: Excavations for installing service pipes or repairing the
same shall be made in compliance with the ordinances relating to excavations in
streets.
   F.   Location Of Service Boxes:
      1.   Residential Service: Service boxes shall be placed on every service
pipe and shall be located near the curb line within the right of way or
easement. Such boxes shall be so located so that they are easily accessible,
and shall be protected from frost.
      2.   Commercial Service: Service boxes shall be so located so that they
are easily accessible, and shall be protected from frost in locations approved
by the village engineer.
   G.   Connection With Main: The service pipe from the main to the curb stop
shall hereafter be installed, subject to approval and inspection by the village
engineer, by and at the expense of the owner of the property or applicant for
service. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-2-230: NEW DEVELOPMENTS; USE OF OR DISCONNECTION FROM MAINS:
   A.   Definition: For the purposes of this section, "disconnection" means: 1)
closing the corporation stop into the water main; 2) removing the service box
and curb stop from the water service distribution system; and 3) accomplishing
any restoration work on the property in question.
   B.   Reuse Or Disconnection: When an application for a building or site
development permit is made for a property which, prior to the date of the
application, has been connected to the village water system, the application
must state whether the proposed building or development will use the existing
water system connection, or if a new or different water service and connection
is required by any law, ordinance or regulation, or if the applicant, though
not required to, desires a new or different water service and connection. If a
new or different water service and connection is required as aforesaid, or if
the applicant desires a new or different water service and connection and such
desired service and connection is approved by the village, then, in each such
event, the applicant must disconnect the existing service, as provided in this
section, in order to obtain the permit.
   C.   Responsibility For Disconnection; Inspection: It shall be the
responsibility of the applicant for the building or development permit to bear
all expenses to accomplish the disconnection as provided in this section,
including the restoration work. The disconnection shall be made only by a
licensed plumber and shall be inspected by the village engineer or his designee
before the work is covered.
   D.   Restrictions On Reuse: Under no circumstances shall any lead water
service lines serving said property be reused. All such water service lines
shall either be replaced with type K copper or with other materials that have
been approved by the village engineer, or abandoned. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-
2007)
4-8B-2-235: RESALE OF WATER:
No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the water
supply to any premises other than that for which the original sale has been
made, as evidenced by meter installation, except as may be specifically
authorized by the village engineer in cases of emergency use. (Ord. 0-2007-815,
5-10-2007)
4-8B-2-240: TAMPERING OR INTERFERING WITH SYSTEM:
   A.   Meters: No unauthorized person shall break or tamper with any seal
placed by the village upon any meter or other fixture which is part of the
village municipal water system. Meters shall be left in the condition as set by
the village and shall not be interfered with or tampered with in any manner. No
meter shall be removed, relocated or otherwise disturbed without the permission
of the village engineer; except, that duly licensed plumbers making repairs to
frozen services may remove the meter, provided it is immediately delivered to
the village engineer for inspection and test, and provided, that a bond wire is
installed prior to the removal. In no case shall a pipe coupling or bypass be
installed in the line in place of or around a meter, except in case of a frozen
meter, the public works personnel shall make such installation. Any person
violating this provision shall, in addition to such fines as established by
this code, be liable to pay an amount estimated by the village engineer to
cover the charges for water service not recorded by reason of the incorrect or
lost registration on the meter.
   B.   Obstructing Access:
      1.   No person shall in any manner obstruct the access to any stopcock,
hydrant or valve, or any public faucet or opening for taking water in any
street, alley, public ground or place connected with or part of the village
water system, nor pile or place any lumber, brick or building material or other
article, thing or hindrance whatsoever within twelve feet (12') of the same, or
so as to in any manner hinder, delay or obstruct the members of the fire
department in reaching the same and, in addition, it is unlawful for any person
in any manner to interfere with or obstruct the members of the fire department
in reaching the same.
      2.   No person shall prevent or deny access to any authorized village
employee attempting to read or inspect any meter during normal business hours.
   C.   Obstructing Flow: It is unlawful for any person in any manner to
interfere with or obstruct the flow, retention, storage or authorized use of
water in the village water system, reservoir or plant, or any part thereof, or
to injure, deface, remove or displace any water main, hydrant, service pipe,
water meter, service box, public fountain, valve, equipment or building
connected with the village water system, or well, or to cause, suffer or permit
any of said things to be done. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-2-245: WATER SERVICE OUTSIDE VILLAGE LIMITS PROHIBITED:
   A.   No building or other structure shall be connected to the village's
water system unless the parcel of real property on which the building or
structure is located is within the corporate limits of the village.
   B.   Any property within the corporate limits of the village that is
connected to and served by the village's water system shall be disconnected
from the village's water system upon disconnection of such property or part
thereof from the village unless the village has consented to such disconnection
and/or has entered into a written agreement to provide or continue to provide
such water service. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-3: WATER METERS AND RATES:
4-8B-3-300: METERS REQUIRED; CHARGES:
   A.   Meters Required; Charges Established: All premises using the village
water system shall be supplied with an adequate water meter approved by the
village engineer and furnished by the village. No meter shall be installed
unless there shall first have been paid to the village the meter charges
established by resolution of the village board.
   B.   Review Of Charges, Exemption: The water meter charge is intended to
cover the cost of the water meter as well as the cost of the inspection and
sealing of the same. If the village installs the meter, an additional charge
will be made to cover the cost of the installation. The determination of the
village engineer as to any water meter charge shall be subject to review by the
corporate authorities at the request of the applicant. The foregoing water
meter charges shall not be applicable to water meters for fire sprinkling
systems as provided in subsection 4-8B-2-220B of this chapter. (Ord. 0-2007-
815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-3-305: SUPERVISION OF AND STANDARDS FOR METER INSTALLATION:
Meters shall be installed under the direction of the village engineer or his
designee in a location that will be accessible for maintenance, reading and
repairs. The standards for installation of meters shall include, but not be
limited to, the following:
   A.   Meters shall not be set in any place where ground or surface water can
rise and cover it or otherwise interfere with its operation.
   B.   Where a service pipe enters a building, it shall be furnished with a
shutoff valve placed within twelve inches (12") of the inside wall where the
service enters the building between the meter and the wall, and a similar
shutoff valve shall be placed on the opposite side of the meter within twelve
inches (12") thereof. Such stops or valves shall have a handle or wrench
attached thereto for the purpose of turning same so that the water may be
turned off in case of leaks in the building. Electrical ground wires, when so
installed, shall only be connected to the street side of the meter and before
the shutoff valve.
   C.   In all new or remodeling construction, an electrical raceway conduit
shall be provided for the physical protection and maintenance of the meter
wiring. This conduit is to be continuous from the remote meter location to the
location of the inside meter.
   D.   A device to permit reading the meter from outside the building shall be
installed with each meter. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-3-310: LOCATION OF METERS:
   A.   General Requirements:
      1.   All meters installed in any structure shall be so located so as to
permit authorized village employees ready and safe accessibility for the
purpose of reading and maintaining such meters.
      2.   No building permit shall be issued for the erection or construction
of any single-family residential structure or multiple-family residential
structure unless the plans accompanying the application for any such permits
show compliance with provisions of this title.
      3.   In the event that a meter is situated in a location that is
inaccessible or difficult to access, the village engineer shall notify the
owner in writing of such condition. If the condition is not remedied in a
satisfactory manner at the expense of the owner within thirty (30) days after
the date such notice is sent, the water supply may be shut off in accordance
with the provisions of section
4-8B-3-340 of this chapter, and shall remain shut off until such condition has
been remedied.
   B.   Large Consumers: Large consumers, including commercial, manufacturing,
office and research establishments, and public buildings, shall provide
unobstructed access to the meter location for ready access during normal
working hours. All such water meters and appurtenant equipment shall become and
remain the property of the village upon installation and approval by the
village engineer or his designee.
   C.   Multi-Tenant Buildings: Each multi-tenant building shall have a common
meter room. The service pipe for a multi-tenant building shall enter the
building in the meter room and shall be furnished with a shutoff valve placed
in a location approved by the village engineer. All water meters used for
village billing purposes that serve the water users in the building shall be
located in the common meter room. Shutoff valves shall be placed on each side
of the meter within twelve inches (12") of the meter. All shutoff valves shall
have a handle or wrench attached thereto so that the water may be turned off in
case of leaks in the building or it is necessary to shut off the water service.
   D.   Second Meter For Water Irrigation Systems:
      1.   Upon payment of necessary fees to the village, a water user may
install a second water meter for the purpose of metering water for lawn
irrigation systems that do not result in drainage or release of water into the
sanitary sewer system.
      2.   The second meter shall be located in close proximity to the primary
meter. At the time of installation of the meter, the village shall inspect the
plumbing to confirm that only nonsewerage water flow is connected to such
second meter and that the primary meter is connected so as to meter all water
use. The village may conduct periodic inspections to determine that the meter
is properly connected and that only nonsewerage flows are being metered. (Ord.
0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-3-315: RESPONSIBILITY FOR METERS; READING AND MAINTENANCE:
   A.   Meters Furnished By Village: All meters used in connection with the
water system shall be furnished by the village and shall be and remain the
property of the village.
   B.   Cost Of Meters And Repairs: The actual cost to the village of
furnishing each meter shall be paid by the person ordering the same. The actual
cost of keeping such meter in repair shall be paid by the person ordering same
or by the owner or occupant of the premises as soon as the billing for same is
presented. The person upon whose application any meter is installed or the
occupant or owner of the premises where installed shall be liable for any
breakage by freezing or otherwise, or any loss or damage to said meter in any
manner except by ordinary use and wear, and the cost of making good such damage
or loss shall be paid by the person upon whose application such meter was
installed, or by the occupant or owner of the premises where installed as soon
as the billing for same is presented, and the amount thereof shall be a lien
against the premises in which such meter is located to the same extent and with
the same effect as delinquent water charges.
   C.   Reading Meters: The village administrator shall cause to be read every
water meter used in the village at such times as are necessary in order that
bills may be sent out at proper times. Reading inside meters shall be required
at least once a year. All meters shall be inspected upon a schedule determined
by the village administrator.
   D.   Accuracy Of Meters, Tests: Any user who disputes the accuracy of his
meter may request that such meter be tested. Upon payment to the village of a
fee established by resolution of the village board, the disputed meter will be
removed by representatives of the village and the meter will be delivered to a
testing facility designated by the village. The meter will be tested in
accordance with the American Water Works Association "Standard Practice For
Testing Of Meters". If, after such testing, the meter proves to be within three
percent (3%) of being accurate, the fee paid shall be retained by the village
to cover the cost of removal, testing and reinstallation of the meter. If,
after such testing, the meter is not accurate within three percent (3%), the
meter shall be repaired and replaced at no cost to the user, and the testing
fee shall be refunded in full. Further, if such testing indicates that the user
has been overcharged for his utility, then an appropriate adjustment will be
made and a credit issued to his account.
   E.   Tampering With Meter: No meter shall be removed or otherwise disturbed
without having first obtained permission to do so from the village engineer.
(Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-3-320: WATER RATES ESTABLISHED:
   A.   Computation: The charge to be paid by every person using water from the
village water system within the corporate limits of the village shall be
computed bimonthly (every 2 months) based upon the basic user charge determined
by the size of the water meter and the quantity of water used (water user
charge).
   B.   Rates: The rates and charges imposed to be paid by every person using
water from the village water system shall be as follows:
      1.   Basic User Charge: Established by resolution of the village board as
a monthly rate based upon meter size.
      2.   Basic Water Charge: Established by resolution of the village board
as a rate per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water used.
   C.   Large Users; Monthly Bills: The village may, but shall not be obligated
to, bill on a monthly basis consumers using in excess of one hundred thousand
(100,000) gallons of water during each bimonthly billing period, such monthly
billing may be based upon one estimated and a second actual reading. (Ord. 0-
2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-3-325: LIABILITY FOR SERVICE:
The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof, and the user of the water
service shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for such service to such
premises, and such service is furnished to the premises by the village only
upon the condition that the owner of the premises, occupant and user of such
service are jointly and severally liable therefor to the village. All users of
the system shall be liable to pay for all water delivered to the premises and
measured by the meter, including any water consumed due to a leak or faulty
equipment on the user's property. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-3-330: USE OF WATER DURING BUILDING CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   Application For Use: During construction of any building and before any
water meter is installed as is herein provided, any owner or contractor so
constructing such building may be permitted to use the village water supply by
making application therefor and paying the flat fee prescribed in this section.
   B.   Restrictions On Use: Any owner or contractor shall use the village
water supply only for purposes directly related to the construction of the
building for which a building permit has been issued. Use of the village water
supply for other purposes not directly related to construction of the building,
watering of landscape and filling of swimming pools shall be prohibited.
Unmetered water usage shall cease when a water meter is installed for the site.
   C.   Permit And Fee: Upon payment of a fee established by resolution of the
village board, a permit for the use of water during construction will be
issued. Such permit shall be valid for ninety (90) days and shall be
prominently displayed with the building permit.
   D.   Penalty: Any owner or contractor who violates this section shall be
punishable as provided in section
4-8B-9-900 of this chapter. Each day in which any violation shall continue
shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-3-335: BILLS FOR SERVICE; PENALTY FOR DELINQUENCIES:
Bills for water service shall be dated and sent on a bimonthly basis. Such
bills shall be due and payable not later than twenty five (25) days thereafter.
After said twenty five (25) day period, a penalty of ten percent (10%) of the
amount of the bill shall be collected as part of said bill. For convenience in
billing, the village may be divided into districts, with a different bimonthly
billing period for each district. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-3-340: NONPAYMENT OF BILLS; DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE:
The water supply may be shut off from any premises for which the bill remains
unpaid twenty five (25) days after the due date; provided, however, that prior
to such shutoff, a written notice shall be mailed or delivered to the person(s)
liable for such bill. Such notice shall advise them of their right to file a
written objection with the village within ten (10) days of the date of the
notice and that such objection shall include the reason for their objection to
such action. If no objection is filed and the bill is not paid, the water
service shall be shut off. If an objection is filed, the water shall not be
shut off until the village administrator has reviewed the objection, considered
the facts and made a decision on the basis of the information available. When
the water supply has been shut off from a premises, the "shutoff/reconnection"
fee shall be added to the amount owed and must be paid prior to the turning on
of the water supply. An additional "after hours" fee shall be charged if the
village is requested to restore service outside normal working hours which, for
the purpose of this section, are defined as Monday through Friday (except
holidays) from eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to four o'clock (4:00) P.M. In
addition to any reconnection fee required herein, if the water supply to any
premises was shut off due to nonpayment, prior to reconnection, the village may
require a cash deposit in an amount equal to the average bill for the last four
(4) months. Fees required by this section shall be established by resolution of
the village board. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-3-345: LIEN FOR UNPAID BILLS; FORECLOSURE:
   A.   Claim For Lien:
      1.   Whenever a bill for water service remains unpaid thirty (30) days
after it has been shut off, the village administrator shall file with the
county recorder of deeds of Cook County a statement of lien claim. This
statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the
amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the village claims a lien for this
amount as well as for all charges for water served subsequent to the period
covered by the proper village officials, as provided by law.
      2.   If the consumer of water whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of
the premises, and the village administrator has notice of this, notice shall be
mailed to the owner of the premises, if his address is known to the
administrator, whenever such bill remains unpaid for a period of thirty (30)
days after it is due.
      3.   The failure of the village administrator to record such lien claim
or to mail such notice or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall
not affect the right to collect the unpaid water bill.
   B.   Foreclosure Of Lien:
      1.   Property subject to a lien for unpaid water charges shall be sold
for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to
pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure, of
statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by bill in equity in the name of the
village.
      2.   The village attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute
such proceedings, in the name of the village, in any court having jurisdiction
over such matters, against any property for which the bill for water has
remained unpaid thirty (30) days after it has been rendered. (Ord. 0-2007-815,
5-10-2007)
4-8B-3-350: REVIEW OF RATES; REVISIONS:
The adequacy of the water service charge shall be reviewed periodically. The
water service charge shall be revised periodically to reflect changes in debt
service or in operation and maintenance costs, including replacement costs.
(Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-3-355: DISPOSITION AND ADMINISTRATION OF REVENUES:
The village treasurer shall receive all revenues from the water user service
charges and all other funds and monies incident to the operation of such system
as the same may be delivered to him and deposit the same in the account of the
fund designated as the "water fund" of the village of South Barrington. The
village treasurer shall administer such fund in every respect in the manner as
provided in the Illinois municipal code and the ordinances and policies of the
village. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-3-360: ACCOUNTS AND RECORDS:
   A.   System Of Accounts And Records: The village treasurer shall establish a
proper system of accounts and shall keep proper books, records, and accounts in
which complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative
to the water system and, at regular annual intervals, shall cause to be made an
audit by an independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and
disbursements of the water system. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-4: NONDOMESTIC WATER USE; BULK DELIVERIES:
4-8B-4-400: APPLICATION FOR TEMPORARY HOOKUP:
   A.   Applications Generally: Every purchaser of bulk amounts of water for
nondomestic purposes such as swimming pools, ice rinks or other purposes
requiring delivery of large quantities of water shall apply to the village
engineer to arrange for a temporary hookup to the village water system. In such
application, the purchaser shall specify the specific date and time at which
the temporary connection service is requested. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-4-405: RESPONSIBILITY TO PROVIDE EQUIPMENT:
The purchaser may obtain water from a hydrant at the water treatment site. The
purchaser shall provide the necessary vehicle, in which case, to transport the
water from such hydrant to the desired site. The village shall not be
responsible for quality and cleanliness of the water beyond the point of
delivery into whatever vehicle provided by the purchaser. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-
10-2007)
4-8B-4-410: SUPERVISION OF TEMPORARY CONNECTIONS:
All temporary connections to fire hydrants for the purposes of supplying bulk
amounts of water for nondomestic use shall be made under the supervision of the
village engineer, and he shall determine which hydrant shall be used for such
temporary connection. Only village personnel shall be permitted to operate fire
hydrants or to make hookups for such purposes. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007)
4-8B-4-415: WATER RATES AND CHARGES FOR NONDOMESTIC PURPOSES:
   A.   Rates Established:
      1.   Purchasers That Are Water System Users: Purchasers receiving water
service from the Village shall be charged for the actual amount of water used
at the current rate applicable to their property as established by this code.
An additional service fee shall be established by the Village Board for the
cost of the temporary hookup. The charges shall be added to the users regular
water billing.
      2.   Purchasers Not Water System Users: Purchasers not receiving water
service from the Village shall be charged two hundred percent (200%) of the
current rate established for the actual amount of water used. An additional
service fee shall be established by the Village Board for the cost of the
temporary hookup. Purchasers not receiving water service from the Village shall
deposit in cash with the Village an amount equal to two hundred percent (200%)
of the estimated charges. The balance, if any, shall be returned to the
purchaser upon determination of the final bill.
   B.   Determination Of Water Used: The actual amount of water used shall be
determined by the use of a water meter connected to the fire hydrant, to be
furnished and installed by the Village. The purchaser shall post a deposit for
the use of the water meter.
   C.   Additional Charges: The purchaser will be billed for any overtime
salaries that must be paid to Village personnel by a request for a temporary
hookup at a time outside of regular working hours. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-2007;
amd. Ord. O-2022-1308, 2-17-2022)
4-8B-5: LIMITATION ON THE USE OF WATER:
4-8B-5-500: PURPOSES:
   A.   The Village of South Barrington desires to be a good steward of our
natural resources and encourage water conservation to all residents;
   B.   The Village of South Barrington municipal water system has developed
extensive storage, pumping and pipeline systems to distribute potable water to
the areas served by the Village water system;
   C.   The Village is located in a climate where drought like conditions
periodically occur;
   D.   High demand, together with drought-like conditions and/or system
constraints, may reduce the available water in local storage to the point of
creating a water shortage;
   E.   The Village finds that it may from time to time be necessary to
implement measures to restrict water use as deemed appropriate to conserve the
water supply of the Village to protect the health, safety and general welfare
of the areas served by the Village water system during periods of potential
water shortage and to promote conservation of water. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-10-
2007; amd. Ord. O-2022-1308, 2-17-2022)
4-8B-5-510: OUTDOOR WATER USE LIMITATIONS DURING DROUGHT OR WATER EMERGENCY:
In order to promote good resource conservation practices and to preserve
potable water supplies during abnormally dry to drought conditions, the use of
the Village's potable water for outdoor watering of landscaping and lawns may
be limited. The Village President may establish limitations on the outdoor
watering of landscaping and lawns until such time that the abnormally dry to
drought water conditions have resolved. Failure to comply with the water
restrictions shall be a violation of this chapter and subject to penalty. (Ord.
0-2007-815, 5-10-2007; amd. Ord. O-2022-1308, 2-17-2022)
4-8B-5-515: SOD INSTALLATION:
The installation of sod within the Village between June 15 and September 15 is
discouraged. The use of the Village's potable water supply for watering of sod
during a drought or water emergency shall be prohibited. (Ord. 0-2007-815, 5-
10-2007; amd. Ord. O-2022-1308, 2-17-2022)

4-8B-9: PENALTY:
4-8B-9-900: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person, household, firm or corporation who violates or assists in the
violation of any provision of this chapter shall be deemed to have committed a
business offense and shall be fined as hereinafter provided for each such
violation. The maximum fine shall be one thousand five hundred ($1,500.00)
dollars. Each day on which, or during which, a violation occurs shall
constitute a separate offense. In addition to any fine imposed, a person,
household, firm or corporation found to be in violation of this section shall
be responsible for any and all responsive costs incurred to investigate such
violation.
The fines imposed pursuant to a violation under this chapter shall be as
follows:
   A.   For violations of
4-8B-510 Outdoor Watering Restrictions, the first violation shall be punishable
by a fine of no less than one hundred ($100.00) dollars. A second violation by
the same person, household, firm or corporation within a twelve (12) month
period shall be punishable by a fine of no less than three hundred ($300.00)
dollars. A third or subsequent violation by the same person, household, firm or
corporation within a twelve (12) month period shall be punishable by a fine of
no less than five hundred ($500.00) dollars.
   B.   For all other violations under this chapter; the first violation shall
be punishable by a fine of no less than five hundred ($500.00) dollars. A
second violation by the same person, household, firm or corporation, within a
twelve (12) month period shall be punishable by a fine of no less than one
thousand ($1,000.00) dollars. The third or subsequent violation by the same
person, household, firm or corporation, within a twelve (12) month period shall
be punishable by a fine of no less than one thousand five hundred ($1,500.00)
dollars.
   C.   Each day on which a violation continues or persists shall be deemed a
separate offense. The village engineer, code enforcement officer or designee
may issue violation notices for violations of this chapter. (Ord. 0-2017-1165,
10-12-2017; amd. Ord. O-2022-1308, 2-17-2022)
CHAPTER 8C
CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL
SECTION:
4-8C-100: Purpose
4-8C-105: Application Of Provisions
4-8C-110: Village Policy
4-8C-115: Definitions
4-8C-120: Water System Described
4-8C-125: Illinois Plumbing Code (Part) Adopted
4-8C-130: Cross Connections Restricted
4-8C-140: Surveys And Inspections

4-8C-150: Booster Pumps
4-8C-155: Violations And Enforcement
4-8C-160: Liability For Cleanup
4-8C-165: Penalty
4-8C-100: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is as follows:
   A.   To protect the public water supply system from contamination or
pollution by isolating within the customer's water system contaminants or
pollutants which would backflow through the service connection into the public
water supply systems.
   B.   To promote the elimination or control of existing cross connections,
actual or potential, between the public or consumer's potable water system and
nonpotable water systems, plumbing fixtures and sources or systems containing
substances of unknown or questionable safety.
   C.   To provide for the maintenance of a continuing program of cross
connection control which will prevent the contamination or pollution of the
public's and consumer's potable water systems. (Ord. 0-2007-816, 5-10-2007)
4-8C-105: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
This chapter shall apply to all premises served by the public potable water
supply system of the village. (Ord. 0-2007-816, 5-10-2007)
4-8C-110: VILLAGE POLICY:
The village engineer shall be responsible for protection of the public water
supply system from contamination due to backflow or backsiphonage of
contaminants through the customer's water service connection. The village
engineer shall be responsible for causing surveys and investigations to be made
of industrial and other nonresidential accounts served by the public water
supply to determine whether actual or potential hazards to the public water
supply may exist. Such surveys and investigations shall be made a matter of
public record and shall be repeated at least every two (2) years, or as often
as the village engineer shall deem necessary. Records of such surveys shall be
maintained and available for review for a period of at least five (5) years.
The installation of an approved backflow prevention device is necessary for the
safety of the public water supply system. The village engineer shall give
notice to the consumer to install such approved backflow prevention device at
each service connection immediately beyond the water meter. The consumer shall
immediately install such approved device or devices at the consumer's own
expense. Failure, refusal or inability on the part of the consumer to install
such device or devices shall constitute grounds for discontinuing water service
to the premises until such device or devices have been installed. The consumer
shall retain records of installation, maintenance, testing and repair as
required in subsection 4-8C-145B of this chapter for a period of at least five
(5) years. (Ord. 0-2007-816, 5-10-2007)
4-8C-115: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply to the interpretation and enforcement of
this chapter:
ASSE: American Society of Sanitary Engineering.
AGENCY: Illinois environmental protection agency.
AIR GAP: The air gap in a water supply system is the unobstructed vertical
distance through the free atmosphere between the lowest opening from any pipe
or faucet supplying water to a tank or plumbing fixture and the flood level rim
of the receptacle.
APPROVED: Accepted or acceptable under an applicable specification stated or
cited in this chapter or accepted as suitable for the proposed use.
AUXILIARY WATER SYSTEM: Any water source or system on or available to the
premises other than the public water supply system. These auxiliary waters may
include water from another purveyor's public water supply system; fire
sprinkler connections or water from a source such as wells, lakes, ponds, or
streams, or process fluids; or used water. These waters may be polluted or
contaminated or objectionable or constitute a water source or system over which
the water purveyor does not have control.
BACKFLOW: The flow of water or other liquids, mixtures, or substances into the
distribution pipes of a potable water system from any source other than the
intended source of the potable water supply.
BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE: Any device, method, or type of construction
intended to prevent backflow or backsiphonage into a potable water system. All
devices used for backflow prevention in Illinois must meet the standards of the
Illinois plumbing code and the Illinois environmental protection agency.
BOOSTER PUMP: A mechanical device used to increase domestic water pressure.
CCDI: Cross connection control device inspector.
COMMUNITY WATER SYSTEM (CWS): A public water supply that is owned or operated
by the village of South Barrington.
CONSUMER OR CUSTOMER: The owner, official custodian or person in control of any
premises supplied by or in any manner connected to a public water system.
CONSUMER'S WATER SYSTEM: The service connection and any water system located on
the customer's premises. A building plumbing system is considered to be a
customer's water system with the exception of the water meter and its
connections.
CONTAMINATION: An impairment of the quality of the water by entrance of any
substance to a degree that could create a health hazard.
CROSS CONNECTION: Any physical connection or arrangement between two (2)
otherwise separate piping systems, one of which contains potable water and the
other a substance of unknown or questionable safety or quality, whereby there
may be a flow from one system into the other.
Direct Cross Connection: A cross connection formed when a water system is
physically joined to a source of unknown or unsafe substance.
Indirect Cross Connection: A cross connection through which an unknown
substance can be forced, drawn by a vacuum or otherwise introduced into a safe
potable water system.
DOUBLE CHECK VALVE ASSEMBLY: An assembly composed of single, independently
acting check valves under ASSE standard 1015. A "double check valve assembly"
must include tight shutoff valves located at each end of the assembly and
suitable connections for testing the water tightness of each check valve.
DRAINAGE: The routing of discharged used water from a reduced pressure
principle backflow preventer, due to the proper operation of the device,
pressure fluctuation, or malfunction of the device. Drainage shall be directed
to a gravity flow sanitary drain, or an ejection system which is rated to be
capable of meeting a full flow discharge from the device, or combination of
devices which may be present. This shall apply to all domestic, irrigation, and
fire prevention applications.
DUAL CHECK VALVE: An assembly composed of single, independently acting check
valves under ASSE standard 1024 for containment.
HEALTH HAZARD: Any condition, device or practice in a water system or its
operation resulting in a real or potential danger to the health and well being
of consumers. The word "severe", as used to qualify health hazard, means a
hazard to the health of the user that could be expected to result in death or
significant reduction in the quality of life.
INSPECTION: A physical inspection to examine carefully and critically all
materials, fixtures, piping and appurtenances, appliances and installations of
a plumbing system for compliance with requirements of the Illinois plumbing
code, 77 Illinois administrative code section 890.
NONCOMMUNITY WATER SYSTEM (NONCWS): A public water supply that is not a
community water supply.
NONPOTABLE WATER: Water not safe for drinking, personal, or culinary use as
determined by the requirements of 35 Illinois administrative code section 604.
PLUMBING: The actual installation, repair, maintenance, alteration or extension
of a plumbing system by any person. "Plumbing" includes all piping, fixtures,
appurtenances and appliances for a supply of water for all purposes, including,
without limitation, lawn sprinkler systems, from the source of a private water
supply on the premises or from the main in the street, alley or at the curb to,
within and about any building or buildings where a person or persons live, work
or assemble. "Plumbing" includes all piping, fixtures, appurtenances, and
appliances for a building drain and a sanitary drainage and related ventilation
system of any building or buildings where a person or persons live, work or
assemble from the point of connection of such building drain to the building's
sanitary sewer or private sewage disposal system for a distance of ten feet
(10') beyond the foundation walls.
POLLUTION: The presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic,
radiological, or biological) in water that tends to degrade its quality so as
to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness of the water.
POTABLE WATER: Water which meets the requirements of 35 Illinois administrative
code section 604 for drinking, culinary and domestic purposes.
POTENTIAL CROSS CONNECTION: A fixture or appurtenance with threaded hose
connection, tapered spout, or other connection which would facilitate extension
of the water supply line beyond its designed termination point.
PROCESS FLUID(S): Any fluid or solution which may be chemically, biologically
or otherwise contaminated or polluted in a form or concentration such as would
constitute a health, pollution, or system hazard if introduced into the public
or a customer's potable water system. This includes, but is not limited to:
   A.   Polluted or contaminated waters.
   B.   Process waters.
   C.   Used waters originating from the public water supply system that may
have deteriorated in sanitary quality.
   D.   Cooling waters.
   E.   Questionable or contaminated natural waters taken from wells, lakes,
streams, or irrigation systems.
   F.   Chemicals in solution or suspension.
   G.   Oils, gases, acids, alkalis and other liquid and gaseous fluids used in
industrial or other processes, or for firefighting purposes.
PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY (PWS): All mains, pipes, water meters, and structures
through which water is obtained and distributed to the public, including wells
and well structures, intakes and cribs, pumping stations, treatment plants,
reservoirs, storage tanks, water meters and appurtenances, collectively or
severally, actually used or intended for use for the purpose of furnishing
water for drinking or general domestic use and which serve at least fifteen
(15) service connections or which regularly serve at least twenty five (25)
persons at least sixty (60) days per year. A "public water supply" is either a
community water supply or a noncommunity water supply.
REDUCED PRESSURE PRINCIPLE BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE: A device containing a
minimum of two (2) independently acting check valves together with an
automatically operated pressure differential relief valve located between the
two (2) check valves and approved under ASSE standard 1013. During normal flow
and at the cessation of normal flow, the pressure between these two (2) checks
shall be less than the supply pressure. In case of leakage of either check
valve, the differential relief valve, by discharging to the atmosphere, shall
operate to maintain the pressure between the check valves at less than the
supply pressure. The unit must include tightly closing shutoff valves located
at each end of the device, and shall be fitted with properly located test
cocks.
SERVICE CONNECTION: The opening, including all fittings and appurtenances, at
the water main through which water is supplied to the user.
SURVEY: The collection of information pertaining to a customer's piping systems
regarding the location of all connections to the public water supply system and
must include the location, type and most recent inspection and testing date of
all cross connection control devices and methods located within that customer's
piping system. The survey must be in written form, and shall not be an actual
plumbing inspection.
SYSTEM HAZARD: A condition through which an aesthetically objectionable or
degrading material not dangerous to health may enter the public water supply
system or a consumer's potable water system.
THERMAL EXPANSION: A condition which occurs in a domestic water system, where a
backflow preventer has been installed, creating a closed water system. Thermal
expansion occurs when the cold water supplied to the hot water tank is heated.
The expansion of the water caused by heat creates a need for the displacement
of the expanded properties of the water. This is accomplished by installing a
diaphragmed thermal expansion tank device, which displaces the expanded volume
of water, keeping the internal piping system safe from extreme internal
pressures.
USED WATER: Any water supplied by a public water supply system to a consumer's
water system after it has passed through the service connection and is no
longer under the control of the water supply official custodian.
VILLAGE: Village of South Barrington.
VILLAGE ENGINEER: The South Barrington village engineer or another individual
designated by the village.
WATER PURVEYOR: The owner or official custodian of a public water system. (Ord.
0-2007-816, 5-10-2007)
4-8C-120: WATER SYSTEM DESCRIBED:
The water system shall be considered as made up of two (2) parts: the public
water supply system and the consumer's water system.
   A.   Public Water System:
      1.   The public water supply system shall consist of the source
facilities and the distribution system and shall include all those facilities
of the potable water system under the control of the village engineer up to the
point where the consumer's water system begins.
      2.   The source shall include all components of the facilities utilized
in the production, treatment, storage, and delivery of water to the public
water supply distribution system.
      3.   The public water supply distribution system shall include the
network of conduits used to deliver water from the source to the consumer's
water system.
   B.   Consumer's Water System: The consumer's water system shall include all
parts of the facilities, including the service connection, used to convey water
from the public water supply distribution system to points of use. (Ord. 0-
2007-816, 5-10-2007)
4-8C-125: ILLINOIS PLUMBING CODE (PART) ADOPTED:
Subpart I of December 1993 Illinois plumbing code is hereby adopted hereto and
by this reference incorporated herein and made a part hereof. Copies of the
Illinois plumbing code are on file in the office of the village clerk for
public use and inspection. (Ord. 0-2007-816, 5-10-2007)
4-8C-130: CROSS CONNECTIONS RESTRICTED:
   A.   Connections between the village water system and other systems or
equipment containing water or other substances of unknown or questionable
quality are prohibited except when and where approved cross connection control
devices or methods are installed, tested, and maintained to ensure proper
operation on a continuing basis.
   B.   No physical connection shall be permitted between the potable portion
of a supply not of equal or better bacteriological and chemical quality as
determined by inspection and analysis by the agency. Control of all cross
connections to a supply is the responsibility of the owner or official
custodian of the supply. If a privately owned water supply source meets the
applicable criteria, it may be connected to a water supply upon approval by the
owner or official custodian and by the agency. Where such connections are
permitted, it is the responsibility of the public water supply officials to
assure submission from such privately owned water supply source or sources
samples and operating reports as required by 35 Illinois administrative code
sections 605 and 606 as applicable to the cross connected source.
   C.   No person, firm, or corporation shall establish or permit to be
established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a
private, auxiliary or emergency water supply, other than the regular public
water supply of the village, may enter the supply or distribution system of the
village unless such private auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method
of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by the village
engineer and the Illinois environmental protection agency. (Ord. 0-2007-816, 5-
10-2007)
4-8C-140: SURVEYS AND INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Surveys: Upon request by the village engineer or designee, the consumer
shall furnish written survey documentation regarding the piping system or
systems or water use within the customer's premises. The refusal to provide
requested information shall, within the discretion of the village engineer, be
deemed evidence of the presence of improper connections as provided in this
chapter.
   B.   Inspections: It shall be the responsibility of the water consumer, upon
the request from the village engineer or his designee, to arrange for a
physical inspection, at his cost, of water use practices on the consumer's
premises to determine whether there are actual or potential cross connections
to the water system through which contaminants or pollutants could backflow
into the consumer's or the public potable water system. The physical inspection
shall confirm that all installations of the backflow devices are installed per
manufacturer specifications and as provided in this chapter. All maintenance,
repair, and testing records must be available and current during inspection.
All cross connection control or other plumbing inspections must be conducted by
licensed plumbers as provided in 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 320/3(1).
   C.   Access And Verification: The consumer's premises shall be open at all
reasonable times to the approved cross connection control device inspector or
the village engineer or his designee for verification of the written survey and
of physical inspection information, in regard to the presence or absence of
cross connections within the consumer's premises, and testing, repair and
maintenance of cross connection control devices within the consumer's premises.
(Ord. 0-2007-816, 5-10-2007)
4-8C-145: BACKFLOW PREVENTION:
   A.   Responsibilities Of Consumer: It is the responsibility of the water
consumer to prevent backflow into the public water system by ensuring that:
      1.   All cross connections are removed; or approved cross connection
control devices are installed for control of backflow and backsiphonage.
      2.   Cross connection control devices shall be installed in accordance
with the manufacturer's instructions.
      3.   Cross connection control devices shall be inspected at the time of
installation and at least annually by a person approved by the agency as a
cross connection control device inspector (CCCDI). The inspection of mechanical
devices shall include physical testing in accordance with the manufacturer's
instructions.
      4.   In new constructions, a properly sized floor drain shall be required
for the discharge from the reduced pressure principle backflow prevention
device.
      5.   Thermal expansion is required on all domestic water services
protected by cross connection control devices. Protection from thermal
expansion shall incorporate properly sized thermal expansion tanks, properly
placed within the system, at the hot water tank.
      6.   All outside hose bibs shall be an antisiphon type.
   B.   Certification And Maintenance Of Devices:
      1.   It shall be the duty of the consumer at any premises on which
backflow prevention devices are required by this chapter to ensure that the
backflow protection devices are installed and have inspections, tests,
maintenance and repairs made in accordance with the following schedule or more
often where inspections indicate a need or are specified in the manufacturer's
instructions:
         a.   Fixed proper air gap separations shall be inspected to document
that a proper vertical distance is maintained between the discharge point of
the service line and the flood level rim of the receptacle at the time of
installation and at least annually thereafter.
         b.   Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention devices shall be
tested at the time of installation and at least annually or more frequently if
recommended by the manufacturer, and required service performed prior to
certification expiration.
      2.   Testing shall be performed by a person who has been approved by the
agency as competent to service the device. Proof of approval shall be in
writing.
      3.   Each device shall have a tag attached listing the date of most
recent test or visual inspection, name of tester, and type and date of repairs.
      4.   The owner of the premises shall maintain a maintenance log which
shall include testing and records as follows:
         a.   Each cross connection control device shall be tested at the time
of installation and at least annually or more frequently, if recommended by the
manufacturer.
         b.   Maintenance records shall be available for inspection by the
agency or the village engineer or his designee at any time.
         c.   Each cross connection control device shall have a tag attached
listing the date of most recent test, testing company, name of CCCDI, approval
number and type and date of repair.
         d.   A maintenance log shall be maintained and include:
            (1)   Date of each test or visual inspection.
            (2)   Company name, approval number, and name of person performing
the test.
            (3)   Test results.
            (4)   Repairs or servicing required.
            (5)   Repairs and date completed.
            (6)   Servicing performed and date completed.
      5.   Whenever backflow prevention devices required by this chapter are
found to be defective, they shall be repaired or replaced at the expense of the
consumer within ten (10) days of notification, or sooner, if required by the
village engineer or his designee. The village engineer or his designee may
immediately disconnect water service if deemed that a public health hazard
exists because of a cross connection.
      6.   Backflow prevention devices shall not be bypassed, made inoperative,
removed, or otherwise made ineffective without specific written authorization
by the village engineer.
   C.   Where Protection Required:
      1.   An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on
connections to the public water supply as described in the plumbing code, 77
Illinois administrative code section 890, and the agency's regulations, 35
Illinois administrative code section 653. In addition, an approved backflow
prevention device shall be installed on each service line to a consumer's water
system serving premises where, in the judgment of the village engineer, actual
or potential hazards to the public water supply system exist.
      2.   An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on each
service line to a consumer's water system serving premises where the following
conditions exist:
         a.   Premises having an auxiliary water supply, unless such auxiliary
supply is accepted as an additional source by the village engineer, and the
source is approved by the Illinois environmental protection agency.
         b.   Premises on which any substance is handled which can create an
actual or potential hazard to the public water supply system. This shall
include premises having sources or systems containing process fluids or waters
originating from the public water supply system that are no longer under the
sanitary control of the village engineer.
         c.   Premises having internal cross connections that, in the judgment
of the village engineer and the cross connection control device inspector, are
not correctable or contain intricate plumbing arrangements which make it
impractical to determine whether or not cross connections exist.
         d.   Premises where, because of security requirements or other
prohibitions or restrictions, it is impossible or impractical to make a
complete cross connection survey.
         e.   Premises having a repeated history of cross connections being
established or reestablished.
         f.   Premises that have a fire sprinkler system where "potable" water
is supplied by the village.
      3.   In addition, an approved backflow prevention device shall be
installed on each service line to a consumer's water system serving, but not
necessarily limited to, the following types of facilities: Any premises used
for residential purposes where, in the judgment of the village engineer, actual
or potential hazards to the public water supply system exist.
         a.   All premises used for nonresidential purposes including, but not
limited to, all commercial uses, office, retail, manufacturing, storage,
agricultural, industrial, educational or governmental.
         b.   Piers, docks, waterfront facilities.
         c.   Pools.
         d.   Irrigation systems.
   D.   Type Of Protection Required:
      1.   The type of protection required under this section shall depend on
the degree of hazard which exists, based upon the determination of the village
engineer, as follows:
         a.   An approved fixed proper air gap separation shall be installed
where the public water supply system may be contaminated with a substance that
could cause a severe health hazard.
         b.   An approved fixed proper air gap separation or an approved
reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device shall be installed where
the public water supply system may be contaminated with a substance that could
cause a system or health hazard.
         c.   An approved fixed proper air gap separation or an approved
reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device shall be installed where
the public water supply system may be polluted with substances that could cause
a pollution hazard not dangerous to health.
      2.   Where a public water supply or an auxiliary water supply is used for
a fire protection system, reduced pressure principle backflow preventers shall
be installed on the fire safety system connected to the public water supply
when:
         a.   The fire safety system contains antifreeze, fire retardant, or
other chemicals;
         b.   Water is pumped into the system from another source;
         c.   Water flows by gravity from a nonpotable source; or water can be
pumped into the fire safety system from any other source; or
         d.   There is a connection whereby another source can be connected to
the fire sprinkler system.
      3.   The type of protection required by this section shall be determined
by the village engineer. Installation standards shall be determined by the
village engineer in accordance with this chapter, Illinois Compiled Statutes
and the Illinois administrative code. Such installations shall be inspected by
the village engineer prior to the turnon of water from the village water
supply.
   E.   Backflow Prevention Devices:
      1.   Approval Required: All backflow prevention devices or methods
required by this chapter shall be approved by American Society of Sanitary
Engineering, and may carry the following additional endorsements: the Research
Foundation for Cross Connection Control of the University of Southern
California, American Water Works Association, or American National Standards
Institute or certified by the National Sanitation Foundation to be in
compliance with applicable industry specification.
      2.   Installation And Maintenance: Installation of approved devices shall
be made in accordance with 35 Illinois administrative code section 653.802, and
only as specified by the Research Foundation for Cross Connection Control of
the University of Southern California or applicable industry specifications.
Maintenance as recommended by the manufacturer of the device shall be
performed. Manufacturer's maintenance manual shall be available on site. (Ord.
0-2007-816, 5-10-2007)
4-8C-150: BOOSTER PUMPS:
   A.   Where a booster pump has been installed on the service line to or
within any premises, such pump shall be equipped with a low pressure cutoff
device designed to shut off the booster pump when the pressure in the service
line on the suction side of the pump drops to twenty (20) psi or less.
   B.   It shall be the duty of the water consumer to maintain the low pressure
cutoff device in proper working order and to certify to the village engineer,
at least once each year, that the device is operable. (Ord. 0-2007-816, 5-10-
2007)
4-8C-155: VIOLATIONS AND ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Discontinuance Of Water Service: The village engineer shall deny or
discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupants thereof, the water
service to any premises wherein any backflow prevention device required by this
chapter is not installed, tested, maintained, repaired and inspected in a
manner acceptable to the village engineer, or if it is found that the backflow
prevention device has been removed or bypassed, or if an unprotected cross
connection exists on the premises, or if a low pressure cutoff device required
by this chapter is not installed and maintained in working order. Immediate
disconnection upon oral or written notice can be effected when the village
engineer is assured that imminent danger of contamination of the public water
supply system exists. Such action shall be followed by written notification of
the cause of disconnection. Immediate disconnection without notice to any party
can be effected to prevent actual or anticipated contamination or pollution of
