the public water supply; provided, that in the reasonable opinion of the
village engineer or the Illinois environmental protection agency, such action
is required to prevent actual or potential contamination or pollution of the
public water supply. Neither the village nor the village engineer, or their
agents or assigns, shall be liable to any customer for any injury, damages or
lost revenues which may result from termination of said customer's water supply
in accordance with the terms of this chapter, whether or not said termination
was with or without notice.
   B.   Restoration Of Water Service: Water service to such premises shall not
be restored until the regulations and to the satisfaction of the village
engineer, and the required reconnection fee of one thousand five hundred
dollars ($1,500.00) is paid to the village. (Ord. 0-2007-816, 5-10-2007)
4-8C-160: LIABILITY FOR CLEANUP:
The consumer is responsible for backsiphoned material or contamination through
backflow. Should contamination of the potable water supply system occur through
an illegal cross connection or by an improperly installed, maintained or
repaired device, or a device which has been bypassed, the owner of the premises
shall bear the cost of cleanup of any contamination of the public water supply
and any repairs required to clean the potable water supply system. (Ord. 0-
2007-816, 5-10-2007)
4-8C-165: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any portion of this chapter shall be
fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. Each day on which a
violation continues or persists shall be deemed a separate offense. The village
engineer or his designee may issue violation notices of this chapter. (Ord. 0-
2007-816, 5-10-2007)
CHAPTER 9
INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLES
SECTION:
4-9-1: Definition Of Inoperable Motor Vehicle
4-9-2: Exterior Storage Prohibited
4-9-3: Penalties
4-9-4: Procedure On Nonpayment
4-9-1: DEFINITION OF INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE:
For the purposes of this Chapter, an "inoperable motor vehicle" is defined to
mean any motor vehicle from which, for a period of at least thirty (30) days,
the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed or on which the engine,
wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or otherwise so treated that
the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its own motor power. (Ord. 0-78-
108, 8-10-1978)
4-9-2: EXTERIOR STORAGE PROHIBITED:
No person in charge of or in control of premises, whether as owner, lessee,
tenant, occupant or otherwise, shall allow an inoperable motor vehicle to
remain on such property longer than ten (10) days; and no person shall leave
any such vehicle on any property within the Village for a longer time than ten
(10) days; except, that this Section shall not apply with regard to any vehicle
in an enclosed building or so located upon the premises as not to be readily
visible from any public place or from any surrounding private property. This
Section shall further not apply with regard to any vehicle on the premises of a
business enterprise operated in a lawful place, other than in a residential
district, and operated in a lawful manner, when the keeping or maintenance of
such vehicle is necessary to the operation of such business enterprise; or with
regard to a vehicle in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained in
a lawful place and manner by the Village or any other public agency or entity.
(Ord. 0-78-108, 8-10-78)
4-9-3: PENALTIES:
The penalty for the violation of any section of this Chapter shall be not less
than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00);
provided, however, that in the event that the owner or operator makes payment
to the Village within fourteen (14) calendar days after the date of the
personal issuance of or the issuance of a hang-on ticket, the penalty shall be
twenty five dollars ($25.00) for such violation. In the further event that the
owner or operator does not make payment within the initial fourteen (14) day
period as specified herein, but does make payment within a period of time as
specified in a final notice, the penalty shall be thirty five dollars ($35.00)
for such violation. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day a
violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 0-89-341, 9-14-89)
4-9-4: PROCEDURE ON NONPAYMENT:
In the event that the person to whom a citation is issued pursuant to this
Chapter fails to settle and pay said violation within the prescribed time, or
within a period of time specified in a final notice, then the police officer or
the designated Village employee is authorized to cause a notice to appear to be
served upon said alleged violator by personal service or certified mail, return
receipt requested, and is authorized to file a complaint and to prosecute the
same in the circuit court of the appropriate county. (Ord. 0-89-341, 9-14-89)
CHAPTER 10
VACANT LOT PROTECTION DURING CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES
SECTION:
4-10-1: Adoption of Preamble
4-10-2: Activities Prohibited on Vacant Lots or Properties
4-10-3: Protective Barrier Required
4-10-4: Violation Prohibited
4-10-5: Penalty for Violation
4-10-1: ADOPTION OF PREAMBLE:
The President and Board of Trustees hereby find that the facts stated in the
preamble to Ordinance 0-91-389 are true and correct and hereby adopt the same
as part of this Chapter. (Ord. 0-91-389, 8-8-91)
4-10-2: ACTIVITIES PROHIBITED ON VACANT LOTS OR PROPERTIES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to perform any one or more of the following
activities on vacant lots or properties:
   A.   Direct driver(s) of automobiles or construction related vehicles to
drive on any portion of vacant lots or properties for the purpose of gaining
access to or from another lot or property.
   B.   Drive automobiles or construction related vehicles on any portion of
vacant lots or properties for the purpose of gaining access to or from another
lot or property.
   C.   Park automobiles or construction related vehicles on any portion of
vacant lots or properties when such automobiles or vehicles are not engaged in
permitted activities on the lot on which they are parked.
   D.   Stockpile construction materials on any portion of vacant lots or
properties when such materials are not intended to be used for the lot on which
they are stockpiled. (Ord. 0-91-389, 8-8-91)
4-10-3: PROTECTIVE BARRIER REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to initiate construction activities for
which a building permit is required to be obtained from the Village without
first having installed a temporary protective barrier along the entire length
of any property line which adjoins vacant lots or properties. Such protective
barrier shall consist of wooden snow fencing supported by metal fence posts
driven into the ground at intervals not to exceed fifty feet (50'), or other
barrier material specifically approved by the Building Officer. The protective
barrier shall remain in place, in a complete and effective manner, for the
duration of the construction process, up to and including the date of the final
inspection. (Ord. 0-91-389, 8-8-91)
4-10-4: VIOLATION PROHIBITED:
Written and/or verbal permission from the owner(s) of adjacent vacant lots or
properties shall not permit any person to violate the provisions contained in
Section
4-10-1 through Section
4-10-3 of this Chapter. (Ord. 0-91-389, 8-8-91)
4-10-5: PENALTY FOR VIOLATION:
   A.   Any person who violates any provisions of Section
4-10-2 above will be subject to a fine of not less than five hundred dollars
($500.00) nor more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for each offense; and
a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during which a
violation occurs or continues to exist.
   B.   If any person fails to install and/or maintain the protective barrier
as provided for in Section
4-10-3 above, a stop work order may be issued by the building officer until
such time as the necessary protection has been installed in accordance with
this Chapter. Violators shall also be subject to a fine of not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense;
and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during which a
violation occurs or continues to exist. (Ord. 0-91-389, 8-8-91)
CHAPTER 11
MUNICIPAL WASTE SYSTEM
SECTION:
4-11-1: Definitions
4-11-2: Findings
4-11-3: Required Use Of Municipal Waste System
4-11-4: Private Collectors And Haulers
4-11-5: Municipal Waste System Account; Rates And Charges
4-11-6: Penalty
4-11-1: DEFINITIONS:
AGENCY: The solid waste agency of northern Cook County.
MUNICIPAL WASTE SERVICE AGREEMENT: The agreement between the municipality and a
municipal waste service contractor to provide for the collection,
transportation and disposal services of system waste from residential dwellings
within the municipality.
MUNICIPAL WASTE SERVICE CONTRACTOR: The person designated by the municipal
waste service agreement to provide for the collection, transportation and
disposal services of system waste from residential dwellings within the
municipality.
MUNICIPAL WASTE SYSTEM: The waste collection, transportation and disposal
system of the municipality operated under license pursuant to section
4-11-4 of this chapter, including all physical assets of the municipality used
for the collection, transportation and disposal of system waste, all amounts on
deposit in the municipal waste system account and all amounts collected on
account of rates and charges imposed by the municipality.
MUNICIPALITY: The village of South Barrington.
PERSON: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association,
joint stock company, joint venture, or corporation, or a receiver, trustee,
conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court.
PROJECT USE AGREEMENT: The 1992 project use agreement by and between the
municipality and the agency, as amended, from time to time.
SYSTEM WASTE: A. Garbage and general household waste,
   B.   Institutional waste,
   C.   Commercial and office waste,
   D.   Industrial lunchroom waste, and
   E.   Construction and demolition waste discarded by persons located within
the municipality. (Ord. 2009-877, 3-12-2009)
4-11-2: FINDINGS:
The municipality finds as follows:
   A.   It is necessary for and in the best interests of the municipality to
regulate and control the collection, transportation and disposal of municipal
waste in the exercise of its police power in order to protect the health,
safety and welfare of its residents.
   B.   The municipality is authorized pursuant to article VII, section 6 of
the Illinois constitution, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-19-1 et seq., and
intergovernmental corporation act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 220/3.2 to
provide for the method or methods of collection, transportation and disposal of
municipal waste within its corporate limits and to provide that the method
chosen may be the exclusive method to be used within the corporate limits.
   C.   The municipality acting pursuant to article VII, section 10 of the
Illinois constitution and section 3.2 of the intergovernmental cooperation act
has entered into an intergovernmental agreement with twenty five (25) other
north and northwest suburban Cook County municipalities, thereby creating the
agency to provide an efficient and environmentally sound municipal waste
disposal system.
   D.   The municipality has entered into a project use agreement by which the
agency will acquire, construct, operate, equip and improve a municipal solid
waste project to provide for the disposal of system waste of the municipality
and other members of the agency.
   E.   Under the project use agreement, the municipality is obligated to
establish a municipal waste disposal system, to cause system waste collected
within its corporate limits to be delivered to the agency and to make certain
payments to the agency, all as described in the project use agreement.
   F.   It is necessary and in the best interests of the municipality to
provide for the environmentally sound and efficient collection, transportation
and disposal of system waste by creating a municipal waste system, by providing
for the disposal of system waste by delivery to the agency and to impose the
rates and charges provided for herein. (Ord. 0-92-402, 3-12-1992, eff. 5-1-
1995)
4-11-3: REQUIRED USE OF MUNICIPAL WASTE SYSTEM:
   A.   All persons owning or occupying real estate within the corporate limits
of the municipality shall dispose of system waste through the municipal waste
system. All system waste shall be collected by or on behalf of the municipality
pursuant to the terms of this chapter and shall be delivered to a transfer
station as directed by the agency and the municipality or as otherwise agreed
to by the agency and the municipality under the project use agreement.
   B.   No person shall dispose of system waste through the municipal waste
system unless the system waste complies with all the rules and regulations
applicable thereto and established, from time to time, by either the
municipality or the agency.
   C.   Any person disposing of system waste through the municipal waste system
shall pay the rates and charges established, from time to time, by the
municipality.
   D.   Owners, agents, tenants, or occupants of any residential dwelling must
secure waste collection service from the municipal waste service contractor
designated in the municipal waste service agreement.
   E.   Commercial and industrial waste may be collected by waste collectors
with no service agreement with the village. (Ord. 2009-877, 3-12-2009)
4-11-4: PRIVATE COLLECTORS AND HAULERS:
   A.   No person shall collect, transport or dispose of residential system
waste unless they are designated as the village's municipal waste service
contractor in the municipal waste service agreement.
   B.   No person shall collect, transport or dispose of nonresidential system
waste unless they are authorized and licensed in accordance with the laws of
the state of Illinois.
   C.   Nothing in this chapter is intended to impair any license or franchise
issued before the effective date of this chapter to any person which authorizes
the person to collect, transport and dispose of municipal waste which
constitutes system waste to a location other than the transfer station
designated by the agency and the municipality. (Ord. 2009-877, 3-12-2009)
4-11-5: MUNICIPAL WASTE SYSTEM ACCOUNT; RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.   Establishment: There is hereby created and established an account
within the general fund known as the municipal waste system account.
   B.   Adoption Of Budget:
      1.   Each fiscal year, the finance committee shall recommend and the
village board shall adopt a budget for the municipal waste system. The budget
shall estimate the revenue required to:
         a.   Pay all operating and maintenance expenses of the municipal waste
system, including all obligations to the agency under the project use
agreement.
         b.   Pay, as they become due, interest on and principal of any revenue
bonds or other obligations payable from the revenues of the municipal waste
system.
         c.   Provide for all unpaid claims.
         d.   Maintain appropriate depreciation and reserve funds, including
reserves for uncollected charges.
      2.   The budget shall estimate the amounts available to pay those
obligations from:
         a.   Rates and charges to be imposed on persons disposing of system
waste through the municipal waste system.
         b.   Other amounts to be credited to the municipal waste system
account.
   C.   Rates To Cover Obligations: The rates and charges imposed for use of
the municipal waste system shall be sufficient, after taking into account
monies then on hand in the municipal waste system account and the proceeds of
fees to be collected which have been assigned and pledged to the municipal
waste system:
      1.   To pay all operation and maintenance expenses of the municipal waste
system, including all obligations to the agency under the terms of the project
use agreement;
      2.   To pay as they become due, interest on, and principal of any revenue
bonds or other obligations payable from revenues of the municipal waste system;
      3.   To provide for all unpaid claims; and
      4.   To provide adequate depreciation and reserve funds for the municipal
waste system, including reserves for uncollected charges.
   D.   Rates Set By Municipality: Rates to be billed by the municipal waste
service contractor shall be as determined by the municipality in the municipal
waste service agreement.
   E.   Billing Of Property Owners: Municipal waste service contractor shall
bill owners and occupants of residential real estate within the municipality
served by the municipal waste system as agent for the municipality.
   F.   Liability For Charges: The owners and occupants of residential real
estate within the municipality served by the municipal waste system shall be
jointly and severally liable to pay all rates and charges imposed by the
municipality pursuant to the provisions of this section and the municipal waste
service agreement.
   G.   Delinquent Bills, Penalties: Penalties with respect to delinquent bills
shall be as determined, from time to time, by the municipality.
   H.   Collection Of Monies: All amounts collected from rates and charges
imposed under this section and due the municipality shall be credited to the
municipal waste system account. (Ord. 2009-877, 3-12-2009)
4-11-6: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than
twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for
each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day
during or on which such violation continues unabated after ten (10) days from
receipt of notice. (Ord. 0-92-402, 3-12-1992, eff. 5-1-1995)
CHAPTER 12
GARBAGE AND REFUSE
SECTION:
4-12-1: Refuse Container Required
4-12-2: Prohibited Acts And Conditions
4-12-3: Penalties
4-12-4: Severability
4-12-1: REFUSE CONTAINER REQUIRED:
Each occupant, tenant or person in possession of any residence, commercial
building, or office shall provide sufficient refuse containers for accumulation
of normal refuse. Every person in possession of any premises shall cause all
garbage and refuse brought into or produced therein to be disposed in the
appropriate container.
All refuse containers shall comply with the specifications provided by the
village's waste hauler. No other type of container shall be acceptable.
Unsanitary, leaking or defective receptacles or receptacles without covers
shall be cleaned, repaired or replaced by the owner or occupant at their
expense. All containers shall be cleaned as often as is necessary to maintain
them in a sanitary condition. (Ord. 2005-751, 9-8-2005)
4-12-2: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Scattering Of Matter: No person shall cast, place or deposit anywhere
within the village any substance, article or thing in such a manner that it or
any of them may be carried or deposited by the action of the sun, wind, rain,
snow, or animal into or upon any street, sidewalk, alley, sewer, parkway or
other public place, or upon any private premises.
   B.   Placement And Removal Of Curbside Garbage Collection Containers: No
garbage collection containers shall be placed at the curbside, adjacent street
or sidewalk area of any premises earlier than three o'clock (3:00) P.M. of the
day preceding the regularly scheduled garbage collection day. Any such
container shall be removed from the curbside, adjacent street or sidewalk area
of the premises no later than nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. of the day after the
regularly scheduled garbage collection day. At no time shall any garbage
collection container be placed upon any street or sidewalk so as to obstruct
vehicular or pedestrian traffic.
   C.   Waste Accumulated On The Premises Prohibited: The owner, lessee, or
occupant of any premises located within the village shall remove from said
premises, or otherwise dispose of, all garbage, rubbish and refuse, and shall
keep the premises free and clear of any accumulation of any such refuse. (Ord.
2005-751, 9-8-2005)
4-12-3: PENALTIES:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall be
fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) for a first offense, and fifty
dollars ($50.00) for each offense thereafter. Each day that a violation exists
shall constitute a separate offense. The South Barrington police department or
its authorized designee, is hereby authorized to issue any and all such
citations. (Ord. 2005-751, 9-8-2005)
4-12-4: SEVERABILITY:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this chapter
is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent
jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and
independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the
remaining portions hereof. (Ord. 2005-751, 9-8-2005)
CHAPTER 13
OUTDOOR STORAGE OF JUNK AND HOUSEHOLD GOODS
SECTION:
4-13-1: Storage Of Junk Prohibited
4-13-2: Outdoor Storage Of Household Goods Prohibited
4-13-3: Observance Of Violation
4-13-4: Notice Of Violation
4-13-5: Service Of Notice
4-13-6: Investigation
4-13-7: Abatement Of Nuisance
4-13-8: Penalties
4-13-1: STORAGE OF JUNK PROHIBITED:
   A.   Nuisance Declared: The storage of junk, trash and refuse on private
property is prohibited and declared a nuisance within the village of South
Barrington unless specifically authorized under the zoning ordinance.
   B.   Defined: "Junk, trash and refuse" are defined herein to include any and
all waste matter, whether reusable or not, which is offensive to the public
health, safety or the aesthetics of the neighborhood, and is specifically
intended to include, but not be limited to, the whole or parts of
nonfunctioning or wrecked or abandoned automobiles, trucks, tractors,
machinery, and appliances. (Ord. 2009-889, 10-8-2009)
4-13-2: OUTDOOR STORAGE OF HOUSEHOLD GOODS PROHIBITED:
   A.   Nuisance Declared: The outdoor storage of household goods on private
property is prohibited and declared a nuisance within the village of South
Barrington unless specifically authorized under the zoning ordinance.
   B.   Defined: "Household goods" are defined herein to include, but not be
limited to, lawn maintenance equipment and tools, bicycles, appliances, indoor
household furniture, vehicle parts, tools, clothing and building materials.
(Ord. 2009-889, 10-8-2009)
4-13-3: OBSERVANCE OF VIOLATION:
Any person who observes a violation of this chapter may file an affidavit with
the building department setting forth in detail the violation, its location,
and the name of the owner and occupant of the property on which such nuisance
is alleged. The building officer or authorized designee shall investigate such
charge, and if such nuisance exists, issue a notice of violation to the owner
or occupant of the property. (Ord. 2009-889, 10-8-2009)
4-13-4: NOTICE OF VIOLATION:
Upon observing any violation of this chapter, the building officer or
authorized designee shall issue a notice of violation directed to the owner of
record of the property on which such nuisance occurs, as shown in the records
of the recorder of deeds of Cook County, or to the occupant of such property,
or to both. The notice shall describe the violation and shall establish a
reasonable time limit for the abatement of the nuisance by the owner or
occupant. For the purposes of this chapter, a reasonable time shall be not less
than two (2) days or more than ten (10) days after service of the notice. (Ord.
2009-889, 10-8-2009)
4-13-5: SERVICE OF NOTICE:
The building officer or authorized designee shall serve the notice of violation
upon the owner or occupant of the property, or both. After service of the
notice, the building officer or authorized designee shall make a copy of the
notice, showing the time of service, the person that was served, and the manner
in which it was served. In the event that the owner or occupant cannot be found
by personal service, service may be made by attaching a copy of the notice upon
the property, and by mailing a copy by registered mail to the last known
address of the owner or occupant, or both. (Ord. 2009-889, 10-8-2009)
4-13-6: INVESTIGATION:
Immediately upon the termination of the time allowed in the notice to abate the
nuisance, the building officer or authorized designee shall investigate to
determine whether or not the nuisance has been abated. (Ord. 2009-889, 10-8-
2009)
4-13-7: ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE:
In the event the owner or occupant of the nuisance property fails to timely
abate the nuisance, then the village or the person who filed an affidavit with
the building department shall file a complaint in the circuit court of Cook
County to abate the nuisance and to punish the owner or occupant, or both, as
provided for in this chapter. The village may also adjudicate a violation of
this chapter by means of the administrative adjudication of ordinance
violations established by section
1-6-7 of this code. (Ord. 2009-889, 10-8-2009)
4-13-8: PENALTIES:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined an
amount not less than thirty dollars ($30.00) or more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each offense. Every day a violation occurs or continues to occur
shall be deemed to be a separate offense. (Ord. 2009-889, 10-8-2009)
CHAPTER 14
PORTABLE STORAGE UNITS
SECTION:
4-14-1: Definitions
4-14-2: Location Of Portable Storage Units
4-14-3: Size Of Portable Storage Units
4-14-4: Condition, Usage And Maintenance Of Portable Storage Units
4-14-5: Permit Required
4-14-6: Violation; Penalty
4-14-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
PORTABLE STORAGE UNIT: Any container designed for the outdoor storage of
personal property which is typically rented to owners or occupants of
residential property for their temporary use on the exterior of the property
and which is delivered to the property and removed by vehicle.
SITE: A tract, or plot of residential real estate occupied or that may be
occupied.
USER: The owner or occupant of residential real estate entering into an
agreement with a portable storage unit company for the placement of a portable
storage unit on a residential site located in the village of South Barrington.
(Ord. 2009-896, 12-10-2009)
4-14-2: LOCATION OF PORTABLE STORAGE UNITS:
Portable storage units may be temporarily located in residential zoning
districts provided the portable storage unit shall be placed within the
required zoning setback restrictions, unless the portable storage unit is
located on a private driveway, then in such case, the portable storage unit may
be located outside of the front yard setback requirement as long as the
portable storage unit does not obstruct vehicular or pedestrian traffic. Under
no circumstances may a portable storage unit be placed in a right of way or
public parkway. (Ord. 2009-896, 12-10-2009)
4-14-3: SIZE OF PORTABLE STORAGE UNITS:
The portable storage unit shall be no larger than one hundred thirty (130)
square feet in area and no higher than ten feet (10') from grade. (Ord. 2009-
896, 12-10-2009)
4-14-4: CONDITION, USAGE AND MAINTENANCE OF PORTABLE STORAGE UNITS:
   A.   The exterior of the portable storage unit shall be constructed of
weatherproof material.
   B.   A portable storage unit shall have no signage other than the name,
address and telephone number of the person or firm engaged in the business of
renting or otherwise placing the portable storage unit and the signage must be
permanently adhered to, or painted on, the portable storage unit.
   C.   The user shall, at all times while the portable storage unit is located
at the site, be responsible for ensuring that the portable storage unit is
maintained in good condition, free from evidence of deterioration, weathering,
discoloration, graffiti, rust, ripping, tearing or other holes or breaks. When
not in immediate use, all storage units shall be locked.
   D.   No portable storage unit shall be resided in by any person, used as
living quarters, or occupied by a person for the conduct of business. In
addition, no portable storage unit shall be used to store solid waste,
construction debris, demolition debris, recyclable materials, business
inventory, commercial goods, goods or property other than at the residential
property where the portable storage unit is located or any other illegal or
hazardous material. Upon reasonable notice to the user and upon reasonable
cause to believe the portable storage unit is being used in violation of the
provisions of this section, the village may inspect the contents and/or use of
any portable storage unit at any reasonable time.
   E.   A portable storage unit may be temporarily parked at a site for a
period of ten (10) consecutive days without a portable storage unit permit. In
any event where a portable storage unit is parked at a site for a period
exceeding ten (10) consecutive days, the village shall require the user to
obtain a portable storage unit permit as provided in section
4-14-5 of this chapter which would authorize the portable storage unit to be
temporarily parked for a period of thirty (30) consecutive days for each
portable storage unit permit. Extended permits may be obtained by the user,
however, no portable storage unit shall remain on a site for a period exceeding
one hundred twenty (120) consecutive days.
   F.   Users are limited to a maximum of four (4) portable storage unit
permits, inclusive of extended permits, per calendar year. (Ord. 2009-896, 12-
10-2009)
4-14-5: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person, corporation or other entity to use, have
or cause a portable storage unit to be parked at any residential property
within the village for a period in excess of ten (10) consecutive days without
having first secured a portable storage unit permit from the village therefor
in accordance with the requirements of this section.
   A.   The portable storage unit permit application shall contain the name,
address, phone number and emergency contact person of the entity providing the
portable storage unit, the name and address of the applicant to whom the
portable storage unit is supplied, whether the person owns, rents, occupies, or
controls the property, the address at which the portable storage unit will be
placed, the delivery date, removal date, active building permit number, if
applicable, and a sketch depicting the location and the placement of the
portable storage unit.
   B.   The portable storage unit permit shall be valid for a period of thirty
(30) consecutive days. In the event the user requests an extension of the
portable storage unit permit, the user shall complete an extended permit
application which shall contain the same information as the original portable
storage unit permit. An extended permit shall be granted for a period of thirty
(30) consecutive days.
   C.   A portable storage unit permit fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00)
shall be submitted with the completed site permit application, which permit fee
covers the thirty (30) day period the portable storage unit is authorized to be
on site by the initial permit. An extended permit fee of five dollars ($5.00)
shall be submitted with the completed extended permit application, which permit
fee covers the thirty (30) day period the portable storage unit is authorized
to be on site by the extended permit. (Ord. 2009-896, 12-10-2009)
4-14-6: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be
fined in an amount not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) per violation. Each day that a violation
continues shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2009-896, 12-10-2009)
CHAPTER 15
DUMPSTERS
SECTION:
4-15-1: Dumpsters In Residential Zoning Districts
4-15-1: DUMPSTERS IN RESIDENTIAL ZONING DISTRICTS:
   A.   Dumpster Defined: For purposes of this chapter "dumpster" shall mean
any container or receptacle that is one cubic yard or more, designed and used
outdoors to hold refuse, garbage, or construction material. This definition is
not to include and this chapter does not apply to residential garbage bins
utilized for regular residential garbage pick up.
   B.   Permit Required: Dumpsters are temporarily permitted on private
property in residential zoning districts provided the property owner first
secures a dumpster permit from the village of South Barrington. During a period
of active construction or rehabilitation of the subject property, a building
permit will be sufficient to authorize the use and location of a dumpster on
the property. If not during a period of active construction or rehabilitation,
a dumpster permit issued by the village of South Barrington shall be required
to authorize the use and location of a dumpster, and in such event, a dumpster
permit fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) shall apply.
   C.   Location Of Dumpsters: Dumpsters may be temporarily located in
residential zoning districts provided the dumpster shall be placed within the
required zoning setback restrictions, unless the construction dumpster is
located on a private driveway, then in such case, the dumpster may be located
outside of the front yard setback requirement as long as the dumpster does not
obstruct vehicular or pedestrian traffic.
   D.   Duration: Dumpsters may remain located on the property during the
period of active construction or rehabilitation provided a building permit has
been issued by the village of South Barrington. If not during a period of
active construction or rehabilitation, a dumpster may also be temporarily
located on the property for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) consecutive
days, provided a dumpster permit has been issued by the village of South
Barrington.
   E.   Violation; Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this chapter
shall, upon conviction, be fined in an amount not less than twenty five dollars
($25.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) per violation.
Each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord.
2009-897, 12-10-2009)
CHAPTER 16
PHOSPHORUS CONTAINING FERTILIZER
SECTION:
4-16-1: Definitions
4-16-2: Prohibition
4-16-3: Impervious Surfaces, Drainageways And Buffer Zones
4-16-4: Exemptions
4-16-5: Signs
4-16-6: Enforcement
4-16-7: Interpretation
4-16-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings ascribed to them:
COMMERCIAL APPLICATOR: A person who is engaged in the business of applying
fertilizer for hire.
FERTILIZER: A substance containing nitrogen, phosphorus, potash or any other
recognized plant nutrient element or compound which is used primarily for its
plant nutrient content. Fertilizer shall not include the following natural
products which shall not be subject to the provisions of this chapter:
agricultural limestone, marl, sea solids and unprocessed animal manure, which
have not been manipulated so as to alter or change them chemically, burnt or
hydrated lime, and sewage sludge produced by any sanitary district.
NONCOMMERCIAL APPLICATOR: A person who applies fertilizer but who is not a
commercial applicator.
PLANT NUTRIENT PHOSPHORUS: Any compound, mixture or substance containing
phosphorus that may be used to stimulate or aid plant growth or health,
including, but not limited to, compounds, mixtures or substances that:
   A.   Have a nonzero P205 fertilizer grade, percentage or ratio;
   B.   Contain any type of ammonium phosphate, calcium phosphate,
superphosphate or phosphoric acid;
   C.   Are packaged or labeled as containing any of the above or as containing
any compound, molecule, mixture or substance containing phosphorus or the
chemical symbol, "P". (Ord. 2010-911, 6-10-2010)
4-16-2: PROHIBITION:
No commercial or noncommercial applicator, including homeowners and tenants,
shall apply to any area within the village any fertilizer, whether in liquid or
granular form, which contains any amount of phosphorus or other compound
containing phosphorus, such as phosphate, except:
   A.   The naturally occurring phosphorus in unadulterated natural or organic
fertilizing products such as yard waste compost; or
   B.   As otherwise provided in section
4-16-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 2010-911, 6-10-2010)
4-16-3: IMPERVIOUS SURFACES, DRAINAGEWAYS AND BUFFER ZONES:
No commercial or noncommercial applicator shall apply any fertilizer to:
Impervious surfaces;
Areas within drainage ditches;
Waterways or within ten feet (10') thereof;
Any delineated wetland and any area established as a natural buffer zone
therefor; and
Frozen ground.
Any person who accidentally applies fertilizer to these areas shall immediately
remove it. (Ord. 2010-911, 6-10-2010)
4-16-4: EXEMPTIONS:
The following are exemptions to the prohibitions described in this chapter:
   A.   The prohibition against the use of fertilizer containing phosphorus
shall not apply to turf and lawn areas for which soil tests confirm, as
determined by applicator, the ambient phosphorus content is below optimum
phosphorus levels for typical area soils. The scope of this exemption shall
only be for such volume or concentration of phosphorus necessary to permit such
turf or lawn area to contain phosphorus levels equal to the optimum phosphorus
levels for typical area soils. Phosphorus applied as fertilizer pursuant to
this exemption shall be integrated into the soil where it is immobilized and
generally protected from loss by stormwater runoff.
   B.   The prohibition contained in section
4-16-2 of this chapter shall not apply to any farming or agricultural business,
provided the use of fertilizers is related to the growth of a product or
maintenance of growing fields. Appropriate steps shall be taken to integrate
the fertilizer into the soil where it is immobilized and generally protected
from loss by stormwater runoff. This exemption shall not apply to the standard
lawn area of said farm or agricultural business.
   C.   The prohibition contained in section
4-16-2 of this chapter shall not apply in the event that the fertilizer is
being applied to establish a new lawn that is in its first growing season. A
building department permit shall be obtained from the village providing
evidence of compliance with this exception. (Ord. 2010-911, 6-10-2010)
4-16-5: SIGNS:
Any person, firm, corporation or partnership which sells any fertilizer at
retail shall be required to post a sign at the point of sale for fertilizer
containing the following legend:
The Village of South Barrington prohibits the application of fertilizer
containing phosphorus to any lawn or turf area and any impervious surface,
drainage way, wetland or buffer zone.
Such sign shall have an area not less than 93.5 square inches and shall be
conspicuously posted no less than four feet (4') above the ground. (Ord. 2010-
911, 6-10-2010)
4-16-6: ENFORCEMENT:
Any person, corporation, firm, franchise or other entity found to violate this
chapter shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and
not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) per violation. Each
application of fertilizer shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2010-911,
6-10-2010)
4-16-7: INTERPRETATION:
This chapter shall not be interpreted as regulating the application of
pesticides or as regulating any other activity regulated by the Illinois
pesticide act. (Ord. 2010-911, 6-10-2010)
CHAPTER 17
COAL TAR PAVEMENT PRODUCTS
SECTION:
4-17-1: Definitions
4-17-2: Enforcement
4-17-3: Regulation Of The Application Of Seal Coat Products Containing Coal Tar
4-17-4: Violation And Penalty
4-17-1: DEFINITIONS:
COAL TAR: A byproduct of the process used to refine coal. Coal tar contains
high levels of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs).
COAL TAR PAVEMENT PRODUCT: A material that contains coal tar and is for use on
an asphalt or concrete surface, including a driveway or parking area.
POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC HYDROCARBONS (PAHs): A group of organic chemicals that are
present in coal tar and are an environmental concern because they are toxic to
aquatic life.
SEAL COAT: A black liquid that is sprayed or painted on asphalt pavement in an
effort to protect and beautify the asphalt. Most seal coat products are coal
tar or asphalt based. (Ord. 2012-961, 4-12-2012)
4-17-2: ENFORCEMENT:
Violations of this chapter will be enforced by the village of South Barrington.
(Ord. 2012-961, 4-12-2012)
4-17-3: REGULATION OF THE APPLICATION OF SEAL COAT PRODUCTS CONTAINING COAL
TAR:
   A.   No person shall apply any coal tar containing seal coat product within
the village of South Barrington.
   B.   A person who owns property on which a coal tar pavement product is used
is presumed to have used a coal tar pavement product in violation of this
section. (Ord. 2012-961, 4-12-2012)
4-17-4: VIOLATION AND PENALTY:
Any violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a municipal
civil infraction subject to the remedies specified in title 1, chapter 4,
"General Penalty", of this code.
(Ord. 2012-961, 4-12-2012)
CHAPTER 18
LIMITATION ON THE USE OF WATER
SECTION:
4-18-1:    Purposes
4-18-2:    Definitions
4-18-3:    Outdoor Water Use Limitations
4-18-4:    Sod Installation
4-18-5:    Penalty
4-18-1: PURPOSES:
   A.   The Village of South Barrington has developed extensive storage,
pumping and pipeline systems to distribute potable water to the village and
other areas served by the village water system;
   B.   The village recognizes that the aquifer that potable water is drawn
from is a finite natural resource;
   C.   The village has developed a plan to conserve outdoor water use and
moderate water use to meet the essential needs of the village and other areas
served by the village water system;
   D.   The village is located in a climate where droughtlike conditions
periodically occur;
   E.   Abnormally high outdoor water use, together with droughtlike
conditions, and/or system constraints, may reduce the available water in local
aquifers to the point of creating a significant strain on the water system; and
   F.   The village finds that it is necessary to provide and implement
measures to conserve water use to protect the water supply of the village to
ensure the health, safety and general welfare of the village residents and
other areas served by the village water system during periods of potential
water shortage.
(Ord. 2025-1442, 9-11-2025)
4-18-2: DEFINITIONS:
IRRIGATION SYSTEM: A system consisting of pipes, valves and sprayers connected
to the village's potable water supply provided by the village system to
manually or automatically be operated/used to irrigate lawns or landscaping.
LANDSCAPE: The area of the property planted with vegetation other than grass.
LAWN: The area of the property planted with grass.
LAWN SPRINKLER: A device attached to a hose designed to allow for the
unattended watering of lawns or landscaping.
LAWN WATERING: Any means or methods of applying water to a lawn and/or
landscaping.
ODD/EVEN ADDRESSES: Address shall be considered odd or even based upon the last
digit in the numerical street address (i.e., 2437 [odd], 2342 [even]).
(Ord. 2025-1442, 9-11-2025)
4-18-3: OUTDOOR WATER USE LIMITATIONS:
   In order to promote good resource conservation practices and to preserve
potable water supplies, the outside use of the village's potable water supply
is limited as follows:
   A.   Restrictions: The outside use of the potable water supply provided by
the village system for landscaping and lawn watering by the use of a lawn
sprinkler or irrigation system is permitted between the hours of five o’clock
(5:00) a.m. and nine o’clock (9:00) a.m., and between the hours of five o’clock
(5:00) p.m. and ten o’clock (10:00) p.m., except as provided in subsection 4-
18-3-B of this section. Lots with odd numbered addresses will be permitted to
use potable water for lawn watering by the use of a lawn sprinkler or
irrigation system on odd numbered days (as long as they are not two (2)
consecutive days in a row) and lots with even numbered addresses will be
permitted to use potable water for lawn watering by the use of a lawn sprinkler
or irrigation system on even numbered days. This requirement is effective
yearly between May 15 and September 15. In addition, new/replacement sprinkle
systems shall be equipped with a WaterSense labeled irrigation controller and
shall be in compliance with Section 2.5(g) of the Illinois Plumbing License Law
(225ILCS 320).
   B.   Exceptions: The restrictions shall apply to all residential, commercial
and industrial properties except for the following uses, which shall be
permitted at all times:
      1.   Residential use of water by watering can, bucket or handheld hose
equipped with a water nozzle, valve, or similar shutoff device, for landscape
and lawn watering which is attended when in use;
      2.   Residential use of water for filling small children's wading pools
and water oriented play devices when those play devices are being actively
used;
      3.   Residential use of water for car washing so long as the hose, if
any, is fitted with a water nozzle, valve, or similar shutoff device, at the
discharge end of the hose and the water is shut off when not being applied to
wash or rinse the vehicle, and which is attended when in use;
      4.   Residential, commercial and industrial use of water for property
maintenance cleaning purposes, such as washing windows, deck cleaning and the
like; and
      5.   A commercial or industrial service involving water usage as part of
an ongoing business operation, such as a car wash.
      6.   New lawns (less than three (3) months old) may be exempted from this
provision with a village permit.
(Ord. 2025-1442, 9-11-2025)
4-18-4: SOD INSTALLATION:
   The installation of sod within the village between May 15 and September 15
is discouraged.
(Ord. 2025-1442, 9-11-2025)
4-18-5: PENALTY:
   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall result in a two
hundred fifty dollar ($250.00) fine for each offense. Each day on which a
violation continues or persists shall be deemed a separate offense.
(Ord. 2025-1442, 9-11-2025)
TITLE 5
POLICE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
5-1-1: Department Created
5-1-2: Chief Of Police
5-1-3: Oath Of Office; Commission
5-1-4: Duties Of Department Members
5-1-5: Serve As Witnesses; Fees
5-1-6: Rules And Regulations
5-1-7: Mandatory Retirement Age
5-1-8: Deputy Police Chief
5-1-9: Board Of Police Commissioners
5-1-9-1: Appointment Of The Chairperson
5-1-9-2: Appointments Of Full Time Members Of The Police Department
5-1-9-3: Promotions
5-1-9-4: Discipline Of Part Time Police Officers
5-1-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby created and established an executive department of the village
which shall be known as the department of police. Such police department shall
consist of such number of full time members, including a chief of police,
patrolmen and part time reserve patrolmen as are from time to time determined
by the board of trustees. The board of trustees may, by motion, constitute a
public safety committee. (Ord. 0-78-90, 4-13-1978; amd. 1992 Code; Ord. 0-97-
514, 6-12-1997)
5-1-2: CHIEF OF POLICE:
   A.   Office Created; Appointment: There is hereby created the office of
chief of police who shall be head of the department of police. He shall be
appointed by the village president, with the advice and consent of the board of
trustees.
   B.   Duties: The chief of police shall have the custody, care and control of
the police department, subject to the direction of the village president. He
shall devote his entire time to the municipal affairs of the village, to
preserve the peace, order, safety and cleanliness thereof, and to this end he
shall execute and enforce all applicable statutes, ordinances and orders of the
village president and board of trustees. He shall be charged with the duty of
protecting the rights of persons and property, providing a proper police force
at every fire, to take notice of any nuisance, to take notice of any
impediment, obstruction or defect in the streets, avenues and public places of
the village, to remove the same or cause immediate notice thereof to be given
to the proper person whose duty it may be to attend to the removal of the same,
and he shall cause to be enforced all ordinances of the village and applicable
statutes of the state. He shall keep a complete record of all arrests, fines
and disposition of all calls and investigations.
   C.   Reports Required: The chief of police shall, not later than January 31
of each year, make an annual report to the president and board of trustees, in
writing, of the state of the police force, with a detailed statement of the
transactions of the department of police for the preceding calendar year, with
such statistics and suggestions in regard to the requirements of the department
as he may deem advisable. He shall also make reports of any matter or thing
concerning such department whenever suggested by the president and board of
trustees.
   D.   Compensation: The compensation of all police department personnel shall
be established annually by the board of trustees.
   E.   Removal From Office; Reinstatement: The village president may remove
the police chief on any formal charge whenever he is of the opinion that the
interests of the village demand removal, but he shall report the reasons for
the removal to the board of trustees at the next regular meeting of the board
of trustees. If the president fails or refuses to report to the board of
trustees the reasons for the removal, or if the board of trustees, by a two-
thirds (2/3) vote of its members authorized by law to be elected, disapproves
of the removal, the chief of police thereupon shall be restored to his office.
The vote shall be by ayes and nays which shall be entered upon the journal of
the president and board of trustees. Upon restoration, the chief of police
shall take a new oath of office. (Ord. 0-2003-681, 4-17-2003)
5-1-3: OATH OF OFFICE; COMMISSION:
Before entering upon his duties, each member of the Department of Police shall
take and subscribe to the same oath or affirmation as provided by the statutes
to be taken and subscribed by all Municipal officers. After subscribing to his
oath of office, each member of the Department of Police shall be issued an
official commission card signed by the President. Said card shall be retained
in the personal possession of the member at all times while on duty. (Ord. 0-
78-90, 4-13-1978)
5-1-4: DUTIES OF DEPARTMENT MEMBERS:
   A.   Generally: It shall be the duty of all members of the Department of
Police to see to the enforcement of all ordinances and statutes effective in
the Village and to preserve order and prevent infractions of the law and to
arrest violators thereof. Every member of the Department of Police is hereby
declared to be a conservator of the peace.
   B.   Serve Processes: All members of the Department of Police shall be
authorized to serve writs, summonses and other processes; but no patrolman
shall serve any such process except upon the order of the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 0-78-90, 4-13-1978)
5-1-5: SERVE AS WITNESSES; FEES:
Every member of the Department of Police shall appear as a witness whenever it
is necessary in a prosecution for a violation of an ordinance or a State or
Federal law. No such member shall receive any witness fee for such service in
any action or suit to which the Village is a party and all fees due for such
services shall, if paid, be turned over to the Village Treasurer. (Ord. 0-78-
90, 4-13-1978)
5-1-6: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The Chief of Police, with the approval of the Village President and Board of
Trustees, may make or prescribe such rules and regulations for the conduct and
guidance of the members of the department as he shall see fit. (Ord. 0-78-90,
4-13-1978)
5-1-7: MANDATORY RETIREMENT AGE:
The age of retirement of any full-time sworn police officer in the service of
the Village shall be sixty-six (66) years, and any full-time sworn police
officer employed by the village shall be required to cease employment as a
sworn police officer upon his or her attainment of the age of sixty-six (66)
years, provided however that the Police Chief who continues to demonstrate the
physical fitness necessary to successfully perform the essential functions of
the position, pursuant to an appropriate medical exam, may extend the mandatory
retirement age for a period not to exceed twelve (12) months, but in no case
shall a Police Chief continue to be employed in that capacity upon attaining
the age of seventy-two (72) years. (Ord. 2018-1176, 2-8-2018; amd. Ord. 2019-
1195, 3-14-2019; Ord. 2020-1229, 3-11-2020; Ord. 2021-1266, 3-11-2021; Ord. O-
2021-1299, 11-11-2021; Ord. O-2022-1310, 3-10-2022; Ord. 2023-1354, 3-9-2023;
Ord. 2024-1396, 3-14-2024)
5-1-8: DEPUTY POLICE CHIEF:
   A.   Office Created: There is hereby created the position of Deputy Police
Chief. The Village President may appoint and can remove the Deputy Police Chief
with the advice and consent of the Village Board of Trustees. The Deputy Police
Chief shall be qualified as a sworn police officer prior to his appointment as
Deputy Police Chief.
   B.   Duties: The Deputy Police Chief shall report to, be evaluated by and
provide those services as required by the Chief of Police. In the event that
there is a vacancy in the Office of Chief of Police or in the event that the
Chief of Police is incapacitated or otherwise not able to perform his duties,
the Deputy Police Chief shall have the same powers and duties generally as that
of Chief of Police, during any vacancy in the office or during the absence or
incapacity of the Chief of Police.
   C.   Compensation: The compensation of the Deputy Police Chief shall be
established by the Village Board of Trustees.
   D.   Rank Upon Removal: A Deputy Police Chief shall serve at the discretion
of the Village President. If a Deputy Police Chief is removed from that
position and continues as a sworn officer with the South Barrington Police
Department, he or she shall revert to the rank of Sergeant without regard as to
whether a vacancy exists in that rank. (Ord. 0-2008-840, 1-10-2008; amd. Ord.
2025-1421, 1-9-2025)
5-1-9: BOARD OF POLICE COMMISSIONERS:
The provisions of division 2.1 of article 10 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65
ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq.) are hereby adopted by reference with respect to all
full time sworn police officers, except as modified herein. To the extent that
any section or provision of this code conflicts with the provisions of division
2.1 of article 10 of the Illinois Municipal Code, this code shall control and
prevail. (Ord. 2014-1032, 9-11-2014; amd. Ord. 2025-1421, 1-9-2025)
5-1-9-1: APPOINTMENT OF THE CHAIRPERSON:
The Village President, with the advice and consent of the Village Board of
Trustees, shall designate a Chairperson to serve during the Municipal fiscal
year. (Ord. 2009-881, 5-14-2009)
5-1-9-2: APPOINTMENTS OF FULL TIME MEMBERS OF THE POLICE DEPARTMENT:
   A.   The provisions of section 10-2.1-17 of article 10 of the Illinois
Municipal Code 1  (the "Act") are applicable to full time members of the Police
Department, except as modified by this section.
   B.   The provisions of section 10-2.1-4 of the Act are hereby modified to
provide that the Village President, with the advice and consent of the Village
Board of Trustees, will appoint all full time members of the Police Department,
including the Chief of Police. The minimum educational requirement for the
original appointment of full-time police officers is a bachelor's degree from
an accredited college or university. After completing the Final Eligibility
Register, the commission will certify to the Village President and the Board of
Trustees, the Final Eligibility Register of candidates for original appointment
to the position of full- time police officer. Each time an original appointment
as a full-time officer is to be made from the Final Eligibility Register, the
Village President will recommend for appointment one person from the top ten
(10) eligible candidates from the current Final Eligibility Register. Such
recommendation to the Village Board will be made subsequent to the Village
President's interview of the candidate and upon the candidate's satisfactory
completion of a polygraph examination and a thorough background investigation.
A candidate whom the Village President considers to be unsuitable for
recommendation for employment in the Police Department will be stricken from
the Final Eligibility Register. With the advice and consent of the Village
Board of Trustees, a conditional offer of employment will be issued by the
Village President to the recommended candidate, conditioned upon the
candidate's satisfactory completion of the required psychological and medical
examinations. If the candidate fails to satisfactorily complete the required
psychological and medical examinations, the conditional offer of employment
will be rescinded by the Village President and such candidate will be stricken
from the Final Eligibility Register. Upon satisfactory completion of the
required psychological and medical examinations, the Village President will
issue a letter of appointment to such candidate. Notwithstanding the above, an
original appointment to a full- time member of the Police Department may also
be made by the Village President's appointment, upon the recommendation of the
Chair of the Board of Police Commissioners, the Chair of the Village Public
Safety Committee and the Chief of Police, and with the advice and consent of
the Board of Trustees, of a qualified part-time police officer currently
employed with the Village's Police Department who has served the Village
honorably for at least two (2) years, taking precedence over candidates on any
existing eligibility register. The Village President has the final authority,
with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, to determine whether it
is in the best interests of the Village to appoint a part-time officer to fill
a full-time vacancy in the Police Department or to select a candidate from a
Final Eligibility Register.
   C.   If the Board of Police Commissioners becomes aware of information
regarding a person listed upon an eligibility register that would have
disqualified that person from being listed on the register if it had been
learned prior to the creation of the register, the Board of Police
Commissioners will strike the name from the eligibility register.
   D.   Should the Final Eligibility Register contain fewer than ten (10) names
at any given time, the Village President may request that the Board of Police
Commissioners prepare a new Final Eligibility Register. If the new Final
Eligibility Register is established prior to the expiration of the current
Final Eligibility Register, persons remaining on the current list may request
that their names be placed upon the new Final Eligibility Register based upon
their scores from the previous register, or they may choose to retest. If the
person chooses to retest for the new eligibility register, the new scores will
be used for the preparation of the new eligibility register and original test
scores will be forfeited.
   E.   All persons appointed as part time or full-time police officers,
including any part-time officer appointed to a full-time officer position, will
have an eighteen (18) month probationary period. The Board of Police
Commissioners may remove a person from any other eligibility register for
police officer if they fail to satisfactorily complete their probationary
period.
   F.   The provisions of this section
5-1-9 do not apply to auxiliary police officers. (Ord. 2017-1162, 9-14-2017)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-4.
5-1-9-3: PROMOTIONS:
   A.   The provisions of section 10-2.1-15 of the Act are hereby modified to
provide that all promotions to the rank of Sergeant will be made by the Village
President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees of the Village.
Full-time police officers who are non-probationary and have completed eighteen
(18) months of continuous service with the South Barrington Police Department
are eligible to be evaluated for promotion to the rank of Sergeant as set forth
in the Rules and Regulations of the Board of Police Commissioners of the
Village of South Barrington. The Village President and Board of Trustees of the
Village may establish educational requirements for promotion to the rank of
Sergeant; however officers hired to a full time position in the South
Barrington Police Department on or before March 1, 2009, are not required to
meet an educational requirement for promotion that is more stringent than that
in effect on March 1, 2009.
   B.   All promotional appointments will be considered as probationary
appointments. Accordingly, members so assigned will be subject to an eighteen
(18) month probationary period. No less than thirty (30) days before the end of
said probationary period, the Chief of Police will recommend to the Village
President either the retention of the promotional appointment or reassignment
of the appointee to his or her previous position. The Village President, with
the advice and consent of the Village Board of Trustees, will make the final
decision with respect to the retention or reassignment of the appointee, which
decision will be final and not subject to review by the Board of Police
Commissioners.
   C.   The position/rank of "Senior Sergeant" and "Deputy Chief" will be an
exempt rank and assignments to the position/rank of "Senior Sergeant" or
"Deputy Chief" will not be subject to the provisions of this section.
Assignments to the position/rank of "Senior Sergeant" or "Deputy Chief" will be
made by the Village President, from the officers holding the rank of Sergeant,
with the advice and consent of the Village Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2017-1162,
9-14-2017; amd. Ord. 2018-1178, 4-24-2018; Ord. 2025-1424, 2-13-2025)
5-1-9-4: DISCIPLINE OF PART TIME POLICE OFFICERS:
The provisions of section 10-2.1-17 of the Act shall not apply to part time
police officers. Part time police officers shall be subject to discipline,
including suspension or discharge, in the discretion of the Chief of Police,
and such disciplinary actions shall not be subject to review by the Board of
Police Commissioners. (Ord. 2009-881, 5-14-2009)
CHAPTER 2
EMERGENCY ALARM SYSTEMS
SECTION:
5-2-1: Definitions
5-2-2: Receiving Station Alarms And Digital Dialer Systems; Minimum Standards
5-2-3: Restrictions On Local Alarms And Direct Dialers
5-2-4: False Alarms
5-2-5: Application; Filing; Revocation Or Suspension
5-2-6: Penalties
5-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
   ALARM: Any device known as a burglar or holdup/panic alarm.
   ALARM USER: The person, family, household, firm, entity, partnership,
association, corporation, company, organization or state, or subdivision
thereof other than the village, of any kind, in control of any building,
structure, or facility or portion thereof wherein an alarm system or protection
system is maintained.
   BURGLAR ALARM:: A system designed to notify the police department, either
automatically or by manual operation, of an unauthorized intrusion.
   FALSE ALARM: The transmission of any alarm signal caused by human error or
mechanical malfunction, whether or not the exact cause of the error or
malfunction is identified, or any other activation of the signal when no actual
emergency exists, other than for testing purposes.
   FIRE ALARM: A system designed to notify the fire department, either
automatically or by manual operation, of an actual or imminent fire.
   HOLDUP/PANIC ALARM: A system designed to notify the police department of a
robbery or other serious criminal act.
   TYPES OF ALARM SYSTEMS:
      Digital Dialer System: A system employing automatic telephone dialing
devices which transmits a prerecorded, taped voice message via a telephone
trunk line.
      Direct Dial System: A system employing automatic telephone dialing
services which transmits a prerecorded, taped voice message via a telephone
trunk line and/or cellular line.
      Local Alarm: An alarm that sounds audibly on the exterior of the premises
of the user.
      Receiving Station Alarms: A system connected directly to the dispatch
center or alarm company from the source of the alarm by permanent, dedicated
telephone lines and/or cellular lines, which constantly scans its customers'
alarms and provides a coded tape if an alarm is triggered, which tape states
the type of alarm, time received, location and alarm status. (Ord. 2009-880, 5-
14-2009; amd. Ord. 2020-1224, 2-13-2020)
5-2-2: RECEIVING STATION ALARMS AND DIGITAL DIALER SYSTEMS; MINIMUM STANDARDS:
All direct "hardwire" and "wireless" cellular receiving station alarm systems
and digital dialer systems shall meet the following minimum standards:
   A.   The system shall conform to all applicable standards of the
Underwriters Laboratories or the National Fire Protection Association.
   B.   Alarm systems shall be maintained by the owner or lessee in such
physical condition that false alarms will be prevented. Alarm users must notify
the police department prior to any system tests to avoid a false alarm.
   C.   Alarm users shall be required to file and maintain an alarm permit
through the village police department. There shall be no cost for the issuance
of the permit. Requirements for alarm permits are established in section
5-2-5  of this chapter.
   D.   Alarm permits are non-transferable. Every alarm user must apply for an
alarm permit. (Ord. 2009-880, 5-14-2009; amd. Ord. 2020-1224, 2-13-2020)
5-2-3: RESTRICTIONS ON LOCAL ALARMS AND DIRECT DIALERS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any local alarm system to
sound continuously for more than fifteen (15) minutes. The sounding of such
alarm for a continuous period of more than fifteen (15) minutes is hereby
declared to be a public nuisance.
   B.   No person shall operate or maintain a direct dialer system which dials
any telephone number within the police department or dispatch center.
   C.   Direct dialers shall not be used for signaling fire or medical alert
alarms. (Ord. 2009-880, 5-14-2009; amd. Ord. 2020-1224, 2-13-2020)
5-2-4: FALSE ALARMS:
   A.   Charges Established:
      1.   If the police department responds to more than three (3) false
alarms in a calendar year at any premises having an alarm system, the user of
such alarm system shall be notified via mail that they have reached assessment
status.
      2.   The below table is the billing schedule for false alarms.
 
Number Of Alarms With A Permit Without A Permit
0-3              No charge     No charge
4-6              $50 for each  $100 for each
7-9              $100 for each $200 for each
10+              $150 for each $300 for each
 
   B.   Notice Of Charge; Reconsideration; Final Decision:
      1.   Payment of a false alarm charge is due within sixty (60) days.
      2.   A permit holder may request reconsideration of a charge through the
village’s adjudication process.
      3.   Within five (5) days after the receipt of a request for
reconsideration from a user, the chief of police shall notify the user of his
decision. The chief's decision shall be final.
   C.   New Alarm Systems Exempt: Except in the case of a holdup/panic alarm,
whenever a new alarm system is installed, the user shall be given thirty (30)
days from the date of the installation of such alarm system within which no
alarm from the premises shall be deemed to be a false alarm.
   D.   If any alarm user fails to file a permit and encounters a false alarm
after the initial thirty (30) day grace period, a warning letter will be sent
stating user has thirty (30) days to file a permit application. If the alarm
user continues to not file a permit and begins to incur charges, as stated in
this section, fines will double the amount of the false alarm charge until a
permit is filed. (Ord. 2009-880, 5-14-2009; amd. Ord. 2020-1224, 2-13-2020)
5-2-5: APPLICATION; FILING; REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION:
   A.   Application Required: Each person desiring to install, maintain or
operate a fire, smoke or medical emergency alarm, as defined herein, shall file
an application on such forms as provided by the village. Each person desiring
to install, maintain or operate a burglar or "holdup/panic alarm", as defined
herein, shall file an application on such forms as provided by the village. The
application shall be submitted to the chief of police and shall contain the
following information:
      1.   Name, address and telephone number of the applicant.
      2.   Name, address and telephone number, and type of business of premises
where alarm system is to be located.
      3.   Name and telephone number of at least two (2) persons responsible
for the premises where the alarm is located to be contacted to deactivate the
alarm system.
      4.   The name and telephone number of the person, firm or corporation
authorized to deactivate the alarm system when none of the persons named in
subsection A3 of this section can be reached.
      5.   The name and telephone number of the person, firm or corporation
responsible for the maintenance and repair of the alarm system.
      6.   In the event none of the above persons will be available at any
particular time, it is the responsibility of the alarm user to notify the
QuadCom communications center of an alternate person to contact.
   B.   Authority To Revoke Or Suspend: The chief of police has the authority
to revoke or suspend the operation of alarm systems, including local alarms, if
any inspection or other evidence reveals noncompliance with the provisions of
this chapter. (Ord. 2009-880, 5-14-2009; amd. Ord. 2020-1224, 2-13-2020)
5-2-6: PENALTIES:
Failure to pay any charge assessed under this chapter within sixty (60) days of
notice of the charge being sent by the police department shall result in the
issuance of a notice of ordinance violation in accordance with the procedures
of the village's administrative adjudication hearing ordinance. The penalty for
failure to pay surcharges assessed under this chapter shall not be less than
one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00);
provided, however, that in the event that the owner or occupant makes payment
for such violation, together with payment in full of all outstanding alarm
charges, prior to a public hearing before the village's administrative hearing
officer, the penalty shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for such violation.
A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each and every day a violation
occurs or continues. After completion of an administrative hearing, remaining
unpaid accounts may be sent to collections. (Ord. 2009-880, 5-14-2009; amd.
Ord. 2020-1224, 2-13-2020)
CHAPTER 3
ANIMAL CONTROL
SECTION:
5-3-1: Definitions
5-3-2: General Provisions
5-3-3: Control Of Animals
5-3-4: Animal Bites
5-3-5: Impounding Animals
5-3-6: License Fee
5-3-7: Inoculations
5-3-8: Estrus (Heat)
5-3-9: Diseased Animal
5-3-10: Disposition Of Dead Animals
5-3-11: Violations; Penalty
5-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
ANIMAL: Any live vertebrate creature except man.
ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER/WARDEN: Any employee of the Village designated by the
Chief of Police to exercise police powers in the enforcement of this Chapter.
AUTHORIZED PERSON: Any member of the Police Department, animal control officer/
warden or any person under their supervision.
BITE: Seizure of a person with the jaws or teeth of any cat, dog or other
animal capable of transmitting rabies so that the person so seized has been
wounded or pierced and further includes contact of the saliva of such cat, dog
or other animal with any break or abrasion of the skin.
CAT: All members of the feline family.
CONTROL: Any owned animal that is secured by one or more of the following:
   A.   A leash or lead no longer than six feet (6') in length;
   B.   An electrical or mechanical device designed to keep an animal confined
to the owner's property;
   C.   A fence, cage, crate or enclosure;
   D.   A vehicle;
   E.   The presence and voice of the owner or member of the owner's family.
DISEASED ANIMAL: Any animal affected with a disease contagious or infectious to
both humans and animals.
DOG: All members of the canine family.
ENCLOSURE: Any fence or structure of at least six feet (6') in height, forming
or causing an enclosure suitable to prevent the entry of young children and to
confine a dog or other animal, designed with secure sides, top and bottom
adequate to prevent escape.
IMPOUNDMENT: The removal and taking into custody of animals pursuant to this
Chapter.
KENNEL: Any establishment or premises where more than four (4) dogs or four (4)
cats or any combination thereof, over four (4) months of age are boarded or
kept for any purpose whatsoever, or on which more than two (2) such animals are
boarded for compensation or kept for sale, with the exception of regularly
established veterinary hospitals, pet shops, pounds or shelters.
LEASH: Any restraint, cord, thong or chain not more than six feet (6') in
length, designed for the purpose of keeping the animal under control. The leash
must securely fasten to the collar or harness of the animal and must be of
sufficient strength to contain the animal.
POUND: Any facility licensed by the Illinois Department of Agriculture and
approved by the Chief of Police for the purpose of enforcing this Chapter and
used as a shelter for seized, stray, homeless, abandoned or unwanted animals.
SHELTER: Any establishment where dogs, cats or other animals are received,
housed and distributed with or without charge.
STRAY ANIMAL: Any animal running at large in the public way or on private
property other than that of the owners or keepers of such animals.
VICIOUS ANIMAL: A. Any individual animal that when unprovoked inflicts bites
and attacks a human being or other animal either on public or private property.
   B.   Any individual animal with a propensity, tendency, or disposition to
attack without provocation, to cause injury or to otherwise do any act that
might endanger the safety of human beings, domestic animals or any other
property of another, including, but not limited to, a disposition to mischief
or fierceness which might lead to attack to the foregoing.
   C.   Any individual animal which attacks a human being or domestic animal
without provocation, whether in play, anger or outbreak of untrained nature.
   D.   No animal shall be deemed vicious if it bites attacks or menaces a
trespasser on the property of its owner or harms or menaces anyone who has
tormented or abused it or is a professionally trained animal for law
enforcement or guard duties.
VILLAGE: The Village of South Barrington, Cook County, Illinois. (Ord. 0-94-
455, 12-12-1994)
5-3-2: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
It shall be unlawful to:
   A.   Inhumanely beat, underfeed, overload or abandon any animal.
   B.   Fail to provide any animal with proper shelter, protection from weather
or veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering.
   C.   Own, keep, harbor or maintain within the Village any breed of fowl that
are or will be used in the pursuit of and staging of cockfighting on any
premises.
   D.   Promote, stage, hold, manage, conduct or carry on any animal fight of a
similar nature, nor any simulated version of same that involves baiting or
inciting an animal toward intent to fight.
   E.   Hold a greased pig contest.
   F.   Keep animals in violation of the "Illinois Humane Care for Animals Act"
or the "Illinois Welfare Act".
   G.   Intentionally strike Canadian geese or other wildlife with a motor
vehicle. Geese and other wildlife shall have the right of way when crossing
streets within the Village. Any person who, as the operator of a motor vehicle,
strikes an animal shall stop at once and render such assistance as may be
possible, or shall immediately report such injury to the animal owner, if
known; or to the appropriate law enforcement agency; or to the local humane
society.
   H.   Torment, shoot at with slingshots, BB or pellet type guns or other
firearms, pelt with rocks or otherwise disturb any animals.
   I.   Give away or use any live animal as a prize for or as an inducement to
enter any contest, game, or other compensation or an inducement to enter a
place of amusement or offer such animal as an incentive to enter any business
agreement whereby the offer was for the purpose of attracting trade.
   J.   Bring or cause to have brought into the Village, sell, offer for sale,
barter or display living baby chicks, ducklings, or other fowl or rabbits which
have been dyed, colored or otherwise treated so as to impart to them an
artificial color, or give away as pets or sell, offer for sale, barter or give
away at no cost or as novelties or prizes. Nothing in this Section shall be
construed to prohibit legitimate commerce in poultry for agricultural or food
purposes.
   K.   Poison or cause to be poisoned any domesticated animal. The only
exception will be by written permit from the Illinois Department of Agriculture
for the purpose of controlling diseases transmissible to humans or other
animals and only when all other methods and means have been exhausted. Any
drugs used for euthanasia shall be by or under the direction of a licensed
veterinarian.
   L.   Take the nest or eggs or young of any bird that is protected by Federal
or State law.
   M.   Keep or permit to be kept or display for exhibition purposes any wild
animal contrary to Federal, State, and local laws or regulations.
   N.   Leave any animal unattended in a motor vehicle or enclosed trailer when
the outside temperature exceeds eighty six degrees Fahrenheit (86°F) (30°C) or
contain any animal in such manner that said animal does not have proper air
circulation while confined in a motor vehicle, trailer, kennel, doghouse, or
any type of container or structure in which an animal may be confined.
   O.   Own any animal which is known to be infected with any disease
transmissible to other animals or man, including severe parasitism, unless such
animal shall be confined in such a manner as not to expose other animals or
man. (Ord. 0-94-455, 12-12-1994)
5-3-3: CONTROL OF ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful:
   A.   Consent Required: For the owner or any person who has in his custody or
control, any dog, cat, or other animal to enter upon the premises of another
within the Village without the consent of the owners.
   B.   Public Body Of Water: To permit any animal, whether licensed or not, to
enter any public body of water, pond, fountain or stream.
   C.   Food Establishment: To permit any animal to enter any place where food
is stored, prepared, served or sold to the public, or any public building or
hall, provided however, that this Section shall not apply to any blind person
using a trained, seeing eye dog, to veterinary offices or hospitals, or to
animal shows or exhibitions.
   D.   Trespass: To permit any animal to run uncontrolled or trespass on
private or public property.
   E.   Damage: To permit any animal to damage or destroy any property.
   F.   Vehicles: To permit any dog to chase, run after or jump at vehicles
using the public thoroughfares.
   G.   Threatening Animal: To permit any dog to habitually snap, growl, snarl,
jump upon or otherwise threaten persons lawfully using any common thoroughfare,
