CHAPTER 5
PART TIME POLICE OFFICERS
SECTION:
5-5-1: General Purpose
5-5-2: Appointments Of Part Time Police Officers
5-5-3: Special Requirements (Rep. by Ord. 2014-1032, 9-11-2014)
5-5-4: Tools And Equipment Used
5-5-5: Physical Demands
5-5-6: Work Environment
5-5-7: Selection Guidelines
5-5-8: Supervision Received
5-5-9: Supervision Exercised
5-5-10: Essential Duties And Responsibilities
5-5-1: GENERAL PURPOSE:
A part time police officer shall serve under the direction of his or her
immediate supervisor or senior, full time officer on duty, and shall comply
with all rules and regulations of the village of South Barrington public safety
committee and the policies of the village. Such officer is responsible in a
supplementary role for the protection of life and property, prevention of
crime, apprehension of criminals and the general enforcement of laws and
ordinances. His or her duties generally consist of routine patrol, preliminary
reports and investigations, and enforcement of traffic regulations. Part time
police officers may, at the direction of the chief of police, be assigned to
assist full time patrol officers with special tasks. The work involves an
element of personal danger. The officer must be able to exercise sound
independent judgment under stress. Work assignments are general, and the
primary function of the part time police officer is to assist the full time
police officer in fulfilling all duties and responsibilities and general patrol
duties. The officer's instructions are received from supervisors or senior full
time officers, who shall review work methods and results through reports,
personnel evaluations and discussion with the officer. (Ord. 0-97-518, 6-12-
1997)
5-5-2: APPOINTMENTS OF PART TIME POLICE OFFICERS:
Appointments for part time police officers shall be made in accordance with the
standards set forth in this section. Any candidate for part time police officer
shall be a certified police officer in good standing, having been certified by
the Illinois law enforcement training standards board under section 8.1 of the
Illinois police training act 1 , and who is either currently working as a full
time police officer for an Illinois law enforcement agency, laid off as a full
time police officer by an Illinois law enforcement agency, or who has retired
as a full time police officer from an Illinois law enforcement agency.
The village shall permanently post on its website an advertisement for part
time police officers, providing, in part, the minimum qualifications for
employment for part time police officers, and further stating that applications
for part time police officers may be submitted by eligible candidates to the
office of the chief of police at any time. At any time that the village seeks
to fill a vacancy in the position of part time police officer, the chief of
police shall conduct an interview, either in person or by telephone, of
eligible candidate(s). Following such interview(s), the chief of police shall
either approve or disapprove any candidate who has been interviewed by the
chief of police. If the chief of police approves a candidate, a background
investigation of such candidate shall be conducted by the village. If such
candidate passes the background investigation, as determined by the chief of
police or his/her designee, such candidate may be eligible to be interviewed by
a committee consisting of the chief of police, the chairperson of the village's
safety committee or the chairperson's designee (provided that such designee
must be another current member of the safety committee), and the chairperson of
the South Barrington board of police commissioners, or the chairperson's
designee (providing that such designee must be another current member of such
police commission). Such committee members shall be provided with copies of the
background investigation material prior to the interview by the committee.
If such candidate is approved by the above described committee, the candidate
shall then be scheduled for a polygraph examination (i.e., "lie detector
test"). If such candidate successfully completes such test, the candidate shall
be interviewed by the village president. If the village president approves of
the hiring of such candidate, the village president shall recommend such
candidate for appointment. With the advice and consent of the village board of
trustees, a conditional letter of employment shall be issued by the village
president to the person recommended. Upon satisfactory completion of a
psychological and physical examination, such person shall be appointed as a
part time police officer. The village president shall issue a certificate of
appointment to such part time police officer. (Ord. 2014-1032, 9-11-2014)
 
Notes
1 1. 50 ILCS 705/8.1.
5-5-3: SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS:
(Rep. by Ord. 2014-1032, 9-11-2014)
5-5-4: TOOLS AND EQUIPMENT USED:
The position requires the ability to operate the following equipment:
   A.   Motor vehicles, reasonably and safely under routine and emergency
conditions, sometimes for lengthy periods of time;
   B.   Firearms, with demonstrated proficiency in the care and use of
assigned/authorized weapons;
   C.   Basic office equipment, including, but not limited to, typewriters,
telephone, computer terminals, mobile data terminals, etc.;
   D.   Writing implements and basic drawing templates, including the ability
to write legible documents and produce simple diagrams; and
   E.   Basic tools and equipment necessary to perform job tasks and functions
including, but not limited to, speed detection, radar, two-way radios, first
aid equipment, fire extinguishers, handcuffs and other weapons, gas masks,
helmets, standard police uniform, simple tools (pry bars, hydrant wrenches,
tape measures, etc.), cameras, fingerprinting equipment, water rescue
equipment, etc. (Ord. 0-97-518, 6-12-1997)
5-5-5: PHYSICAL DEMANDS:
   A.   The officer must be in the physical condition required to:
      1.   Effect arrest;
      2.   Subdue resisting individuals;
      3.   Chase fleeing suspects;
      4.   Run to person requiring emergency assistance;
      5.   Lift and carry equipment and injured/deceased persons;
      6.   Force entry into buildings;
      7.   Climb flights of stairs/ladders;
      8.   Walk, stand, or sit for long periods of time (including driving);
      9.   Endure exposure to extreme weather and disease;
      10.   Perform lifesaving procedures (CPR, first aid, etc.);
      11.   Communicate effectively, verbally and nonverbally;
      12.   Perform job tasks and functions; and
      13.   Provide assistance to citizens and coworkers in distress,
including, but not limited to, manually pushing stalled motor vehicles.
   B.   The officer must have audio-visual discrimination and perception
required to:
      1.   Make observations;
      2.   Read and write; and
      3.   Drive and operate equipment safely.
   C.   The officer must have the ability required to:
      1.   Observe analytically and objectively, analyze situations quickly,
determine and take prompt, effective action;
      2.   Understand, interpret and apply applicable Federal and State
statutes, local ordinances, court decisions, Police Department and Village
rules and policies;
      3.   Understand and respond quickly and accurately to written and oral
directions, instructions, inquiries and requests;
      4.   Work independently and effectively within the confines of standard
operating procedures;
      5.   Initiate appropriate interpersonal and intra- and interagency
communications establishing a rapport with all members and segments of the
community to enhance the police professional image and instill a respect for
law and order;
      6.   Act quickly, calmly, and decisively in emergencies and under stress;
      7.   Handle situations firmly, courteously, tactfully, and impartially;
      8.   Express oneself clearly and concisely, orally and in writing;
      9.   Record information clearly and completely;
      10.   Facilitate effective conflict arbitration/resolution;
      11.   Maintain confidentiality in the performance of duties; and
      12.   Assimilate, retain and effectively use geographic knowledge
concerning the Village and surrounding vicinity. (Ord. 0-97-518, 6-12-1997)
5-5-6: WORK ENVIRONMENT:
The position of part time police officer involves exposure to, and requires the
employee to function in the presence of:
   A.   All weather conditions, including extreme weather conditions;
   B.   All lighting conditions, including extreme lighting conditions,
daylight and night light;
   C.   Fire, smoke, and chemical leaks/spills in close proximity as necessary
to provide emergency services; and
   D.   Personal danger, including, but not limited to:
      1.   Armed and/or dangerous persons/animals;
      2.   Persons and/or articles with contagious/communicable disease;
      3.   Hazards associated with emergency driving, traffic control and
working in and around traffic; and
      4.   Hazards associated with natural and manmade disasters. (Ord. 0-97-
518, 6-12-1997)
5-5-7: SELECTION GUIDELINES:
The job description of a part time police officer does not constitute an
employment agreement between the employer and employee and is subject to change
by the employer as the needs of the employer and requirements of the job
change.
The duties listed above are intended only as illustrations of the various types
of work that may be performed. The omission of specific statements of duties
does not exclude them from the position if the work is similar, related, or a
logical assignment to the position. (Ord. 2008-852, 4-10-2008)
5-5-8: SUPERVISION RECEIVED:
The part time police officer shall work under the supervision of a police
sergeant or senior full time police officer. (Ord. 0-97-518, 6-12-1997)
5-5-9: SUPERVISION EXERCISED:
The part time police officer shall exercise no supervision over any other
police officer. The chief of police may appoint a part time police officer to
act as the coordinator of the contingent of part time officers. No additional
compensation shall be applied to this responsibility. (Ord. 0-97-518, 6-12-
1997)
5-5-10: ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
The primary duty and responsibility of the part time police officer is to
complement the full time police officer in meeting the following
responsibilities:
   A.   Crime Prevention:
      1.   Patrolling assigned areas for observing criminal activity, traffic
violations, persons needing assistance and safety hazards including, but not
limited to, leaking water pipes, gas mains or sewers, all street and traffic
lights that are defective, all traffic signs, power and telephone lines that
are in need of repair, and making notification to the appropriate authority
concerning health and safety hazards;
      2.   Being thoroughly familiar with the streets and boundaries of the
village, as well as neighborhoods and potential problem areas;
      3.   Conducting security checks of businesses and homes, and making
recommendations on security issues when practical; and
      4.   Making presentations to groups and individuals on subjects related
to the job's tasks and functions.
   B.   Criminal Investigations And Apprehension: The part time police officer
shall:
      1.   Handle complaints filed by citizens;
      2.   Watch for, detect, and investigate violations of laws and
ordinances, as well as document and investigate reported violations;
      3.   Conduct interviews and interrogations of victims, witnesses,
suspects, offenders, and other persons;
      4.   Conduct preliminary and follow up investigations;
      5.   Identify, collect, process, package, and log items of physical
evidence;
      6.   Collect information and either act upon it, if within the scope of
his or her authority, or route it to the proper authority or agency;
      7.   Search persons, vehicles, places, and other items;
      8.   Identify and arrest offenders, including subduing resistive
arrestees;
      9.   Book, guard, and escort prisoners;
      10.   Prepare and serve criminal complaints, arrest warrants, and other
court documents;
      11.   Prepare cases for trial; and
      12.   Appear and testify in court, at coroner's inquests, at disposition
sessions, and similar proceedings.
   C.   Traffic: The part-time police officer:
      1.   Engages in traffic and parking law enforcement;
      2.   Controls, regulates, and directs traffic, vehicular and pedestrian;
and
      3.   Investigates traffic accidents, including protecting the scene,
aiding the injured, controlling traffic, clearing the scene, determining the
cause, preparing reports and diagrams.
   D.   Juveniles: The part-time police officer deals with all ages of children
in a variety of circumstances such as delinquents; minors requiring
authoritative intervention; children who have been neglected and/or abused;
children who are runaways or who are lost (or found); children who are the
victims of crimes; children who are participating in public relations or
instructional functions; and children who are informants.
   E.   Miscellaneous Order Maintenance: The part-time police officer should:
      1.   Be responsive to and diligent with respect to all verbal and written
orders issued by supervisors and to all work assignments transmitted to them by
authorized individuals;
      2.   Watch for, correct and/or report any public hazards, dangerous
conditions, streets, sidewalks, Village or other property likely to prove
dangerous to the public, as well as the presence of any litter, garbage, ashes,
dead animals or other offensive matters;
      3.   Deal with domestic disputes and other interpersonal and business
conflicts;
      4.   Administer first aid, including CPR, to sick and injured persons;
      5.   Investigate incidents involving dead persons resulting from
criminal, accidental, suicidal, and natural causes, including a determination
of the circumstances and handling/removal of the body, and dealing with the
family, relatives, friends, witnesses, etc.;
      6.   Investigate reports of lost and found property;
      7.   Investigate reports of missing and found persons;
      8.   Investigate animal complaints, including the apprehension and
transport of stray or vicious animals;
      9.   Be responsible for complying with all written safety rules and
regulations of the Police Department and Village;
      10.   Be responsible for performing duties and responsibilities
exhibiting due concern for the officer's personal safety, as well as the safety
of coworkers and the public;
      11.   Direct and/or supervise others, civilians, and public employees, at
the scenes of crimes, accidents, disasters, assemblies, etc.; and
      12.   Generally render assistance to persons in distress.
   F.   Organizational Support:
      1.   May perform desk duties including: telecommunications (telephone,
computer terminal, and radio); assisting persons at the counter; processing and
filing reports;
      2.   Conduct background investigations;
      3.   Attend training as assigned;
      4.   Develop and maintain required skills and licenses/permits/
certifications associated with areas of special instruction, expertise, etc.
(firearms qualifications; breath operator certification; CPR; evidence
technician; accident investigator; juvenile law; criminal investigation);
      5.   Train new officers, part-time officers and other employees in areas
of special skills or expertise; and
      6.   Prepare clear, accurate and complete reports, logs, MDT entries and
documents on any and all activities engaged in. The position of part-time
police officer involves regular and irregular shift work and shift rotation
necessary to supplement the full-time staff to provide police services twenty
four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week, fifty two (52) weeks a year,
including weekends and holidays. Work hours will vary, but will not exceed
thirty two (32) hours in any one week. The hour limitation may be lifted in the
event of an emergency, disaster or extreme work load by the Chief of Police.
      7.   Shall perform any other task/assignment so ordered by the Chief of
Police or his designate. (Ord. 0-97-518, 6-12-1997)
CHAPTER 6
9-1-1 EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM
SECTION:
5-6-1: Created
5-6-2: Surcharge
5-6-3: Definitions
5-6-4: Exemption From Surcharge
5-6-5: Deductions By Telecommunications Carriers
5-6-6: Remittance Of Surcharge
5-6-7: Remittance Return
5-6-8: Adjustments To Surcharge
5-6-9: Emergency Telephone System Board
5-6-1: CREATED:
There is hereby created and established a "9-1-1" emergency telephone system.
(Ord. 2000-616, 11-9-2000)
5-6-2: SURCHARGE:
A surcharge at a rate of two dollars ($2.00) per month per network connection
is hereby imposed upon the monthly billing subscribers of telecommunication
carriers within the village for the funding of the "9-1-1" emergency telephone
system as authorized by referendum on March 20, 1990. (Ord. 2000-616, 11-9-
2000)
5-6-3: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
MONTHLY BILLING SUBSCRIBER: A person or entity subscribing for telephone
service through telecommunication carriers. A monthly billed subscriber shall
be deemed to reside within the village if the "service address", as hereinafter
defined, is located within the village.
NETWORK CONNECTION: The number of voice grade communication channels directly
between a subscriber and a telecommunications carrier's public switched network
without the intervention of any other telecommunications carrier's switched
network which would be required to carry the subscriber's interpremises
traffic.
SERVICE ADDRESS: The location of the subscriber's telecommunications facilities
accessing the network connection or connections that are subject to the
surcharge. If this is not a defined location, service address shall mean the
location of a subscriber's primary use of the network connection as defined by
telephone number, authorization code, or location in Illinois where bills are
sent.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS CARRIER: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate,
partnership, association, joint stock company, joint adventure, corporation,
municipal corporation, or political subdivision of this state, or a receiver,
trustee, conservator, or other representative appointed by order of any court
engaged in the business of transmitting messages by means of electricity. (Ord.
2000-616, 11-9-2000)
5-6-4: EXEMPTION FROM SURCHARGE:
The village clerk shall provide any telecommunication carrier collecting the
surcharge with a certified list of those network connections assigned to the
village to be exempt from imposition of the surcharge. The certified list may
be revised by the village on sixty (60) days' prior written notice provided to
the telecommunications carriers. (Ord. 2000-616, 11-9-2000)
5-6-5: DEDUCTIONS BY TELECOMMUNICATIONS CARRIERS:
Each telecommunication carrier is hereby authorized and instructed to deduct
three percent (3%) from the gross amount of surcharge collected prior to
remittance to the village of this chapter in reimbursement for the expense of
accounting and collecting the surcharge. (Ord. 2000-616, 11-9-2000)
5-6-6: REMITTANCE OF SURCHARGE:
Every telecommunication carrier shall remit to the village treasurer the amount
of surcharge collected for each calendar month within thirty (30) days
following expiration of each month to which the surcharge applies, net of any
network or other "9-1-1" system charge then due to the particular
telecommunication carrier as shown on an itemized bill and the three percent
(3%) accounting and collection charge described in section
5-6-5 of this chapter. (Ord. 2000-616, 11-9-2000)
5-6-7: REMITTANCE RETURN:
Simultaneously with the remittance described in section
5-6-6 of this chapter, each telecommunication carrier shall make a return to
the village treasurer for the period to which the remittance applies stating as
follows:
   A.   The name of the telecommunication carrier.
   B.   The telecommunication carrier's principal place of business.
   C.   The number of network connections to which the surcharge applies.
   D.   The amount of surcharge collected.
   E.   Such other reasonable and related information as the corporate
authorities may require. (Ord. 2000-616, 11-9-2000)
5-6-8: ADJUSTMENTS TO SURCHARGE:
   A.   Credits: If it shall appear that an amount of surcharge has been paid
which was not due under the provisions of this chapter, whether as the result
of a mistake of fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be credited
against any surcharge due, or to become due, under this chapter; provided that
no amounts erroneously paid more than three (3) years prior to the filing of a
claim therefor shall be so credited. Ninety (90) days' prior notice shall be
given to the emergency telephone system board on any credit against a
surcharge.
   B.   Recovery Of Surcharge: No action to recover any amount of surcharge due
under the provisions of this chapter shall be commenced more than three (3)
years after the due date of such amount. (Ord. 2000-616, 11-9-2000)
5-6-9: EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM BOARD:
The public safety committee of the village board and the police chief of the
village are hereby appointed as the emergency telephone system board and shall
have all the powers and responsibilities of the emergency telephone system
board as empowered by the act and hereunder. (Ord. 2000-616, 11-9-2000)
CHAPTER 7
AUXILIARY POLICE OFFICERS
SECTION:
5-7-1: Purpose
5-7-2: Position Established
5-7-3: Appointment
5-7-4: Residency
5-7-5: Serves At Discretion Of President Under Direction Of Chief
5-7-6: Compensation
5-7-7: Fingerprint Check Required
5-7-8: Ineligible Persons
5-7-9: Not Member Of The Regular Police Force
5-7-10: General Powers And Duties
5-7-11: Oath
5-7-12: Carrying Of Weapons
5-7-13: Conservators Of The Peace
5-7-14: Training
5-7-15: Supervision
5-7-16: Uniform And Identification Symbols
5-7-17: Termination With Or Without Cause
5-7-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to free the sworn officers from the village of
South Barrington to perform regular patrol duties during events occurring
within the village of South Barrington and thus allowing the police to continue
their normal and traditional patrol duties; while utilizing auxiliary police
officers to control vehicular and pedestrian traffic in and around those areas
where the events are occurring. (Ord. 2006-757, 2-6-2006)
5-7-2: POSITION ESTABLISHED:
The position of auxiliary police officer is hereby established by the village.
(Ord. 2006-757, 2-6-2006)
5-7-3: APPOINTMENT:
   A.   The president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, is
hereby authorized to appoint such number of auxiliary police officers, who
shall have attained the age of twenty one (21) years or older, as may from time
to time be requested from the chief of police. Appointments to the police
auxiliary shall be made annually and shall terminate on January 31 of each year
or at such later time as the president and board of trustees approve new yearly
appointments.
   B.   Any appointment made to the police auxiliary shall be for one year
unless sooner terminated with or without cause. Any person whose appointment
has been terminated shall immediately return to the chief of police any
uniforms, badges, cap pieces, and other department property held by him or her.
   C.   The chief of police shall create hiring standards for auxiliary
officers in accordance with professional police practices. (Ord. 2006-757, 2-6-
2006)
5-7-4: RESIDENCY:
An auxiliary police officer need not be a resident of the village. (Ord. 2006-
757, 2-6-2006)
5-7-5: SERVES AT DISCRETION OF PRESIDENT UNDER DIRECTION OF CHIEF:
The position of auxiliary police officer is not a full time position with the
village, and the auxiliary police officer serves at the discretion of the
president and trustees of the village of South Barrington, under the direction
of the chief of police. (Ord. 2006-757, 2-6-2006)
5-7-6: COMPENSATION:
Auxiliary police officers shall be paid an hourly rate as established by the
president and board of trustees from time to time for each hour of service
performed, including court attendance; provided, service is performed at the
direction of the chief of police, or his designee. (Ord. 2006-757, 2-6-2006)
5-7-7: FINGERPRINT CHECK REQUIRED:
Prior to appointment, all proposed auxiliary police officers shall be
fingerprinted and their fingerprints shall be checked with the federal bureau
of investigation, Washington, D.C., in addition to any county, state and local
law enforcement agencies, for any possible criminal record. (Ord. 2006-757, 2-
6-2006)
5-7-8: INELIGIBLE PERSONS:
No person shall be appointed as an auxiliary police officer if he/she has been
convicted of a felony of this state or any other state or convicted of other
crimes involving moral turpitude. (Ord. 2006-757, 2-6-2006)
5-7-9: NOT MEMBER OF THE REGULAR POLICE FORCE:
Auxiliary police officers shall not be members of the regular police force of
the village of South Barrington. (Ord. 2006-757, 2-6-2006)
5-7-10: GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES:
Auxiliary police officers shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   To aid or direct vehicular or pedestrian traffic within the village.
   B.   To aid in control of natural or manmade disasters.
   C.   To aid in case of civil disorder as directed by the chief of police.
   D.   To aid in other duties allowed by statute and assigned by the chief of
police. (Ord. 2006-757, 2-6-2006)
5-7-11: OATH:
An auxiliary police officer shall take an oath like that of a sworn member of
the police force. (Ord. 2006-757, 2-6-2006)
5-7-12: CARRYING OF WEAPONS:
Auxiliary police officers shall not carry firearms or any other nonprescribed
weapons on or off duty. (Ord. 2006-757, 2-6-2006)
5-7-13: CONSERVATORS OF THE PEACE:
Auxiliary police officers of the village of South Barrington shall not be
conservators of the peace and shall not have the powers specified in 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-15-25. (Ord. 2006-757, 2-6-2006)
5-7-14: TRAINING:
Auxiliary police officers before entering upon their duties, shall receive a
course of training in traffic direction and other police procedures appropriate
for the exercise of the powers conferred upon them under this chapter. The
training and course of study shall be determined and provided by the village of
South Barrington. Auxiliary police officers will from time to time be required
to attend additional training, as directed by the chief of police. (Ord. 2006-
757, 2-6-2006)
5-7-15: SUPERVISION:
All auxiliary police officers shall, at all times during the performance of
their duties, be subject to the direction and control of the chief of police
and/or his designee. (Ord. 2006-757, 2-6-2006)
5-7-16: UNIFORM AND IDENTIFICATION SYMBOLS:
Uniforms and identification symbols worn by auxiliary police officers shall be
different and distinct from those used by members of the regular police
department. (Ord. 2006-757, 2-6-2006)
5-7-17: TERMINATION WITH OR WITHOUT CAUSE:
Termination with or without cause of an auxiliary police officer shall be at
the discretion of the president with the advice and consent of the board of
trustees. (Ord. 2006-757, 2-6-2006)
TITLE 6
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
CHAPTER 1
VEHICLE LICENSES
(Rep. by Ord. 0-2002-663, 9-12-2002, eff. 1-1-2003)
CHAPTER 2
TRAFFIC CODE
SECTION:
6-2-1: Adoption Of The Illinois Vehicle Code
6-2-2: Exceptions And Additions To Code
6-2-3: Vehicle Size, Weight And Load
6-2-3-1: Temporary Prohibition Of Certain Classes Of Vehicles
6-2-3-2: Vehicles Exceeding Limits; Police Escorts And Special Permits
6-2-3-3: Exceptions
6-2-3-4: Enforcement And Penalties
6-2-4: Penalties
6-2-1: ADOPTION OF THE ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE:
There is hereby adopted by the village of South Barrington and made a part of
this code and incorporated herein by specific reference for the purpose of
regulating and controlling traffic on the streets, within the village, the
Illinois vehicle code being 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 et seq.,
together with all amendments thereto that may, from time to time, be adopted.
(Ord. 2008-858, 6-12-2008)
6-2-2: EXCEPTIONS AND ADDITIONS TO CODE:
The following are exceptions and additions to the Illinois vehicle code, 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-101 et seq.:
Exceptions: Paragraph 1-114 (Commercial Vehicle).
Additions:
Commercial Vehicle. Any vehicle operated for the transportation of persons or
property in the furtherance of any commercial or industrial enterprise or other
non-personal use, for-hire, not including a commuter van, a vehicle used in a
ridersharing arrangement, or a recreational vehicle not being used
commercially.
Operator. Every person who operates or is in actual physical control of a
vehicle.
Property Line. The line marking the boundary between any public way and the
private property abutting thereon.
Public Way. Any sidewalk, roadway, alley or other public thoroughfare open to
the use of the public, as a matter of right, for purposes of travel.
Supervision. A disposition of conditional and revocable release without
probationary supervision, but under such conditions and reporting requirements
as are imposed by the court, at the successful conclusion of which disposition
the defendant is discharged and a judgment dismissing the charges is entered.
Through Traffic. A vehicle taking a route over any road or highway, or portion
thereof, under the maintenance jurisdiction of the village, without trip
origination or destination without the village or to or from a location whose
only means of ingress and egress is along said road or highway. (Ord. 0-85-218,
2-14-1985)
6-2-3: VEHICLE SIZE, WEIGHT AND LOAD:
6-2-3-1: TEMPORARY PROHIBITION OF CERTAIN CLASSES OF VEHICLES:
   A.   Whenever any highway or road, or parts thereof, under the jurisdiction
of this village, by reason of deterioration, rain, snow or other climatic
conditions, will be seriously damaged or destroyed by the use of trucks or
other commercial vehicles, the operation of said vehicles thereon shall be
prohibited.
   B.   The chairman of the village road committee or the chief of police is
hereby authorized to determine and designate the time and the highways or
roads, or parts thereof, which shall be so seriously damaged or destroyed as
above provided, and shall so advise the village board of trustees. The board of
trustees, by resolution, may prohibit the operation of trucks or other
commercial vehicles over and upon such roads or highways, or parts thereof, so
designated; provided, that said prohibition shall not exceed ninety (90) days
in any one calendar year.
   C.   Upon enacting such resolution, the board of trustees shall cause to be
erected and maintained regulatory signs designating the provision of the
resolution at each end of that portion of any highway or road, or parts
thereof, affected thereby, and the resolution shall not be effective unless and
until such signs are erected and maintained.
   D.   If the village president (or in his absence, the president pro tem)
shall determine that any roads or highways, or parts thereof, might suffer
serious damage prior to the time in which the board of trustees could meet for
the purpose of taking remedial action as provided in subsections B and C of
this section, then in such emergency the president (or in his absence, the
president pro tem) may act alone in prohibiting the operation of trucks or
other commercial vehicles over and upon such roads or highways, or parts
thereof, and may direct the erection of regulatory signs at each end of such
road or highway, or parts thereof, affected thereby.
   E.   The board of trustees, at its next regular meeting called after action
taken by the president or president pro tem, as provided above, shall either
confirm said action by resolution or extend said prohibition for a period not
to exceed ninety (90) days or, by resolution, direct that the signs be removed
and declare that no emergency exists. (Ord. 0-86-242, 4-10-1986)
6-2-3-2: VEHICLES EXCEEDING LIMITS; POLICE ESCORTS AND SPECIAL PERMITS:
   A.   Police Escorts And Special Permit Required: Each vehicle exceeding the
size, weight and load limitations of this chapter may be operated on the roads
and streets under the jurisdiction of the village only with a police escort and
a special written permit issued from the office of the village clerk.
   B.   Application For Special Permit: Application for a special permit shall
be made in writing to the village clerk, and shall:
      1.   State if the applicant is an authorized carrier under the Illinois
motor carrier of property act; if so, provide the certificate, registration or
permit number issued by the Illinois commerce commission;
      2.   Specifically describe the vehicle or vehicles and the load to be
operated or moved, and indicate that such permit is requested for a single
trip;
      3.   State the points of origin and destination of the vehicle or
vehicles to be operated under the special permit;
      4.   State if the vehicles or loads will be transported for hire;
      5.   State the gross weight, axle weight, height, width and length of the
vehicle.
   C.   Conditions Of Permit: The village clerk is authorized to issue permits
hereunder, subject to the following conditions:
      1.   No permit shall issue until the applicant shall have supplied the
village clerk with a surety bond in the amount of twenty five thousand dollars
($25,000.00) to compensate for any damage to any road or road structure.
      2.   In establishing the routes to be traveled, the chief of police shall
establish the most direct and shortest route consistent with the public safety,
and taking into consideration existing traffic, the character of the road or
roads, and the configuration of the terrain.
      3.   Every permit shall be in writing and shall be carried in the driving
compartment of the vehicle or combination of vehicles to which it refers, and
shall be open to inspection by any police officer or authorized agent of the
village.
      4.   The fees for such permits shall be as follows:
Single round trip permit (each trip shall require a separate permit): One
hundred dollars ($100.00).
In addition, the fee for police escort shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00)
for a single round trip.
      5.   Payment of fees authorized by this section shall be made to the
village clerk. No permit shall be issued until such fees have been paid. All
money received under the terms of this section shall be deposited in the
general corporate fund. No refund shall be made to applicant following the
issuance of a permit if the move is not completed.
      6.   The village clerk may refuse to issue such a permit if in the
opinion of the village engineer, by reason of deterioration, rain, snow or
other climatic conditions, any roads or road structure or part thereof under
the jurisdiction of the village may suffer damage in excess of the amount of
the aforesaid surety bond. (Ord. 2016-1128, 7-14-2016)
6-2-3-3: EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   The provisions of this chapter governing size, weight and load shall
not apply to:
      1.   Fire apparatus;
      2.   Equipment for snow and ice removal operations owned or operated by
any governmental body, or required or directed by the village;
      3.   Implements of husbandry temporarily operated or towed in a
combination upon a road, street or highway in this village, provided that such
combination does not consist of more than three (3) vehicles or, in the case of
having fresh, perishable fruits or vegetables from farm to the point of first
processing, not more than three (3) wagons being towed by an implement of
husbandry 1 ;
      4.   School buses as defined in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-182.
   B.   The provisions of this chapter governing weight shall not apply to:
      1.   Vehicles (including loads) operated by a public utility when
transporting equipment required for emergency repair of public utility
facilities or properties, or vehicles transporting equipment required for the
emergency repair of water wells or septic systems;
      2.   Trucks used exclusively for garbage or refuse disposal equipped with
self-compactors but not containing industrial roll-off hoists and roll-off
containers, provided that such vehicles do not exceed the following weight
limitations:
         22,000 pounds per single axle
         40,000 pounds per tandem axle
         54,000 gross vehicle
      3.   A tow truck under instructions from a police officer to legally
clear, remove or impound a vehicle. (Ord. 2016-1128, 7-14-2016)

1 1. As defined in 625 ILCS 5/1-130.
6-2-3-4: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES:
Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of section
6-2-3-1 and/or
6-2-3-2 of this chapter, of a regulatory sign, or overweight on registration,
the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty of such violation
and either the owner or the driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such
violation. Any person convicted of any violation of section
6-2-3-1 and/or
6-2-3-2 of this chapter including, but not limited to, a maximum axle or gross
limit specified on a regulatory sign, shall be fined according to the following
schedule:

                             removed to conform to all legal weights

   From 3,501 through 4,00600.00
   From 4,001 through 4,50850.00
   From 4,501 through 5,00950.00

                             fractions thereof
 
In addition, any person, firm or corporation convicted of four (4) or more
violations of any of section
6-2-3-1 and/or
6-2-3-2 of this chapter within any twelve (12) month period shall be fined an
additional amount of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for the
fourth and each subsequent conviction within the twelve (12) month period;
provided, however, that with regard to a firm or corporation, a fourth or
subsequent conviction shall mean a fourth or subsequent conviction attributable
to any employee-driver. (Ord. 2016-1128, 7-14-2016)
6-2-4: PENALTIES:
   A.   Except as otherwise provided herein, any person violating any
provisions of this chapter shall be punished by a fine as provided by reference
to the applicable provisions of the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/15-100 et seq., as provided by reference to applicable
provisions of the Illinois vehicle code. Each day any violation of any
provision of this chapter shall continue shall constitute a separate offense.
Notwithstanding anything contained in this chapter, any court of competent
jurisdiction shall be authorized to enter an order of supervision or
conditional discharge as provided by the Illinois unified code of corrections,
730 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-1-1 et seq., for any violation of any
provisions of this chapter.
   B.   Failure to obtain a permit as required by this section may be
prosecuted administratively or through the circuit court. The penalty shall be
no less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 2016-1128, 7-14-2016)

6-3-1: STREET DEFINED:
For purposes of applying any and all traffic regulations in the village,
"street" shall be defined as the entire width between boundary lines of every
way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public
for purposes of vehicular travel, and shall include those ways dedicated but
not yet accepted by the village pursuant to its subdivision regulations 1 .
(Ord. 0-79-143, 11-8-1979)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 11 of this code.
6-3-2: SPEED RESTRICTIONS ON STREETS UNDER THE EXCLUSIVE JURISDICTION OF THE
VILLAGE:
   A.   Speed Restrictions Generally: The village president and board of
trustees of the village hereby find that the safe maximum reasonable speed
limit for the streets and highways under the exclusive jurisdiction of the
village is twenty five (25) miles per hour unless otherwise provided herein.
   B.   Speed Restrictions In School Zones: School zones include both sides of
that part of the public highway in front of any public elementary, middle or
high school or parochial school, and extending not less than three hundred feet
(300') in either direction from such school property. Such area shall be marked
as a school zone by official traffic signs and the safe maximum reasonable
speed limit for the streets and highways in said school zone is twenty (20)
miles per hour. Proper signs indicating the maximum speed limit applicable to
those streets under the exclusive jurisdiction of the village shall be posted
as provided by law. The following school zones are hereby established:
      Barbara Rose School: Penny Road and Bartlett Road subject to Cook County
jurisdiction
   C.   Speed Restriction In Park Zones: Park zones include both sides of that
part of the public highway adjacent to any public park, and extending not less
than three hundred feet (300') in either direction from such park property.
Such area shall be marked as a park zone by official traffic signs and the safe
maximum reasonable speed limit for the streets and highways in said park zone
is twenty (20) miles per hour. Proper signs indicating the maximum speed limit
applicable to those streets under the exclusive jurisdiction of the village
shall be posted as provided by law. The following park zones are hereby
established:
      Bridges Drive from Bartlett Road west to Regency entrance
      Witt Road from Penny Road south to Dalton Court
   D.   Signs Posted: Proper signs indicating the maximum speed limit
applicable to those streets under the exclusive jurisdiction of the village
shall be posted as provided by law. (Ord. 2008-858, 6-12-2008)

(Rep. by Ord. 2008-858, 6-12-2008)
6-3-3: STOP STREETS:
   A.   Purpose: Traffic investigations have been made concerning the
intersections referred to in this section, and as a result of such traffic
investigations, the village president and board of trustees hereby find that
the establishment of the stop entrances to the intersections described in this
section are necessary and reasonable for the safety of the persons using the
public streets within the village.
   B.   Operation Of Vehicle At Stop Intersections: The driver of a vehicle
shall stop in obedience to a stop sign at an intersection where a stop sign is
erected pursuant to this section, and shall proceed cautiously, yielding to the
vehicles not so obliged to stop which are within the intersection or
approaching so close as to constitute an immediate hazard, unless traffic at
such intersection is controlled by a police officer on duty, in which event the
directions of the police officer shall be complied with.
   C.   Stop Streets Designated: The following are hereby designated as stop
entrances:

6-3-5: U-TURNS PROHIBITED:

in the opposite direction at the following locations:
Barrington Road: Studio Drive north to Tennis Club Lane
   B.   Proper signage shall be posted at all locations within the village
where U-turns are prohibited. (Ord. 2008-858, 6-12-2008)
6-3-6: THROUGH TRAFFIC PROHIBITED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for the driver of any motor vehicle to use Revere
Drive as a through street to travel continuously from its intersection with
Penny Road through its entire length through its intersection with Mundhank
Road.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for the driver of any motor vehicle to use North
Liberty Drive or South Liberty Drive as a through street to travel continuously
from their respective intersections with Bartlett Road through their entire
length through their respective intersections with Champlain Road.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for the driver of any motor vehicle to use Spring
Creek Drive as a through street to travel continuously from its intersection
with Penny Road to its intersection with Beacon Hill Drive and thereafter west
to its intersection with Bartlett Road.
   D.   It shall be unlawful for the driver of any motor vehicle to use Beacon
Hill Drive as a through street to travel continuously from its intersection
with Bartlett Road through its intersection with Spring Creek Drive and
thereafter south through its intersection with Penny Road.
   E.   The chief of police or his designee is hereby directed to cause the
installation of appropriate regulatory signage identifying North Liberty Drive,
South Liberty Drive, Revere Drive, Spring Creek Drive and Beacon Hill Drive as
"local traffic only". (Ord. 0-98-556, 11-12-1998)

CHAPTER 4
PARKING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
6-4-1: General
6-4-2: Unauthorized Use Of Parking Places For Persons With Disabilities
6-4-3: Recreational Vehicles
6-4-4: Exceptions, Parking Enforcement
6-4-5: Penalty Provisions
6-4-1: GENERAL:
   A.   Parking On Village Streets: It shall be unlawful to stand or park any
vehicle on any public street of the village between the hours of one o'clock
(1:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M.
   B.   Parking With Left Wheels To Curb: It shall be unlawful to stand or park
any vehicle on any public street of the village when the vehicle's left wheels
are to the parkway or curb.
   C.   Parking In A Designated Fire Lane: It shall be unlawful to park any
vehicle in any area designated by sign or otherwise as a fire lane.
   D.   Stopping, Standing Or Parking Prohibited In Specified Places:
      1.   Prohibited Places: It shall be unlawful to stop, stand or park a
vehicle:
         a.   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge
or curb of a street;
         b.   On a sidewalk;
         c.   Within an intersection;
         d.   On a crosswalk;
         e.   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet
(30') of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone,
unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings;
         f.   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when
stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic;
         g.   At any place where official signs prohibit stopping;
         h.   In the area between roadways of a divided highway, including
crossovers;
         i.   In a public parking area if the vehicle does not display a
current annual registration sticker or current temporary permit pending
registration;
         j.   That is an intercity vehicle that does not have prior approval as
set forth subsection E. of this section.
      2.   Excepted Locations: It shall be unlawful to stand or park a vehicle,
whether occupied or not, except momentarily to pick up or discharge passengers:
         a.   In front of a public or private driveway;
         b.   Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant, including a dry
hydrant;
         c.   Within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk at an intersection;
         d.   Within thirty feet (30') upon the approach to any flashing
signal, stop sign, yield sign, or traffic control signal located at the side of
a roadway;
         e.   At any place where official signs prohibit standing.
      3.   Additional Exception: This exception shall not apply to intercity
vehicles unless prior approval has been granted by the chief of police of the
village or his or her designee. It shall be unlawful to park a vehicle, whether
occupied or not, except temporarily for the purpose of and while actually
engaged in loading or unloading property or passengers at any place where
official signs prohibit parking.
      4.   Temporary Parking Restrictions:
         a.   At any place within the village where official temporary signs
prohibit the stopping, standing or parking of motor vehicles. Temporary
stopping, standing and parking restrictions shall become effective upon the
chief of police declaring that parking is prohibited by order of the South
Barrington police department and the placement of temporary signage stating "No
Parking Any Time". Temporary stopping, standing and parking restrictions shall
remain in effect until the temporary signage is removed by the police chief or
his designee.
         b.   It shall be unlawful for any person other than the chief of
police or his designee to place or remove any signage that restricts or
prohibits the temporary stopping, standing or parking of motor vehicles.
   E.   Intercity Vehicles.
      1.   Definitions, The following words, terms and phrases, when used in
this subsection shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this subsection,
except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
CHIEF OF POLICE: The chief of police of the village or his or her designee.
INTERCITY VEHICLE: Any bus, recreational vehicle or other vehicle used for
transporting more than three (3) individuals between the village and locations
outside of the village, but shall not include vehicles owned or leased by the
village and buses of the Chicago Transit Authority or another component of the
Regional Transportation Authority including, but not limited to. the suburban
bus commonly known as “Pace.”
      2.   Additional Requirements for Intercity Vehicles.
         a.   No owner or operator of any intercity vehicle shall use any
designated bus stop, bus stand, passenger loading’unloading zone or any other
location for loading or unloading of passengers, luggage or other goods without
first obtaining the approval of the chief of police. The prohibition in this
subsection shall not apply to: (i) intercity buses or shuttle buses that are
exclusively used to transfer passengers to trains operated by the National
Railroad Passenger Corporation, commonly known as “Amtrak” and/or the Northeast
Illinois Rail Corporation, commonly known as “Metra”; (ii) school buses while
on authorized school business/ activities; (iii) taxicabs, limousines,
ridesharing vehicles, including Ubers and Lyfts, or similar vehicles used for
private hire by persons working or residing within the village or by persons
visiting a specific residence or place of business located within the village
when allowed or authorized by the owner of the property; (iv) non-commercial
vehicles with a gross vehicle weight rating that is less than 16,000 pounds
that are owned, leased or used by a resident or local business in carry ing out
ordinary business or customary activities of said business or resident; or (v)
any commercial vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating that exceeds 16.000
pounds if that vehicle is transporting persons as part of a past practice that
has been occurring prior to January 1,2020.
         b.   Application for such approval shall be made to the chief of
police and shall contain the name and address of the applicant, the location of
the proposed bus stop, bus stand, passenger loading/unloading zone or other
location where such loading or unloading of passengers, luggage or other goods
shall take place, the time of day and length of time any such intercity vehicle
shall stand in the proposed bus stop, bus stand, passenger loading/unloading
zone or other location, and the number of intercity vehicles that shall leave
from and come to the proposed bus stop, bus stand, passenger loading unloading
zone or other location per day. The application shall be signed by the
applicant. The chief of police shall approve or deny the application no later
than thirty (30) days after the application was filed with the village.
         c.   The chief of police’s review of the application shall take into
consideration administrative efficiency and available resources, public safety
and orderly traffic flow, and an approval shall be subject to such conditions
and restrictions that the chief of police may impose in his or her sole
discretion (including, without limitation, those addressing day/time
availability of any such location(s), number of daily arrivals/departures to/
from any such location(s), and advance notification requirements by the
applicant). The chief of police may also require certified medical
documentation that passengers are not presently, and have not within the last
thirty (30) days prior to the date of unloading, been diagnosed or have
contracted any contagious disease such as malaria, tuberculosis or such other
contagious disease that, if spread to others, would adversely affect others
health, safety or welfare; provided, however, that such certification shall not
be required of domiciled residents of the United States who have not, within
the last thirty (30) days prior to unloading, traveled to a country
experiencing an outbreak of any such contagious disease.
         d.   If the chief of police denies the application, it shall be based
upon a determination that the loading unloading of passengers, luggage or other
goods at that time, or in that particular designated bus stop, bus stand,
passenger loading/unloading zone or other location presents an unreasonable
threat to the health, safety and welfare of the public or impedes the safe and
efficient flow of traffic or imposes an unreasonable burden on available
resources. If the chief of police denies the application, the chief of police
shall send by e-mail or U.S. mail a notification to the applicant in writing
specifying the reasons for the decision. Any applicant may seek review of the
decision of the chief of police denying such application in the manner provided
by law. (Ord. 0-97-521, 10-9-1997; amd. Ord. 2007-806, 4-12-2007; Ord. 2023-
1390, 12-28-2023)
6-4-2: UNAUTHORIZED USE OF PARKING PLACES FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to park, stop or leave standing any motor
vehicle, whether attended or unattended, which is not bearing registration
plates or decals issued to a person with disabilities in any parking place,
including any private or public off street parking facilities, specifically
reserved, by the posting of an official sign as designated, under section 11-
301 of the Illinois motor vehicle code 1 , for motor vehicles bearing such
registration plates or decals. It shall be further unlawful to park, stop or
leave standing any motor vehicle, whether attended or unattended, in a
designated access aisle adjacent to any parking place specifically reserved for
persons with disabilities, by the posting of an official sign as designated,
under section 11-301 of the Illinois vehicle code 2 , for motor vehicles
bearing such registration plates or decals. (Ord. 2008-858, 6-12-2008)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/11-301.
2 2. 625 ILCS 5/11-301.
6-4-3: RECREATIONAL VEHICLES:
   A.   Definitions. For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and
phrases shall be construed to have the meanings ascribed to them in this
section, unless it is apparent from the context that a different meaning is
intended:
      1.   Day: any twenty-four (24) hour period.
      2.   Recreational Vehicle or RV: every camping trailer, boat, or similar
water vehicle, motor home, mini-motor home, travel trailer, truck camper or van
camper or other similar vehicle used primarily for recreational purposes. See,
e.g. 625 ILCS 5/1-169.
      3.   Resident: a person who physically resides within the village or who
maintains a legal place of residence or who owns land within the village. It
shall not mean a person who maintains an address at a mailbox drop or who rents
a room that is not his or her primary place of residence nor shall it mean a
person who maintains only a post office box, unless that person also provides
evidence of residence at a street address within the village.
   B.   Permission required. No person shall park, stop, or leave standing any
recreational vehicle on any residential driveway, except after providing a
written or telephonic request to the department of police of the village. The
request shall note the affected address of the property in question. The person
parking, stopping, or leaving the recreational vehicle, and if a separate
individual is the resident where the RV is to be parked, shall each jointly and
severally assume and bear responsibility for the making of said request. The
request shall be deemed approved unless the requestor or a resident where the
RV is to be parked is otherwise notified by the village.
   C.   Temporary RV Parking. The purpose of the temporary RV parking is to
allow users of recreational vehicles to park in the driveway of a residence to
load, unload, clean and maintain their recreational vehicles for a limited
period of time, not to exceed a day. A separate incidence of RV parking shall
mean any portion of a day. By way of example, if a resident parks a
recreational vehicle for a period of fifteen (15 ) minutes, a day shall be
counted.
      1.   Residential Zones. Temporary RV parking shall only be permitted in
residential zones of the village. No more than one (1) recreational vehicle
shall be permitted to park at any residential address at any given time, unless
the RV is towing another recreational vehicle.
      2.   Parking Restrictions. There shall be no more than fourteen (14)
separate days when a resident may have an RV parked in their residential
driveway during any calendar year. Each day or portion of a day must be
separate and distinct, and no user of a recreational vehicle may combine or
bank days. Any part of a day shall count as a whole day.
   D.   Prohibited Activities. No person shall:
      1.   Use slide outs, pop outs or other appurtenances on a recreational
vehicle that encroach on or into the roadway, parkway and/or sidewalk in such a
manner as to interfere with the path of safe travel of vehicles or pedestrians;
      2.   Open or partially open any awnings on a recreational vehicle in such
a manner as to interfere with the path of safe travel of vehicles and/or
pedestrians:
      3.   Cause or permit any utility connections, electrical cords, extension
cords, hoses or cables to cross over, above, on or across any street or
sidewalk to or from a recreational vehicle with the uses limited to loading,
unloading, and maintaining the RV:
      4.   Use power generators or other noise-generating equipment between the
hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. within or adjacent to a recreational vehicle;
      5.   Conduct any commercial activity with an RV, including renting or
leasing an RV, while parked in a residential district;
      6.   Connect a recreational vehicle to the public sewer system or dump
waste onto public or private land or into streets, gutters, or storm drains,
other than lawfully at a designated, licensed and permitted recreational
vehicle sanitary wastewater dump station; or
      7.   Knowingly allow any ty pe of grease, oil, fuel or other harmful
substance to leak or be emitted onto any public right of way.
   E.   Revocation.
      1.   The chief of police shall have the authority to revoke temporary RV
parking permission if the chief of police makes any one of the following
findings:
         a.   The recreational vehicle has fallen into a state of disrepair and
has become a public nuisance, or a danger to pedestrians or other vehicles:
         b.   The recreational vehicle has become inoperable; and/or
         c.   There has been a violation of this section.
   F.   To revoke RV parking permission, the chief of police shall issue a
notice of revocation in writing to the grantee specifying the basis for and the
effective date of the revocation. To the extent permission expires pursuant to
its own terms before the effective date of such revocation, the chief of police
may use such revocation as a basis to deny a future request from the same
requester. The chief of police's determination to revoke temporary RV parking
permission shall be final. (Ord. 2023-1357, 3-22-2023)
6-4-4: EXCEPTIONS, PARKING ENFORCEMENT:
Except as specifically set forth in this code, a written or telephonic request
may be submitted to the chief of police of the village for the purpose of
regulating vehicle parking and traffic upon private property, which includes
the parking and storage of vehicles set forth in chapter 9 of the Zoning
Ordinance titled "Vehicle Storage and Parking Regulations." The request must be
submitted by the owner(s) of the property or the person(s) having a legal right
to manage or control the property. After such written request has been approved
by the village, such property shall be subject to all of the provisions of this
chapter or chapter 9 of the Zoning Ordinance. (Ord. 0-97-521, 10-9-1997; amd.
Ord. 2023-1357, 3-22-2023)
6-4-5: PENALTY PROVISIONS:
   A.   Penalties: The penalty for any violation of this chapter, other than
the disability provisions of section
6-4-2 and the recreational vehicles provision of section
6-4-3 of this chapter, shall be not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) and
not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00); provided, however, that in the
event that the owner or operator does not make payment to the village within
fourteen (14) calendar days after the date of the personal issuance of a ticket
or the issuance of a hang-on ticket as specified in a final notice, the penalty
shall be forty dollars ($40.00) for such violation. The penalty for any
violation of section
6-4-2, "Unauthorized Use Of Parking Places For Persons With Disabilities" of
this chapter shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00). The penalty for any
violation of section
6-4-3. "Recreational Vehicles" of this chapter, shall not be more than five
hundred dollars $500.00). The penalty for any violation of subsection
6-4-1 E. “Intercity Vehicles” of this chapter shall not be more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) and the seizure and impoundment of the intercity
vehicle in accordance with applicable laws. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed of each day any violation under this chapter occurs or continues.
   B.   Procedure On Nonpayment Of Penalty Fee: In the event that the person to
whom a citation is issued pursuant to this section fails to settle and pay said
violation within the prescribed time, or within a period of time specified in a
final notice, then the police officer or the designated village employee or
entity is authorized to cause a notice to appear to be served upon said alleged
violator by personal service or certified mail, return receipt requested, and
is authorized to file a complaint and to prosecute the same in the circuit
court of the appropriate county. (Ord. 0-2006-796, 12-14-2006; amd. Ord. 2023-
1357, 3-22-2023; Ord. 2023-1390, 12-28-2023)
CHAPTER 5
ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
6-5-1: Enforcement Of Traffic Code In Certain Subdivisions
6-5-1: ENFORCEMENT OF TRAFFIC CODE IN CERTAIN SUBDIVISIONS:
   A.   Subject to the provisions set forth in subsection B below, the
provisions of Chapters 2 and 3 of this Title shall be enforceable in
subdivisions where the streets and public improvements have not yet been
accepted by the Village Board of Trustees; provided, however, that the
enforcement of the traffic laws of this Village in such subdivisions shall in
no event be deemed to constitute an acceptance of the streets or public
improvements in such subdivision.
   B.   In the event any person or board of directors owning, operating, or
representing a residential subdivision as described above files a written
request with the Village Clerk pursuant to the provisions of the Illinois
Vehicle Code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-209.1, the Village shall,
upon the adoption of an ordinance, enforce the traffic laws on private streets
and roads in such subdivision. (Ord. 0-96-482, 3-14-1996)
CHAPTER 6
SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES USED IN THE COMMISSION OF OFFENSES
SECTION:
6-6-1: Vehicle Seizure And Impoundment
6-6-2: Existing Regulations Not Abrogated
6-6-3: Exceptions
6-6-4: Notice
6-6-5: Hearings
6-6-6: Administrative Penalty
6-6-7: Vehicle Possession
6-6-8: Hearing Officer
6-6-9: Decision Review
6-6-1: VEHICLE SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT:
   A.   Seizure And Impoundment By Village: Any motor vehicle operated or used,
with the express or implied permission of the registered owner of record (as
registered with the Secretary of State of the State of Illinois, or the
appropriate authority of another State) during the commission of or in
furtherance of any offense or violation set forth in subsection B of this
section, shall be subject to seizure and impoundment by the Village, and the
owner of record of said vehicle may be liable to the Village for a civil
penalty in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), in addition to any
towing and storage fees as hereinafter provided.
   B.   Violations Or Offenses Subject To Seizure And Impoundment:
      1.   Operating or in physical control of a motor vehicle while driver’s
license, permit, or privilege to operate a motor vehicle is suspended or
revoked (625 ILCS 5/6-303); or a similar Local Ordinance, except that vehicles
shall not be subjected to seizure and impoundment if the suspension is for
violation of the Vehicle Emissions Inspection Law of 2005 625 ILCS 5/13c-1 et
seq., or for an unpaid citation (parking or moving); or
      2.   Operating or in physical control of a motor vehicle while under the
influence of alcohol, other drug or drugs, intoxicating compound or compounds,
or any combination thereof 1 ; or
      3.   Unlawful use of a firearm (UUW) 2 ; or
      4.   Operation of a motor vehicle during the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, a felony or in violation of Cannabis Control Act 3 ; or
      5.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission or attempted
commission of any offense for which a motor vehicle may be seized and forfeited
pursuant to section 36-1 of the Criminal Code of 2012; or
      6.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle by a person against whom a
warrant for arrest has been issued by a circuit clerk in Illinois for failing
to appear in court and answer charges that the driver violated section 6-303 or
11-501 of the Illinois Vehicle Code.
      7.   Operation or use of an intercity vehicle in violation of subsection
6-4-1 E. “Intercity Vehicles” of the village code. (Ord. 2014-1019, 5-8-2014;
amd. Ord. 2019-1220, 12-12-2019; Ord. 2020-1257, 12-10-2020; Ord. 2023-1382,
10-12-2023; Ord. 2023-1390, 12-28-2023)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/11-501.
2 2. 720 ILCS 5/24-1.
3 3. 720 ILCS 550/1 et seq.
6-6-2: EXISTING REGULATIONS NOT ABROGATED:
   A.   The provisions of this chapter shall be in addition to and shall not
replace or otherwise abrogate any existing state or federal law or village
ordinance that relates to the seizure and/or impoundment of motor vehicles, and
any penalty provided herein shall be in addition to any and all penalties that
may be assessed or imposed by a court for violation of any criminal offense or
local ordinance violation offense.
   B.   Any and all fees for towing and storage of a vehicle under this chapter
shall be those approved by the Chief of Police for all towing companies
authorized to tow for the Village. (Ord. 2014-1019, 5-8-2014; amd. Ord. 2023-
1382, 10-12-2023)
6-6-3: EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter are inapplicable if at the time of the offense
the vehicle used in the violation was stolen and the theft was reported to the
appropriate police authority within twenty-four (24) hours after the theft was
discovered, or the vehicle was otherwise operated without the knowledge and
express or implied consent of the registered owner. (Ord. 2014-1019, 5-8-2014;
amd. Ord. 2023-1382, 10-12-2023)
6-6-4: NOTICE:
Whenever a police officer has probable cause to believe that a vehicle is
subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to this chapter, and the police
officer has effected an arrest for any of the offenses set forth in subsection
6-6-1-B of this chapter, the police officer shall provide for the towing of the
vehicle to a facility authorized by the Village. Prior to or at the time the
vehicle is towed, the police officer shall notify or make a reasonable attempt
to notify the owner or any person identifying himself as the owner of the
vehicle, or any person who is found to be in control of the vehicle at the time
of the alleged offense, of the fact of the seizure and of the vehicle owner’s
right to request a preliminary vehicle impoundment hearing and hearing to be
conducted in accordance with section
6-6-5 of this chapter. The vehicle shall be impounded pending the completion of
the hearing(s) provided for in subsections
6-6-5-A and B of this chapter, unless the owner of the vehicle posts with the
Village a cash bond in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) and pays
the towing and storage charges. (Ord. 2014-1019, 5-8-2014; amd. Ord. 2023-1382,
10-12-2023)
6-6-5: HEARINGS:
   A.   Preliminary Hearing: If the owner or lessee of record of a vehicle
seized and impounded desires to contest the seizure and impoundment of the
vehicle he or she must make a request for a preliminary hearing within twenty-
four (24) hours of the seizure. The request shall be deemed filed upon delivery
to the Chief of Police in care of the South Barrington Police Department. The
preliminary hearing request shall be in writing and the Chief of Police or his/
her designee shall conduct the preliminary hearing within twenty-four (24)
hours after receipt of the request, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, or Village
holidays, in which case the preliminary hearing shall be heard on the next
business day after the request. All interested parties shall be given a
reasonable opportunity to be heard at the preliminary hearing. The formal rules
of evidence shall not apply at the preliminary hearing, and hearsay evidence
shall be admissible only if it is of the type commonly relied upon by
reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs. If, after the
preliminary hearing, the Chief of Police or his/her designee determines there
is probable cause to believe that the vehicle is subject to seizure and
impoundment, he/she shall order the continued impoundment of the vehicle as
herein provided, unless the owner of the vehicle posts with the Village a cash
bond in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), and pays any applicable
towing and storage fees. If the Chief of Police or his/her designee determines
that there is no such probable cause to believe the vehicle was used or
operated during the commission or attempted commission of the offenses set
forth in subsection
6-6-1-B of this chapter, then the vehicle shall be returned to the registered
owner without penalty or other fees.
   B.   Administrative Hearing: Unless a vehicle has been released for no
probable cause at a preliminary hearing or the owner, lessee or lienholder has
posted cash bond and agreed in writing to waive an administrative hearing, the
Village shall, within ten (10) days after a vehicle is seized and impounded,
notify the registered owner, lessee and any lienholder of record by personal
service or first class mail, postage prepaid, of the date, time, and location
of a hearing that will be conducted. The notice of hearing shall be sent to the
interested party’s address as registered with the. Secretary of State of the
State of Illinois, or the appropriate authority of another state. An initial
hearing shall be scheduled and held no later than forty-five (45) days after
mailing the notice of hearing or personal service of the notice of hearing.
Continuances shall only be granted for good cause shown. All interested persons
shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard at the hearing. At any time
prior to the hearing date, the hearing officer may, at the request of any
party, direct witnesses to appear and give testimony at the hearing. Subpoenas
for the production of witnesses and records may be issued upon request and for
good cause. The formal rules of evidence shall not apply at the hearing, and
hearsay evidence shall be admissible only if it is of the type commonly relied
upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs. If, after
the hearing, the hearing officer determines by a preponderance of the evidence
that the vehicle was used or operated in connection with or during the
commission or attempted commission of any of those offenses set forth in
subsection
6-6-1-B of this chapter, or that the police officer had reasonable cause to
believe the motor vehicle was subject to seizure and impoundment, the hearing
officer shall enter an order finding the owner of record of the vehicle civilly
liable to the Village for a civil penalty in the amount of five hundred dollars
($500.00), and requiring the vehicle to continue to be impounded until the
owner pays the civil penalty to the Village plus any and all fees to the tower
and/or Village for the towing and storage of the vehicle as the case may be.
If, after proper service of notice, the owner of record fails to appear at the
hearing, the hearing officer shall conduct the hearing in absentia and, if
appropriate, enter an order finding in favor of the Village, a copy of which
order shall be sent to the registered owner, lessee and/or lienholder of record
by first class mail, postage prepaid. If at the hearing the hearing officer
finds that no such violation occurred, or reasonable cause did not exist, the
hearing officer shall order the immediate return of the vehicle and any bond
posted to the owner without assessing any fees or penalty. (Ord. 2014-1019, 5-
8-2014; amd. Ord. 2020-1257, 12-10-2020; Ord. 2023-1382, 10-12-2023)
6-6-6: ADMINISTRATIVE PENALTY:
If a civil penalty is imposed, the penalty shall constitute a debt due and
owing to the Village of South Barrington. If a cash bond has been posted the
bond shall be applied to the penalty. If a vehicle remains impounded when a
penalty is imposed, the Village may seek to obtain a judgment on the debt and
enforce such judgment against the vehicle as provided by law. Except as may
otherwise be provided in this chapter, a vehicle shall continue to be impounded
until the civil penalty is paid to the Village and any applicable towing and
storage fees are paid to the tower and/or Village, as the case may be, in which
case possession of the vehicle shall be given to the person who is legally
entitled to possess the vehicle, or the vehicle is sold or otherwise disposed
of to satisfy a judgment and lien as provided by law. If the civil penalty and
applicable towing and storage fees are not paid within thirty (30) days after
the expiration of time in which administrative review of the hearing officer’s
determination may be sought, or within thirty (30) days after an action seeking
administrative review has been resolved in favor of the Village, whichever is
applicable, the vehicle shall be deemed unclaimed and shall be disposed of in
the manner provided by law for the disposition of unclaimed vehicles under the
Illinois Vehicle Code. (Ord. 2014-1019, 5-8-2014; amd. Ord. 2020-1257, 12-10-
2020; Ord. 2023-1382, 10-12-2023)
6-6-7: VEHICLE POSSESSION:
Except as may otherwise be provided by law or by order of the hearing officer,
no owner, lessee, lienholder, or other person shall be legally entitled to take
possession of a seized and impounded vehicle until the civil penalty and towing
and storage fees have been paid. However, whenever a person or other entity
with a lien of record against an impounded vehicle has commenced foreclosure
proceedings prior to the date of the motor vehicle seizure or impoundment,
possession of the vehicle shall be given to that person or entity if the
lienholder of record agrees in writing to refund to the Village the amount of
the net proceeds of any foreclosure sale, less any amounts required to pay all
lienholders of record, not to exceed the civil penalty, plus the applicable
towing and storage fees. (Ord. 2014-1019, 5-8-2014; amd. Ord. 2020-1257, 12-10-
2020; Ord. 2023-1382, 10-12-2023)
6-6-8: HEARING OFFICER:
The hearing officer shall be appointed by the Village President of the Village
of South Barrington, and he or she shall be an attorney licensed to practice
law in the State of Illinois for a minimum of three (3) years next preceding
the date of his/her appointment. (Ord. 2014-1019, 5-8-2014; amd. Ord. 2023-
1382, 10-12-2023)
6-6-9: DECISION REVIEW:
Any party may appeal a final decision of the hearing officer pursuant to the
provision of the Illinois Administrative Review Law 1 . (Ord. 2014-1019, 5-8-
2014; amd. Ord. 2023-1382, 10-12-2023)
 
Notes
1 1. 735 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.
TITLE 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
SECTION:
7-1-1: Roadway And Driveway Specifications In Industrial And Commercial Areas
7-1-2: Maintenance Of Swales And Drainage Ditches
7-1-3: Wage Rates For Public Works Employees
7-1-4: Road Improvement Projects
7-1-4-1: FA Route 173
7-1-4-2: Barrington Road
7-1-4-3: Algonquin Road
7-1-1: ROADWAY AND DRIVEWAY SPECIFICATIONS IN INDUSTRIAL AND COMMERCIAL AREAS:
   A.   Subgrade Preparation For Industrial And Commercial Roadways:
      1.   All topsoil and other unsuitable material shall be removed from
areas to be paved, whether in cut or fill. Fill material shall be of clay or
granular material compacted to ninety five percent (95%) of density. (Ord. 0-
72-20, 10-12-1972)
      2.   No culvert pipe shall be less than twelve inches (12") in diameter
and shall be fitted with preformed end sections. Only concrete, aluminized
corrugated metal, and plastic pipe are allowed. The length of the pipe shall be
the width of the driveway plus the radius; all plastic pipe shall be HDPE
corrugated pipe; all concrete and aluminized corrugated pipe shall meet IDOT
specifications. All culvert pipe used shall be of sufficient diameter to
provide a means for adequate drainage as determined by a licensed professional
engineer appointed by the village board. (Ord. 2016-1132, 10-10-2016)
   B.   Roadway Specifications:
      1.   Industrial Areas: Public roadways within industrial areas shall be
of minimum width of thirty feet (30'), have gravel shoulders of six feet (6'),
and have a four inch (4") crown, and shall be constructed within the minimum
standards as herein set forth.
The minimum base course for all industrial roadways shall consist of ten inch
(10") no. 9 road gravel put down in two (2) lifts of five inches (5") each,
primed with MC-O liquid asphalt at the rate of one-third (1/3) gallon per
square yard. The surface course shall consist of bituminous concrete pavement
of two inches (2") compacted thickness of bituminous concrete binder course I-
11 hot plant mix asphalt, and a one inch (1") compacted thickness of bituminous
concrete surface course I-11 hot plant mix asphalt; all constructed as per
state of Illinois highway specifications.
      2.   Commercial Areas: Public roadways within commercial areas shall be
of minimum width of twenty feet (20'), have gravel shoulders of six feet (6'),
and have a three inch (3") crown, and shall be constructed within the minimum
standards as herein set forth.
The minimum base course for all commercial roadways shall consist of eight inch
(8") no. 9 road gravel put down in two (2) lifts of four inches (4") each,
primed with MC-O liquid asphalt at the rate of one-third (1/3) gallon per
square yard. The surface course shall consist of bituminous concrete pavement
of one and one-half inches (11/2") compacted thickness of bituminous concrete
binder course I-11 hot plant mix asphalt, and a one inch (1") compacted
thickness of bituminous concrete surface course I-11 hot plant mix asphalt; all
constructed as per state of Illinois highway specifications.
   C.   Driveways:
      1.   Industrial Areas: The minimum width of driveways leading from
industrial areas onto public roadways shall be twenty feet (20') at the
property line with a ten foot (10') radius.
      2.   Commercial Areas: The minimum width of driveways leading from
commercial areas onto public roadways shall be twenty feet (20') at the
