ARTICLE C. A-3 (1 ACRE) SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENCE DISTRICT
SECTION:
4C-1: Uses Permitted
4C-2: Yard Areas
4C-3: Lot Size
4C-4: Building Height
4C-5: Dwelling Standards
4C-6: Off Street Parking And Loading
4C-1: USES PERMITTED:
No building or premises improved or unimproved shall be used and no building
shall be hereafter erected or altered within any A-3 Residence District unless
otherwise provided in this ordinance, except for the following uses:
   A.   Permitted Uses:
Accessory buildings and accessory structures, as defined in section
1-3 of this ordinance.
Churches and temples for public worship, on any zoning lot having an area of
not less than ten (10) acres, having not more than thirty percent (30%) of the
lot occupied by buildings, and having sufficient area to provide for both
building space and off street parking area as required in chapter 8 of this
ordinance.
Convents, monasteries, rectories or parish houses, to be occupied by not more
than fifteen (15) persons.
Home occupations as regulated by section
2-8 of this ordinance.
Residential off street parking facilities as regulated or permitted by chapter
8 of this ordinance.
Single-family detached dwellings.
Small residential care homes provided: 1) they are eligible to have obtained a
State license or certification or the sponsoring agency is licensed or
certified by the State to operate residential care homes; 2) they are located
not less than two thousand five hundred feet (2,500') from another small
residential care home; and 3) prior to occupancy, a certificate of zoning
compliance is applied for and received. (Ord. 2018-1180, 6-7-2018)
   B.   Special Uses: Special uses, subject to conditions and requirements of
the Architectural Control Commission provisions under title 2, chapter 4 of the
South Barrington Village Code and the special use provisions under section
11-5 of this ordinance. The following special use may be permitted in this
district:
Memory care assisted living facility, provided that such facility: 1) is
located on not less than three and one- half (3.5) acres, 2) has no more than
twenty percent (20%) of the lot occupied by structures, and 3) shall be wholly
served by the Village of South Barrington water and sewer systems. (Ord. 2012-
977, 11-8-2012)
4C-2: YARD AREAS:
   A.   Front Yard: Each lot upon which a building is constructed shall have a
setback of not less than seventy five feet (75').
   B.   Side Yards: On each lot upon which a building is constructed, there
shall be a side yard on each side of not less than twenty five feet (25'), for
uses permitted under subsection 4C-1A of this article, and fifty feet (50') for
uses under subsection 4C-1B of this article.
   C.   Rear Yards: Every lot or parcel of land upon which a building is
constructed shall have a rear yard of not less than twenty five feet (25'), for
uses permitted under subsection 4C-1A of this article, and thirty five feet
(35') for uses under subsection 4C-1B of this article.
   D.   Transition Yards: For uses permitted under subsection 4C-1B of this
article, each lot, upon which a building is constructed and adjoining the A-
1 Zoning District, shall have a landscape transition setback buffer of a
minimum of twelve feet (12') from the lot line, which transitional yard may
include public utility easements. (Ord. 2012-977, 11-8-2012)
4C-3: LOT SIZE:
   A.   Lot area: Except as provided in subsection 4C-1B of this article, not
less than one acre.
   B.   Lot width: Not less than one hundred twenty five feet (125') at the
required minimum building setback line for uses permitted under subsection 4C-
1A of this article and four hundred feet (400') for uses under subsection 4C-1B
of this article. (Ord. 2012-977, 11-8-2012)
4C-4: BUILDING HEIGHT:
Same as for the A-1 Residence District. (Ord. 2012-977, 11-8-2012)
4C-5: DWELLING STANDARDS:
Same as for the A-1 Residence District. (Ord. 2012-977, 11-8-2012)
4C-6: OFF STREET PARKING AND LOADING:
   A.   Off Street Parking: Parking spaces in accordance with the provisions
set forth in chapter 8 of this ordinance.
   B.   Off Street Loading: For nonresidential permitted uses and special uses,
loading berths in accordance with the provisions set forth in chapter 8 of this
ordinance. (Ord. 2012-977, 11-8-2012)
ARTICLE D. A-4 (30,000 SQUARE FEET MINIMUM) SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENCE DISTRICT
SECTION:
4D-1: Purpose
4D-2: Uses Permitted
4D-3: Yard Areas
4D-4: Lot Size
4D-5: Building Height
4D-6: Dwelling Standards
4D-7: Off Street Parking And Loading
4D-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the A-4 Single-Family Residence Zoning District is to provide
for a cohesive, architecturally enhanced and imaginative development plan and
subdivision, subject to and conditioned upon being located on tracts of land
that are:
   A.   No greater than twenty (20) acres; and
   B.   Served by the Village of South Barrington water system. (Ord. 2011-950,
9-22-2011)
4D-2: USES PERMITTED:
No building or premises improved or unimproved shall be used and no building
shall be hereafter erected or altered within any A-4 Single-Family Residence
District unless otherwise provided in this ordinance, except for the following
uses:
Accessory buildings and accessory structures, as defined in section
1-3 of this ordinance.
Churches and temples for public worship, on any zoning lot having an area of
not less than ten (10) acres, having not more than thirty percent (30%) of the
lot occupied by buildings, and having sufficient area to provide for both
building space and off street parking area as required in chapter 8 of this
ordinance.
Convents, monasteries, rectories or parish houses, to be occupied by not more
than fifteen (15) persons.
Home occupations as regulated by section
2-8 of this ordinance.
Residential off street parking facilities as regulated or permitted by chapter
8 of this ordinance.
Single-family detached dwellings.
Small residential care homes provided: 1) they are eligible to have obtained a
State license or certification or the sponsoring agency is licensed or
certified by the State to operate residential care homes; 2) they are located
not less than two thousand five hundred feet (2,500') from another small
residential care home; and 3) prior to occupancy, a certificate of zoning
compliance is applied for and received. (Ord. 2018-1118, 6-7-2018)
4D-3: YARD AREAS:
   A.   Front Yard: Each lot upon which a building is constructed shall have a
setback of not less than forty feet (40').
   B.   Side Yards: On each lot upon which a building is constructed, there
shall be a side yard on each side of not less than twenty five feet (25').
   C.   Rear Yards: Every lot or parcel of land upon which a building is
constructed shall have a rear yard of not less than twenty five feet (25').
(Ord. 2011-950, 9-22-2011)
4D-4: LOT SIZE:
   A.   Lot area: Not less than thirty thousand (30,000) square feet.
   B.   Lot width: Not less than one hundred twenty five feet (125') at the
required minimum building setback line. (Ord. 2011-950, 9-22-2011)
4D-5: BUILDING HEIGHT:
Same as for the A-1 Single-Family Residence District. (Ord. 2011-950, 9-22-
2011)
4D-6: DWELLING STANDARDS:
Same as for the A-1 Single-Family Residence District, except as follows:
No dwelling shall be erected or maintained in the A-4 District with gross
interior living space of the dwelling (not including those portions of the
dwelling below or partially below finish grade elevation, but excluding
garages, balconies, sunroofs or porches) which is less than three thousand five
hundred (3,500) square feet or greater than six thousand (6,000) square feet
per residence. Square footage shall be calculated by the total heated and
finished living space of the first, second and third floors only. (Ord. 2011-
950, 9-22-2011)
4D-7: OFF STREET PARKING AND LOADING:
   A.   Off Street Parking: Parking spaces in accordance with the provisions
set forth in chapter 8 of this ordinance.
   B.   Off Street Loading: For nonresidential permitted uses and special uses,
loading berths in accordance with the provisions set forth in chapter 8 of this
ordinance. (Ord. 2011-950, 9-22-2011)
CHAPTER 5
BUSINESS DISTRICTS
ARTICLE A. B-1 LIMITED RETAIL BUSINESS DISTRICT
SECTION:
5A-1: Uses Permitted
5A-2: Conditions Of Use
5A-3: Yards
5A-4: Minimum Lot Sizes
5A-5: Building Height
5A-6: Off-Street Parking And Loading
5A-7: Public Utility Easements
5A-1: USES PERMITTED:
No building or land shall be used and no building shall be erected,
structurally altered or enlarged, unless otherwise provided in this Ordinance
except for the following uses:
   A.   Retail and service uses, as follows:
      Art and school supply stores
      Art galleries
      Banks and financial institutions
      Barber shops
      Beauty shops
      Book or stationery stores
      Camera and photographic supply stores
      Carpet, rug and linoleum stores
      China and glassware stores
      Clothes pressing establishments
      Coin and philatelic stores
      Custom dressmaking and millinery shops
      Department stores
      Drugstores
      Dry-cleaning and laundry receiving stations, processing to be done
elsewhere
      Dry goods and notion stores
      Electrical and household appliances stores, including radio and
television sales
      Florist shops and conservatories
      Food stores, grocery stores, meat markets, bakeries, candy and ice cream
shops, delicatessens and frozen food stores
      Furniture stores, including upholstering when conducted as part of the
retail operations and secondary to the principal use
      Furrier shops, including the incidental storage and conditioning of furs
      Garden supply and seed stores
      Gift shops
      Haberdasheries
      Hardware stores
      Hobby shops, for retail of items to be assembled or used away from the
premises
      Interior decorating shops, including upholstering and making of
draperies, slipcovers and other similar articles, when conducted as part of the
retail operations and secondary to the principal use
      Jewelry stores, including watch repair
      Leather goods and luggage stores
      Liquor stores, package goods only
      Loan offices
      Locksmith shops
      Medical and dental clinics
      Musical instrument sales stores, including minor repair
      Office equipment and supply stores
      Optician shops
      Paint and wallpaper stores
      Photographers
      Restaurants, tearooms, outdoor sidewalk cafes and outdoor garden cafes
conducted accessory to indoor establishments
      Sewing machine stores, household machines only
      Shoe and hat repair stores
      Shoe stores
      Sporting goods stores
      Tailor shops
      Tobacco shops
      Toy shops
      Variety stores
      Wearing apparel shops
   B.   Offices - business and professional
   C.   Miscellaneous uses, as follows:
      Churches and temples for public worship, and any zoning lot having an
area of not less than ten (10) acres, having not more than thirty percent (30%)
of the lot occupancy by buildings, and having sufficient area to provide for
both building space and off-street parking area as required in Chapter 8 of
this Ordinance
      Clubs and lodges (nonprofit), fraternal or religious institutions
   D.   The following accessory uses, buildings or other structures customarily
incidental to and commonly associated with the principal use as hereby
permitted, provided they are operated and maintained under the same ownership
and on the same lot as the permitted use:
      Communication systems and equipment directly serving the primary business
at that location and screened from public view
      Temporary buildings for construction purposes, for a period not to exceed
the duration of such construction
   E.   Special uses, subject to conditions and requirements of Section
1-5 of this Ordinance as follows:
      Auditoriums, stadiums, arenas, armories, gymnasiums and other similar
places for public events
      Bus terminal or mass transportation stations
      Golf courses, public or private
      Municipal recreation buildings or community centers
      Police stations or fire stations
      Public buildings, including art galleries, libraries, museums or similar
structures
      Public or private recreation areas or clubs
      Public parks or playgrounds
      Public utility facilities, i.e., filtration plant, water reservoir or
pumping station, heat or power plant, transformer station and other similar
facilities
      Veterinarian and animal hospitals (not including open kennels)
   F.   All uses not expressly authorized in this Section
5A-1 are hereby deemed prohibited. (Ord. 0-95-460, 3-9-1995)
5A-2: CONDITIONS OF USE:
All business uses permitted in this District (except special uses) shall be
retail establishments dealing directly with consumers, and shall be subject to
the following conditions:
   A.   All retail activities, unless otherwise excepted in this Ordinance,
shall be conducted wholly within an enclosed building.
   B.   There shall be no manufacture, processing or treatment of products
other than those which are clearly incidental and essential to the retail
business conducted on the same premises.
   C.   Such uses, operations or products shall not be established, maintained
or constructed if they cause or result in a nuisance by reason of fumes, dust,
smoke, noise, vibrations or other similar causes.
   D.   The signs allowed in the B-1 District shall be the same as those
allowed in the O/R II Office/Research District, Section 5E-9 of this Ordinance.
(Ord. 0-95-460, 3-9-1995)
5A-3: YARDS:
   A.   Front Yard:
      1.   The minimum setback shall be not less than twenty five feet (25')
along streets where no off-street parking is provided in front of the building.
Where off-street parking facilities are provided in front of the building, the
minimum setback shall be measured from the front line of the off- street
parking facilities. Curbs or other traffic control facilities shall be
installed with approval of the Village Engineer in accordance with the
provisions of the ordinances of the Village.
      2.   Where buildings have been erected along twenty percent (20%) of the
frontage between two (2) intersecting streets or along the frontage measured
three hundred fifty feet (350') in any direction from the side lot line of the
zoning lot on which a building is proposed, where no street intersections are
located within three hundred feet (300') from said side lot line, no building
shall be permitted to project in front of the average setback established by
the existing buildings, but in no event shall the minimum requirements be
greater than fifty feet (50').
   B.   Side Yard: No side yard is required; except for a corner lot which
abuts upon an R District or upon an alley separating this District from an R
District, there shall then be provided a side yard equal to one-half (1/2) the
front yard required in the abutting R District, but in no case more than fifty
feet (50').
   C.   Rear Yard: In the B-1 District, a rear yard shall be provided for
residential special uses to be not less than fifty feet (50') in depth and to
begin at a level no higher than that of the finished floor of the lowest
residential unit.
   D.   Transitional Yards: Where a B-1 District adjoins a residence district,
transitional yards shall be provided in accordance with the following
regulations:
      1.   Where lots in a B-1 District front on a street and at least eighty
percent (80%) of the frontage directly across the street between two (2)
consecutive intersecting streets is in a residence district, the setback
regulations for the residence district shall apply to the said lots in the
business district.
      2.   In a B-1 District where a side lot coincides with a side or rear lot
line of property in an adjacent residence district, a yard shall be provided
along such side lot line. Such yard shall be equal in dimension to the minimum
side yard which would be required under this Ordinance for a residential use on
the adjacent property in the residential district.
      3.   In a B-1 District where a rear lot line coincides with a rear or
side lot line of property in an adjacent residence district, a rear yard shall
be provided along such rear lot line equal in dimension to the minimum rear
yard which would be required under this Ordinance for a residential use on the
adjacent property in the residential district.
      4.   In a B-1 District where the extension of a front or side lot line
coincides with the front lot line of an adjacent lot located in a residence
district, a yard equal in depth to the minimum setback required by this
Ordinance on such adjacent lot in the residence district shall be provided
along such front or side lot line for a distance of at least twenty five feet
(25'), including the width of any intervening alley, from such lot in the
residence district. (Ord. 0-95-460, 3-9-1995)
5A-4: MINIMUM LOT SIZES:
Where public water supply and sanitary sewer facilities are available, every
zoning lot for a building hereafter erected or enlarged shall have an area of
twenty thousand (20,000) square feet or more. Where the property lacks either
public water supply or public sewer facilities, the lots shall have a minimum
of forty thousand (40,000) square feet and shall meet the requirements
stipulated in Section
11-3-10 of the subdivision regulations of the Village Code. Where lots have
neither public water supply nor public sewer facilities, they shall have a
minimum area of one acre or more and a minimum frontage of one hundred fifty
feet (150'). (Ord. 0-95-460, 3-9-1995)
5A-5: BUILDING HEIGHT:
In a B-1 District, the height of the buildings or structures shall not exceed
two and one-half (21/2) stories and shall not exceed thirty five feet (35'),
unless adjacent to and in the same block with a B-2 District, in which case the
height shall not exceed three (3) stories and shall not exceed forty five feet
(45'). (Ord. 0-95-460, 3-9-1995)
5A-6: OFF-STREET PARKING AND LOADING:
Automobile parking and loading facilities shall be provided as required or
permitted in Chapter 8 of this Ordinance. (Ord. 0-95-460, 3-9-1995)
5A-7: PUBLIC UTILITY EASEMENTS:
Proposed location for easements necessary to the development of the property to
be served, as recommended by the respective public utility companies, shall be
indicated on plat, but such designation shall not constitute a dedication of
such proposed easement. (Ord. 0-95-460, 3-9-1995)

   C.   Such uses, operations or products shall not be established, maintained

5B-6: YARDS:

   B.   Side Yard: No side yard is required, except for a corner lot which
abuts upon an R District. There shall then be provided a side yard equal to
one-half (1/2) the front yard required in the abutting R District, but in no
case more than fifty feet (50').
   C.   Rear Yards: In the B-2 District, a rear yard shall be provided to be
not less than fifty feet (50') in depth. Required rear yards shall be
unobstructed from the lowest level to sky except as allowed in Chapter 2 of
this Ordinance.
   D.   Transitional Yards: In the B-2 District, the regulations governing
transitional yards in the B-1 District shall apply 1 . (Ord. 0-95-460, 3-9-
1995)

5C-4: CONDITIONS OF USE:
In the B-3 District, the permitted uses listed in Section
5C-1 of this Ordinance are subject to the following conditions:
   A.   Dwelling units and lodging rooms, other than those located in a
transient hotel or motel, are not permitted below the second floor.
   B.   Not more than six thousand feet (6,000') in the aggregate of gross
floor area per establishment shall be devoted to the production or processing
of goods or products.
   C.   No activities involving the production, processing, cleaning,
servicing, testing or repair of materials, from fire, or explosion, or of
offensive noise, vibration, smoke, dust, odors, heat, glare or other
objectionable conditions beyond the boundaries of the premises upon which the
use is located are permitted.
   D.   All production, processing, cleaning, servicing, testing or repair of
materials, goods or products shall take place within completely enclosed
buildings, except for the storage of building materials and except for the
parking of motor vehicles in the open. (Ord. 0-69-105, 5-8-69)

front yard required in the abutting R District, but in no case more than fifty
feet (50').

shall be the same as required in the B-2 District.
   D.   Transitional Yards: The regulations governing transitional yards in the
B-3 District shall be the same as required in the B-1 District 1 . (Ord. 0-69-
105, 5-8-69)

ARTICLE D. O/R OFFICE RESEARCH DISTRICT
SECTION:
5D-1: Description Of District
5D-2: Use Regulations
5D-2-1: Uses Permitted
5D-2-2: Special Uses
5D-2-3: Accessory Uses
5D-2-4: Temporary Uses
5D-2-5: Prohibited Uses
5D-2-6: Conditions Of Use
5D-3: Yards
5D-4: Lot Size; Number Of Buildings
5D-5: Lot Coverage
5D-6: Minimum Contiguous Area
5D-7: Building Height
5D-8: Parking And Loading Areas, Access Routes
5D-9: Signs
5D-10: Special Provisions
5D-1: DESCRIPTION OF DISTRICT:
The office/research district is a specialized classification in which the
development of large office, entertainment or hotel structures upon large sites
is incorporated. This district sets aside large, accessible land parcels where
architecturally coordinated office, entertainment and hotel structures can be
constructed in a "park-like" atmosphere compatible with an adjoining
residential district. No territory shall be classified in this district unless
such property is located along or bounded by at least one major thoroughfare or
arterial street. In addition, no territory shall be classified in this district
which is bounded on more than one side by territory in a residential district
unless such additional territory in a residential district is separated from
territory proposed to be classified in this district by a major thoroughfare or
arterial street. (Ord. 0-2000-612, 7-13-2000)
5D-2: USE REGULATIONS:
5D-2-1: USES PERMITTED:
No building or land shall be used and no building shall hereafter be erected,
structurally altered or enlarged, except as permitted or accessory uses as
hereinafter described. The following uses are permitted in this district:
Business, professional and governmental offices.
Research and development laboratory facilities. (Ord. 0-78-94, 5-11-1978)
5D-2-2: SPECIAL USES:
Subject to the conditions and requirements of section
11-5 of this ordinance, the following special uses may be permitted in this
district:
Banks and savings and loan associations with or without drive-in facilities.
Financial institutions.
Heliports accessory to principal use.
Hotel buildings, including related and accessory retail and restaurant uses
located within the hotel structure.
Personnel training centers.
Private indoor or outdoor recreation facilities, accessory to the principal
use.
Public parks or playgrounds.
Restaurants (but not including "fast food" restaurants or "drive through"
facilities).
Theaters with concessions, together with ancillary retail and restaurant uses.
(Ord. 0-2000-612, 7-13-2000)
5D-2-3: ACCESSORY USES:
The following accessory uses, buildings or other structures customarily
incidental to and commonly associated with the principal use are hereby
permitted, provided they are operated and maintained under the same ownership
and on the same lot as the permitted use:
Employee food service, vending and cafeteria facilities, provided such
facilities are located within the building or buildings housing the principal
use.
Gate houses, the floor area of which shall not exceed two hundred (200) square
feet and the height of which shall not exceed one story.
Off-street parking and loading facilities, in accordance with the provisions of
this article and all other ordinances applicable thereto.
Parking structures above and below ground, in accordance with the provisions
contained in this article.
Service and sales activities, provided such activities are carried on within
the building or buildings housing the principal use.
Sewage disposal unit, pump houses and other mechanical and electrical equipment
buildings serving the facility.
Signs in accordance with the provisions hereinafter set forth in this article.
(Ord. 0-78-94, 5-11-1978)
5D-2-4: TEMPORARY USES:
Temporary buildings or yards for construction, materials and/or equipment, both
incidental and necessary to construction on the zoning lot, shall be permitted;
provided, that such buildings or yards shall not be located within one hundred
feet (100') of any property used for residential purposes. (Ord. 0-78-94, 5-11-
1978)
5D-2-5: PROHIBITED USES:
All uses not expressly authorized in this article are hereby deemed prohibited.
(Ord. 0-78-94, 5-11-1978)
5D-2-6: CONDITIONS OF USE:
All business and professional activities shall take place within the enclosed
buildings. (Ord. 0-78-94, 5-11-1978)
5D-3: YARDS:
   A.   Front Yard: All structures (with the exception of gate houses) shall be
set back from the front lot line at least one hundred fifty feet (150').
   B.   Side Yards: All structures (with the exception of gate houses) shall be
set in from the side lot lines a distance of not less than one hundred fifty
feet (150').
   C.   Rear Yard: All structures shall be set in from the rear lot line at
least one hundred fifty feet (150'). (Ord. 0-78-94, 5-11-1978)
5D-4: LOT SIZE; NUMBER OF BUILDINGS:
Every use hereafter established within this district shall be on a lot which
will provide an area of not less than five (5) acres, and shall be not less
than two hundred fifty feet (250') in width at the established building line.
More than one building or structure may be constructed on a zoning lot,
provided all buildings and structures will be under the same ownership and
operation, provided, however, that lot areas under five (5) acres may be
permitted pursuant to a special use. (Ord. 0-2000-612, 7-13-2000)
5D-5: LOT COVERAGE:
Not more than fifteen percent (15%) of the area of the zoning lot may be
occupied by buildings or structures, including accessory buildings and enclosed
parking structures. However, up to twenty percent (20%) of the area of the
zoning lot may be occupied by the buildings and structures, including accessory
buildings and enclosed parking structures pursuant to a special use under this
chapter. A minimum of thirty five percent (35%) of a zoning lot shall be in
lawn, landscaped area, lakes and ponds, exclusive of parking areas, except that
this minimum shall not apply to an individual zoning lot which is part of any
overall special use granted in the district where the property subject to the
special use contains a total aggregate open area that satisfies the thirty five
percent (35%) requirement of this section. (Ord. 0-2000-612, 7-13-2000)
5D-6: MINIMUM CONTIGUOUS AREA:
The minimum contiguous area of land zoned within this O/R district shall be
forty (40) acres. (Ord. 0-78-94, 5-11-1978)
5D-7: BUILDING HEIGHT:
   A.   No building or structure shall be erected or altered to exceed a height
of three (3) stories. In no event shall any building or structure exceed fifty
five feet (55') in height. "Height" is herein defined as the vertical distance
from the lowest elevation of the ground at the building line to the highest
elevation of the roof, exclusive of elevator penthouses, roof access or
stairway penthouses. That portion of section
1-3 of this ordinance, definition of "story", which limits the height of a
story to fourteen feet (14'), shall not apply to this article.
   B.   Provided, however, that pursuant to a special use permit under this
article, for property located adjacent to an interstate highway and a regional
arterial highway, the corporate authorities may permit:
      1.   Office structures not to exceed four (4) stories and fifty five feet
(55') in height,
      2.   A hotel structure of up to six (6) stories and eighty five feet
(85') in height (including penthouse and/or mechanical equipment),
based upon location on the property, the nature and proximity of adjacent land
uses and structures and the relative elevation of the site. (Ord. 0-2000-612,
7-13-2000)
5D-8: PARKING AND LOADING AREAS, ACCESS ROUTES:
In addition to the requirements of this article, automobile parking and loading
facilities shall be provided as required or permitted in chapter 8 of this
ordinance.
   A.   Surfacing: All open off-street driveways, internal access routes,
parking areas and loading berths shall be improved with a compacted macadam or
equivalent base not less than seven inches (7") thick, surfaced with not less
than two inches (2") of asphaltic concrete or some comparable all- weather,
dustless material. Parking areas shall be improved with poured concrete
curbing.
   B.   Location:
      1.   Where the rear lot line and/or any side lot line abuts upon any lot
or land area in a residence district, no part of the area within one hundred
feet (100') of said lot or land area shall be used for a driveway or other
access route except when such residence district is separated from said lot or
land area by a street or highway. Internal roadways and access routes shall be
a minimum of twenty feet (20') in width and driveway access from public right
of way shall have a minimum radius of one hundred feet (100').
      2.   Open off-street parking areas shall not be located in the required
front yard or within one hundred feet (100') of any other lot line.
      3.   Enclosed parking structures shall not be located within any required
yard areas.
   C.   Special Uses: The corporate authorities may prescribe parking, loading
and access requirements (and permit elevated parking structures subject to
section
5D-7 of this article) appropriate to implement any special use granted pursuant
to this article. (Ord. 0-2000-612, 7-13-2000)
5D-9: SIGNS:
   A.   Identification Signs:
      1.   Identification signs shall be permitted in any front, side or rear
yard which abuts or is bounded by a street or limited access expressway or
tollway, provided such signs shall be set back a minimum of fifty feet (50')
from any right of way.
      2.   Only one identification sign shall be permitted for each street or
highway frontage. Identification signs shall conform to the requirements of all
other applicable ordinances of the village except to the extent that such
ordinances may be in conflict with this article.
      3.   Identification signs shall be subject to the following requirements:
         a.   Illumination: Identification signs may be illuminated only by
light cast upon such signs from a concealed light source.
         b.   Size: All identification signs shall be detached (not mounted on
a building) and not exceed fifteen feet (15') in height including the base. The
face area of any sign shall not exceed one hundred fifty (150) square feet and
the width of the face area shall not exceed fifteen feet (15'). The face area
of a double-faced sign shall be calculated on the basis of only one face.
   B.   Other Signs: The following signs shall be allowed anywhere within a
zoning lot so long as they are not illuminated, do not exceed four (4) square
feet in sign face area and do not exceed ten feet (10') in height:
      1.   Signs to regulate traffic.
      2.   Signs required to be posted by law.
      3.   Warning signs and no trespassing signs.
      4.   Signs giving information concerning the location and/or use of
accessory off-street parking facilities or loading and unloading facilities.
      5.   Signs established by governmental agencies.
The number of the above designated signs shall be limited to the reasonable
amount necessary to serve the functions for which such signs are designed to
accomplish. (Ord. 0-78-94, 5-11-1978)
5D-10: SPECIAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   Site Plan: A site plan shall be prepared and submitted to the plan
commission/zoning board of appeals for review and recommendation to the village
board and approved by the village board prior to issuance of a building permit
for construction of any building.
   B.   Underground Utility Facilities: All utility lines including electric
power and telephone lines shall be located underground.
   C.   Lighting: All exterior lighting including lighting of buildings,
interior street lighting and landscape lighting shall be directed away from
adjacent highways, streets and properties.
   D.   Landscape Plans: A landscape plan shall be prepared and submitted to
the plan commission/zoning board of appeals for review and recommendation to
the village board. No site plan shall be approved unless the landscaping plan
herein required is approved by the village board. Such plan shall locate
proposed trees and shrubs, and indicate the size and species of all plant
material proposed to be installed throughout the project including areas within
the off-street parking space.
   E.   Screening And Berming: Landscape screening and/or earthen mounds shall
be used whenever possible to reasonably screen all off-street parking from
adjoining roadways and residential districts. All refuse storage areas shall be
screened from view with solid fencing and landscaping. Plans for screening and
berming shall be considered as part of the required landscape plan submitted
pursuant to subsection D of this section. (Ord. 0-78-94, 5-11-1978)
ARTICLE E. O/R II OFFICE AND RESEARCH DISTRICT
(Rep. by Ord. 2005-732, 1-13-2005)
ARTICLE F. LIMITED OFFICE DISTRICT
SECTION:
5F-1: Description Of District
5F-2: Use Regulations
5F-2-1: Uses Permitted
5F-2-2: Special Uses
5F-2-3: Accessory Uses
5F-2-4: Temporary Uses
5F-2-5: Prohibited Uses
5F-2-6: Conditions Of Use
5F-3: Yards
5F-4: Lot Size; Number Of Buildings
5F-5: Lot Coverage
5F-6: Minimum Contiguous Area
5F-7: Building Height
5F-8: Building Size
5F-9: Setbacks From Adjacent Residential Areas And Arterial Streets
5F-10: Parking Areas, Access Routes
5F-11: Vehicles
5F-12: Signs
5F-13: Special Provisions
5F-1: DESCRIPTION OF DISTRICT:
The purpose and intent of this District is to provide a transition zone between
the residential districts in the Village and the adjoining districts located
outside of the Village. The small office structures permitted in this District
shall be designed and configured in such a manner as to be compatible with the
residential properties abutting the District. The District shall encourage the
establishment of small business offices, while protecting the existing
aesthetic and residential character of the area. (Ord. 0-95-468, 8-24-1995)
5F-2: USE REGULATIONS:
5F-2-1: USES PERMITTED:
No building or land shall be used and no building shall hereafter be erected,
structurally altered or enlarged, except as permitted or accessory uses as
hereinafter described. The following uses are permitted in this District:
Business, professional and governmental office. (Ord. 0-95-468, 8-24-1995)
5F-2-2: SPECIAL USES:
Subject to the conditions and requirements of Section
11-5 of the Zoning Ordinance the following special uses may be permitted in
this District:
Attached garages, with a garage door not to exceed eight feet (8') in height
Banks and savings and loan associations with or without drive-in facilities
Financial institutions
Outdoor picnic and patio facilities
Private indoor or outdoor recreation facilities, accessory to the principal use
Public parks or playgrounds
Sewage disposal unit, pump houses and other mechanical and electrical equipment
buildings serving the facility (Ord. 0-95-468, 8-24-1995)
5F-2-3: ACCESSORY USES:
The following accessory uses, buildings or other structures customarily
incidental to and commonly associated with the principal use are hereby
permitted, provided they are operated and maintained under the same ownership
and on the same lot as the permitted use:
Employee food service and vending facilities, provided such facilities are
located within the building or buildings housing the principal use.
Gate houses, the floor area of which shall not exceed two hundred (200) square
feet and the height of which shall not exceed one story.
Off-street parking facilities, in accordance with the provisions of this
Article and all other ordinance applicable thereto.
Signs in accordance with the provisions hereinafter set forth in this Article.
(Ord. 0-95-468, 8-24-1995)
5F-2-4: TEMPORARY USES:
Temporary buildings or yards for construction, materials and/or equipment, both
incidental and necessary to construction on the zoning lot, shall be permitted;
provided that such buildings or yards shall not be located within one hundred
feet (100') of any property used for residential purposes. (Ord. 0-95-468, 8-
24-1995)
5F-2-5: PROHIBITED USES:
All uses not expressly authorized in this Article are hereby deemed prohibited.
(Ord. 0-95-468, 8-24-1995)
5F-2-6: CONDITIONS OF USE:
All business and professional activities shall take place within the enclosed
buildings. (Ord. 0-95-468, 8-24-1995)
5F-3: YARDS:
Subject to the provisions of Section
5F-9 of this Ordinance, the Limited Office District shall have the following
setback requirements:
   A.   Front Yards: Each lot upon which a building is constructed shall have a
front yard setback of not less than sixty five feet (65').
   B.   Side Yards: Each lot upon which a building is constructed shall have a
side yard setback on each side of not less than twenty five feet (25').
   C.   Rear Yards: Each lot upon which a building is constructed shall have a
rear yard setback of not less than thirty five feet (35'). (Ord. 0-95-468, 8-
24-1995)
5F-4: LOT SIZE; NUMBER OF BUILDINGS:
Every use hereafter established within this District shall be on a lot which
will provide an area of not less than sixty thousand (60,000) square feet, and
shall be not less than one hundred feet (100') in width at the established
building line. Not more than one building or structure may be constructed on a
zoning lot. (Ord. 0-95-468, 8-24-1995)
5F-5: LOT COVERAGE:
Not more than fifteen percent (15%) of the area of the zoning lot may be
occupied by a building or structure, including attached garage. A minimum of
fifty percent (50%) of a zoning lot shall be comprised of lawns, landscaped
areas, lakes and ponds, exclusive of parking areas. (Ord. 0-95-468, 8-24-1995)
5F-6: MINIMUM CONTIGUOUS AREA:
The minimum contiguous area of land zoned within this Limited Office District
shall be ten (10) acres. (Ord. 0-95-468, 8-24-1995)
5F-7: BUILDING HEIGHT:
No building or structure shall be erected or altered to exceed a height of two
(2) stories. In no event shall any building or structure exceed thirty five
feet (35') in height. "Height" is herein defined as the vertical distance from
the lowest elevation of any adjoining arterial roadway to the highest elevation
of the roof, inclusive of elevator penthouses, roof access or stairway
penthouses, or, the vertical distance from the lowest elevation of any
adjoining arterial roadway to the highest elevation of the roof, inclusive of
elevator penthouses, roof access or stairway penthouses, whichever distance is
lowest. That portion of Section
1-3 of the Zoning Ordinance which, in its definition of "story", limits the
height of a story to fourteen feet (14'), shall not apply to this Article.
(Ord. 0-95-468, 8-24-1995)
5F-8: BUILDING SIZE:
No building or structure shall be erected or altered to exceed twelve thousand
(12,000) square feet, exclusive of the attached garage required by Section 5F-
11 below. (Ord. 0-95-468, 8-24-1995)
5F-9: SETBACKS FROM ADJACENT RESIDENTIAL AREAS AND ARTERIAL STREETS:
The setback from adjacent residential areas shall be no less than one hundred
feet (100'), and shall be occupied exclusively by lawns, landscaped areas,
lakes and ponds. Parking shall not be permitted in such setbacks. The setback
from any arterial street shall be no less than one hundred feet (100');
provided, however, that parking may be located in said setback as long as it is
not less than fifty feet (50') from such arterial street. (Ord. 0-95-468, 8-24-
1995)
5F-10: PARKING AREAS, ACCESS ROUTES:
In addition to the requirements of this Article, automobile parking facilities
shall be provided as required or permitted in Chapter 8 of the Zoning
Ordinance. Neither loading facilities nor enclosed parking structures or any
parking other than surface parking shall be permitted in this District, except
as provided in Section
5F-11 below. In addition to the requirements set forth in Chapter 8, the
following requirements shall be complied with; provided, however, that in the
event of a conflict between the requirements of Chapter 8 and the requirements
set forth below, the more restrictive requirements shall apply.
   A.   Parking Spaces Offices - Business, Professional And Governmental: One
parking space for each two hundred fifty (250) square feet of floor space
(exclusive of basement areas not used for offices).
   B.   Surfacing: All open off-street driveways, internal access routes,
parking areas and loading berths shall be improved with a compacted macadam or
equivalent base not less than seven inches (7") thick, surfaced with not less
than two inches (2") of asphaltic concrete or some comparable all- weather,
dustless material. Parking areas shall be improved with poured concrete
curbing.
   C.   Location: Parking and access routes shall not be permitted within the
one hundred foot (100') residential setback established in Section
5F-9 hereof, or within the fifty foot (50') arterial road setback also
established in said Section
5F-9. Internal roadways and access routes shall be a minimum of twenty feet
(20') in width and driveway access from public right of way shall have a
minimum radius of one hundred feet (100').
   D.   Prohibited Hours: The parking of any vehicle shall be prohibited
between twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and five o'clock (5:00) A.M., except
for emergency purposes. (Ord. 0-95-468, 8-24-1995)
5F-11: VEHICLES:
Only vehicles which are classified as vehicles of the First Division pursuant
to section 1-217 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/1-217) (those motor vehicles which are designed for the carrying of not more
than 10 persons) and Class B vehicles on the Second Division (vehicles with a
gross weight, including vehicle and maximum load, of 8,000 pounds and less)
shall be permitted to park in the District; provided that any other vehicles of
the Second Division may be allowed to park temporarily for the purpose of
unloading and delivering goods and materials. (Ord. 0-95-468, 8-24-1995)
5F-12: SIGNS:
   A.   Identification Signs:
      1.   Identification signs shall be permitted in any front, side or rear
yard which abuts or is bounded by a public or private street or limited access
expressway or tollway, provided such signs shall be set back a minimum of
twenty feet (20') from the property line.
      2.   Only one identification sign shall be permitted for each building.
Identification signs shall conform to the requirements of all other applicable
ordinances of the Village except to the extent that such ordinances may be in
conflict with this Article.
      3.   Identification signs shall be subject to the following requirements:
         a.   Illumination: Identification signs may be illuminated only by
light cast upon such signs from a concealed light source.
         b.   Size: Identification signs shall be detached (not mounted on a
building) and not exceed fifteen feet (15') in height including the base,
except one wall mounted sign not to exceed twelve (12) square feet shall be
permitted for any building. The face area of any detached sign shall not exceed
thirty two (32) square feet and the width of the face area shall not exceed
eight feet (8'). The face area of a double- faced sign shall be calculated on
the basis of only one face.
   B.   Other Signs: The following signs shall be allowed anywhere within a
zoning lot so long as they are not illuminated, do not exceed four (4) square
feet in sign face area and do not exceed ten feet (10') in height.
      1.   Signs to regulate traffic.
      2.   Signs required to be posted by law.
      3.   Warning signs and no trespassing signs.
      4.   Signs giving information concerning the location and/or use of
accessory off-street parking facilities or loading and unloading facilities.
      5.   Signs established by governmental agencies.
The number of the above designed signs shall be limited to the reasonable
amount necessary to serve the functions which such signs are designed to
accomplish. (Ord. 0-95-468, 8-24-1995)
5F-13: SPECIAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   Site Plan: A site plan shall be prepared and submitted to the Plan
Commission/Zoning Board of Appeals for review and recommendation to the Village
Board and approved by the Village Board prior to issuance of a building permit
for construction of any building.
   B.   Underground Utility Facilities: All utility lines including electric
power and telephone lines shall be located underground.
   C.   Lighting: All exterior lighting including lighting of buildings,
interior street lighting and landscape lighting shall be directed away from
adjacent highways, streets and properties. Plans for lighting shall be
considered as part of the required landscape plan standard submitted pursuant
to subsection D hereof.
   D.   Landscape Plans: A landscape plan standard shall be prepared and
submitted to the Plan Commission/Zoning Board of Appeals for review and
recommendation to the Village Board. No site plan shall be approved unless the
landscaping plan for such site meets the minimum standard provided for by the
plan. Such plan shall locate proposed trees and shrubs, and indicate the size
and species of all plant material proposed to be installed throughout the
project including areas within the off-street parking space.
   E.   Screening And Berming: Landscape screening and/or earthen mounds shall
be used whenever possible to reasonably screen all off-street parking from
adjoining roadways and residential districts. All refuse storage areas shall be
screened from view with solid fencing and landscaping. Plans for screening and
berming shall be considered as part of the required landscape plan standard
submitted pursuant to subsection D hereof. (Ord. 0-95-468, 8-24-1995)
ARTICLE G. GOVERNMENTAL USE DISTRICT
SECTION:
5G-1: Establishment And Description Of District
5G-2: Use Regulations
5G-2-1: Uses Permitted
5G-2-2: Special Uses
5G-2-3: Accessory Uses
5G-2-4: Temporary Uses
5G-2-5: Prohibited Uses
5G-2-6: Conditions Of Use
5G-3: Yards
5G-4: Lot Size; Number Of Buildings
5G-5: Lot Coverage
5G-6: Minimum Contiguous Area
5G-7: Building Height
5G-8: Parking And Loading Areas, Access Routes
5G-9: Signs
5G-10: Special Provisions
5G-1: ESTABLISHMENT AND DESCRIPTION OF DISTRICT:
A zoning district to be called the Governmental Use District is hereby
established. The Governmental Use District is a specialized classification in
which the development of public structures upon large sites is incorporated.
This District sets aside large, accessible land parcels where architecturally
coordinated public structures can be constructed in a "park-like" atmosphere
compatible with an adjoining residential district. No territory shall be
classified in this District unless such property is located along or bounded by
at least one major thoroughfare or arterial street or is contiguous to property
located in this District. (Ord. 0-94-428, 2-17-1994)
5G-2: USE REGULATIONS:
5G-2-1: USES PERMITTED:
No building or land shall be used and no building shall hereafter be erected,
structurally altered or enlarged, except as permitted or accessory uses as
hereinafter described. The following uses are permitted in this District:
Public and governmental offices and facilities. (Ord. 0-90-362, 5-10-1990)
5G-2-2: SPECIAL USES:
Subject to the conditions and requirements of Section
11-5 of this Ordinance, the following special uses may be permitted in this
District:
Any special use permitted in the Office/Research District.
Business and professional offices.
Research and development laboratory facilities.
Public recreation area or club, including the facilities attendant to such a
club, such as a gymnasium, running track, classrooms, indoor and outdoor
swimming pools, indoor and outdoor tennis courts, indoor racquetball courts,
outdoor basketball courts, fitness center and locker rooms. (Ord. 0-94-428, 2-
17-1994)
5G-2-3: ACCESSORY USES:
The following accessory uses may be permitted in this District:
      1.   Any accessory use permitted in the Office/Research District.
      2.   Restaurants conducted accessory to public recreation areas or clubs;
provided, that such restaurant is located within the building or buildings
housing the principal use. (Drive- in restaurants or facilities or food stands
catering to customers with facilities for parking on the premises for
consumption of food in autos shall not be permitted.) (Ord. 0-94-428, 2-17-
1994)
5G-2-4: TEMPORARY USES:
The temporary uses allowed in the Governmental Use District shall be the same
as those allowed in the Office/Research District. (Ord. 0-90-362, 5-10-1990)
5G-2-5: PROHIBITED USES:
All uses not expressly authorized in this Article are hereby deemed prohibited.
(Ord. 0-90-362, 5-10-1990)
5G-2-6: CONDITIONS OF USE:
All business and professional activity shall take place within enclosed
buildings; provided, however, that a) any recreational activities and programs
taking place on any property or facilities owned by the South Barrington Park
District and b) any activities taking place within bank drive-up facilities,
shall not be deemed to be in violation of this Section. (Ord. 0-94-428, 2-17-
1994)
5G-3: YARDS:
The front yard, side yard and rear yard setback requirements in the
Governmental Use District shall be the same as the setback requirements in the
Office/Research District. (Ord. 0-90-362, 5-10-1990)
5G-4: LOT SIZE; NUMBER OF BUILDINGS:
Every use hereafter established within this District shall be on a lot which
will provide an area of not less than ten (10) acres, and shall be not less
than five hundred feet (500') in width at the established building line. More
than one building or structure may be constructed on a zoning lot, provided all
buildings and structures will be under the same ownership. (Ord. 0-90-362, 5-
10-1990)
5G-5: LOT COVERAGE:
The maximum lot coverage of land zoned within the Governmental Use District
shall be the same as that allowed in Office/Research District. (Ord. 0-90-362,
5-10-1990)
5G-6: MINIMUM CONTIGUOUS AREA:
The minimum contiguous area of land zoned within this Governmental Use District
shall be ten (10) acres. (Ord. 0-90-362, 5-10-1990)
5G-7: BUILDING HEIGHT:
No building or structure shall be erected or altered to exceed a height of two
(2) stories. In no event shall any building or structure exceed forty five feet
(45') in height. "Height" is herein defined as the vertical distance from the
lowest elevation of the ground at the building line to the highest elevation of
the roof, exclusive of elevator penthouses, roof access or stairway penthouses.
The definition of "story" in Section
1-3 of this Ordinance limiting the height of a story to fourteen feet (14')
shall not apply to this District. (Ord. 0-90-362, 5-10-1990)
5G-8: PARKING AND LOADING AREAS, ACCESS ROUTES:
   A.   Requirements: The requirements pertaining to parking, loading areas and
access routes in the Governmental Use District shall be the same as those
allowed in the Office/Research District, provided, however, that parking
requirements for banks in the Governmental Use District shall be determined in
the same manner as for office, business, professional and governmental
facilities in the Office/Research District.
   B.   Surfacing: The requirements pertaining to surfacing of off-street
driveways, internal access routes, parking areas and loading berths shall be
the same as those allowed in Office/Research District. (Ord. 0-90-362, 5-10-
1990)
5G-9: SIGNS:
The requirements pertaining to signs in the Governmental Use District shall be
the same as those allowed in Office/Research District. (Ord. 0-90-362, 5-10-
1990)
5G-10: SPECIAL PROVISIONS:
The provisions pertaining to site plans, underground utility facilities,
lighting, landscape plans, and screening and berming in the Governmental Use
District shall be the same as those allowed in Office/Research District. (Ord.
0-90-362, 5-10-1990)

6-3: CONDITIONS OF USE:
In the M-1 District, all permitted uses are subject to the following:
   A.   Any production, processing, cleaning, servicing, testing, repair or
storage of goods, materials or products shall take place without creating
disturbing influences to the use and occupancy of adjoining properties.
   B.   All business, production, servicing and processing shall take place
within completely enclosed buildings unless otherwise specified. Within one
hundred fifty feet (150') of the nearest point of any residential district, all
storage shall be in completely enclosed buildings or structures, and storage
located elsewhere in this District may be open to the sky, but shall be
enclosed by solid wall or fence, including solid doors, or gates thereto, at
least eight feet (8') high, but in no case lower in height than the enclosed
storage. However, open off-street loading facilities and open off- street
parking facilities for the storage of motor vehicles may be unenclosed
throughout the District except for such screening of parking and loading
facilities as may be required under the provisions of Chapter 8 of this
Ordinance. (Ord. 0-69-105, 5-8-69)
6-4: YARD AREAS:
   A.   Front Yard: In the M-1 District, on every zoning lot, a front yard of
not less than thirty five feet (35') in depth shall be provided.
   B.   Side Yards: In the M-1 District, on every zoning lot, a side yard shall
be provided along each side lot line. Each side yard shall be not less in width
than fifteen feet (15').
   C.   Rear Yard: A rear yard of not less than fifteen feet (15') is required
except where a lot abuts upon a residence district, in which case there shall
be a rear yard of not less than thirty feet (30'), and no storage of materials
or equipment, or the parking of automobiles shall take place within the fifteen
feet (15') closest to any residential lot or lots. (Ord. 0-69-105, 5-8-69)
6-5: LOT COVERAGE:
The maximum area occupied by all buildings on any lot shall not exceed forty
percent (40%) of the total area of the lot. (Ord. 0-69-105, 5-8-69)
6-6: BUILDING HEIGHT:
No principal or accessory building shall exceed three (3) stories or forty five
feet (45') in height. (Ord. 0-69-105, 5-8-69)
6-7: OFF-STREET PARKING AND LOADING:
Automobile parking and loading facilities shall be provided as required or
permitted in Chapter 8 of this Ordinance. (Ord. 0-69-105, 5-8-69)
6-8: PUBLIC UTILITY EASEMENTS:
Proposed location for easements necessary to the development of the property to
be served as recommended by the respective public utility companies shall be
indicated on plat, but such designation shall not constitute a dedication of
such proposed easement. (Ord. 0-69-105, 5-8-69)
CHAPTER 6A
PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENT DISTRICT
SECTION:
6A-1: Purpose
6A-2: Definitions
6A-3: Permitted Uses And Special Uses
6A-4: Procedures
6A-5: Specific Content
6A-6: Standards
6A-7: Fees; Schedule
6A-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the Planned Unit Development District in the village is to
encourage a better and more imaginative design of mixed use building forms and
site planning for tracts of land exceeding sixty (60) acres than is possible
under the more conventional zoning regulations. Designation of a Planned Unit
Development District pursuant to the home rule powers of the village of South
Barrington shall promote high quality buildings, architecture, design, and
landscaping that is adapted to the natural features of such sites. Such planned
unit developments shall be compatible with the surrounding land uses and
significant architectural features in the village. The plan commission may
recommend, and the corporate authorities may require, any reasonable condition
or design consideration which will promote proper development in this district.
The following objectives are sought through use of the planned unit development
process:
   A.   To permit maximum choice in the types of environment available to the
public by allowing a development that would not be possible under the strict
application of the other sections of the village code and/or village zoning
ordinance;
   B.   To promote a creative approach to the use of land and related physical
facilities that results in better design and development, with the inclusion of
aesthetic amenities;
   C.   To combine and coordinate architectural styles, building forms, and
building relationships, including, when appropriate, mixing different
relationships and uses in an innovative design;
   D.   To encourage a pattern of development to preserve natural vegetation,
topographical and geological features, and environmentally appropriate
features;
   E.   To create a method for the permanent preservation of common open space
for the continued use and enjoyment of the residents of the development;
   F.   To provide for more usable and suitably located recreation facilities,
schools, and other public and private facilities;
   G.   To promote the economical use of land and the installation and
maintenance of utilities, street improvements, structures and other facilities;
   H.   To encourage a land use which promotes the public health, safety,
comfort, morals, and welfare; and
   I.   To provide an environment of stable character compatible with
surrounding areas in the village.
The planned unit development is intended to provide for projects in excess of
sixty (60) acres that incorporate a variety of mixed but related uses which are
planned and developed or redeveloped as a unit. The planned unit development
should provide amenities not otherwise required by law and often establishes
facilities and open space greater than the minimum required by law. (Ord. 2000-
597, 3-23-2000; amd. Ord. 2022-1336, 8-11-2022)
6A-2: DEFINITIONS:
CODE: The village code of the village of South Barrington, Illinois, as amended
from time to time.
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The president and board of trustees of the village of
South Barrington, Illinois.
ORDINANCE: The zoning ordinance of the village of South Barrington, Illinois,
as amended from time to time.
PLAN COMMISSION: The plan commission of the village of South Barrington,
Illinois.
VILLAGE: The village of South Barrington, Illinois. (Ord. 2000-597, 3-23-2000)
6A-3: PERMITTED USES AND SPECIAL USES:
   A.   Permitted Uses: Permitted uses in this district may be constructed only
after following the procedures and receiving the approvals set forth in section
6A-4 of this article. Permitted uses shall include, and be limited to:
      1.   Single-family detached dwellings on lots of no less than one acre.
      2.   Churches, temples and other institutions for public worship, on any
zoning lot having an area of not less than ten (10) acres, having not more than
thirty percent (30%) of the lot occupied by buildings, and having sufficient
area to provide for both building space and off-street parking area as required
in chapter 8 of this ordinance.
      3.   Convents, monasteries, rectories or parish houses.
      4.   Public schools.
      5.   Park district recreational parks and facilities.
      6.   Municipal buildings and/or improvements.
      7.   Recreational areas and open spaces.
   B.   Special Uses:
      1.   All uses listed as permitted or special uses in the other zoning
districts in this ordinance and not listed as permitted uses in subsection A of
this section, and any uses specifically approved in an annexation agreement for
the subject property, and subject to any conditions therein, are special uses
in this district.
      2.   Single-family detached dwellings with no minimum lot size, provided
that the total area designated for single-family residential use complies with
the standard in this chapter of an overall average density of no more than one
unit per gross acre. (Ord. 2000-597, 3-23-2000)
6A-4: PROCEDURES:
   A.   Preapplication Procedure: Prior to the filing of an application for
approval of a preliminary plan, the applicant shall provide the village
administrator with an informal presentation of the proposed planned unit
development. At such presentation the applicant shall provide information as to
the location of the proposed planned unit development, the uses, and
approximate area of use categories, a list of any known exceptions to the
subdivision, zoning and/or other ordinances of the village, and any other
information the applicant deems necessary to clearly explain the proposed
planned unit development. The village administrator may request additional
information or documentation. The purpose of such preapplication presentation
is not intended to provide binding opinions or advice on behalf of the village
to the applicant but to make advice and assistance available to the applicant
before preparation of the preliminary plan, so that the applicant may
determine:
      1.   Whether the proposed planned unit development appears in general to
be in compliance with the provisions of this ordinance and other applicable
ordinances;
      2.   Whether any zoning amendment, special use or other relief is
required in connection with the proposed planned unit development;
      3.   Whether the proposed planned unit development is consistent with the
goals and policies of the village for development.
The preapplication presentation does not require formal application, fee, or
filing of a planned unit development plat.
   B.   Preliminary Plan Procedures:
      1.   Preliminary Plan: The purpose of the preliminary plan submission is
to obtain tentative approval and/or commitments from the village that the
plans, design, and program that the applicant intends to build and follow are
acceptable, and that the applicant can reasonably proceed into final detailed
architecture, engineering, surveying, and landscape architecture in
anticipation of final plan approval and subsequent construction. Approval of
the preliminary plan shall not constitute authority to proceed with
construction of any improvements, but rather constitutes an approval of the
general features of the plan as a basis for preparing the final plans. The
preliminary plan shall describe all uses and shall document all infrastructure,
buildings, landscaping, open space, and other improvements for the property.
The corporate authorities shall only approve final plans which substantially
conform to the approved preliminary plan and the ordinances rezoning the
property and authorizing the special uses within the Planned Unit Development
District.
      2.   Procedure:
         a.   Application: A petition to rezone the subject property and an
application for approval of a preliminary plan verified by the owner(s) of
record or authorized agent of said owner(s) of the property involved shall be
filed simultaneously with the village administrator upon a form prescribed by
the village, which shall contain or be accompanied by all required information.
Fifteen (15) copies of all required information shall be submitted. The
application and petition shall be in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter and ordinance. Upon receipt of such application and petition, the
village administrator shall forward same to the corporate authorities with the
request that the corporate authorities refer the matter to the plan commission
and request the plan commission make recommendations as to whether or not the
corporate authorities should approve the preliminary plan and grant the zoning
requested. The corporate authorities shall refer the application and petition
to the plan commission at a regular or special meeting of the village board
within thirty (30) days of receiving them from the village administrator.
         b.   Fees: The application shall be accompanied by a fee which shall
be established by the corporate authorities from time to time and a signed
agreement that the applicant will pay all reasonable fees incurred by the
village for consulting planners, engineers, or legal review of the proposed
development 1 .
         c.   Public Hearing: Within sixty (60) days of receipt of the petition
and application, and after a determination that they comply with the
requirements of this chapter, the plan commission shall schedule and hold a
public hearing in the manner provided in this ordinance for hearings on the
rezoning of property and the granting of special uses. A record of the
testimony presented at the public hearing shall be made by a court reporter at
the applicant's expense, and maintained by the village as part of its permanent
record concerning the petition and application.
         d.   Findings Of Fact: Following the close of the public hearing on
the preliminary plan and supporting data, the plan commission shall, within
sixty (60) days, submit findings of fact and a written recommendation for
approval, modification, or disapproval, and the reasons therefor, or indicate
why a report cannot be rendered to the corporate authorities at that time. The
report shall set forth in what respects the proposed plan would or would not be
in the public interest and may include findings of fact on the following:
            (1)   In what respects the proposed plan is or is not consistent
with the stated purpose of these planned unit development regulations;
            (2)   The extent to which the proposed plan meets or fails to meet
the requirements and standards of the planned unit development regulations;
            (3)   The extent to which the physical design of the proposed plan
does or does not make adequate provision for public services, provide adequate
control over vehicular traffic, provide for and protect designated and common
open space, and further the amenities of light, air, recreation, and visual
enjoyment;
            (4)   The relationship and compatibility of the proposed plan to
the adjacent properties and neighborhood;
            (5)   The desirability of the proposed plan with regard to the
physical development, tax base, and economic well-being of the village;
            (6)   The extent to which the proposed plan will affect property
values in the vicinity.
         e.   Conditions And Guarantees: In connection with the filed petition
and application, the plan commission may recommend, and the corporate
authorities of the village may stipulate, such conditions and restrictions upon
the establishment, location, design, layout, height, density, construction,
maintenance, aesthetics, operation, and other elements of the planned unit
development as they deem necessary for the protection of the public interest,
improvement of the development, protection of adjacent areas, and compliance
with this ordinance, the village code, and all existing federal, state, and
local legislation and regulation. In all cases in which the approval of a
petition to rezone and application for approval of a preliminary plan are
subject to such conditions, the corporate authorities of the village may
require such evidence and guarantees as they may deem necessary that the
conditions stipulated in connection with the approval of the petition to rezone
and application for approval of a preliminary plan will be met.
         f.   Determination: After receipt of the aforesaid findings and
recommendations from the plan commission, the corporate authorities of the
village, shall, within sixty (60) days, unless the applicant consents in
writing to an extension of time, either approve the petition for rezoning and
application for approval of a preliminary plan with such modifications,
requirements, or conditions as it may deem necessary, or deny the petition and
application. Failure of the corporate authorities to act within sixty (60) days
without an approved extension of time shall be deemed a denial of the petition
and application. The corporate authorities may approve or deny a petition and
application notwithstanding any contrary recommendations or findings of fact of
the plan commission. A preliminary plan which fails to receive approval of the
plan commission shall not be approved by the corporate authorities except by a
majority of the trustees then holding office. In the case of approval, or
approval with modifications, the corporate authorities shall pass an ordinance
indicating approval of the preliminary plan, rezoning the property, waiving any
requirements of this Zoning Ordinance or the South Barrington Village Code that
are deemed overly burdensome by the Corporate Authorities and granting the
necessary special uses, if any, contingent upon approval of the final plan.
   C.   Final Plan Procedures:
      1.   Final Plan: The final plan shall designate with particularity the
land subdivided into conventional lots as well as the division of other lands,
not so subdivided, into common open space and building sites. The final plan is
intended as a document to be recorded. The final plan shows the exact location
of facilities, while the preliminary plan shows the general location of these
same facilities.
      2.   Procedures:
         a.   Application For Approval Of Final Plans: The final plan, or if
the planned unit development is to be phased, the final plan for the first
phase shall be filed with the village administrator, together with all
supporting data required in subsection 6A-5C of this article, within one year
of the approval of the preliminary plan or within the time frame(s) set forth
in the approved phasing schedule, if greater. Prior to the end of the one year
period or the time frame(s) set forth in the approved phasing schedule, if
greater, the corporate authorities of the village, at their discretion and for
good cause, may extend for up to twelve (12) months the period for filing of
the final plan(s) in whole or for any phase. If the applicant fails to file a
final plan within the aforementioned time period, or any extension thereof, the
corporate authorities of the village, on their motion, may initiate revocation
of the approval of the preliminary plan and/or rezoning of the subject
property. Prior to such revocation and/or rezoning, the village shall provide
written notice to the applicant and the corporate authorities shall conduct a
public hearing at which the applicant shall be afforded an opportunity to be
heard. After such public hearing, the corporate authorities may adopt an
ordinance revoking approval of the preliminary plan and/or rezoning the
property. The final plan and, if the planned unit development is to be phased,
all phased final plans shall substantially conform to the preliminary plan as
approved. The final plan and all phased final plans and supporting data shall
fully comply with the provisions in this ordinance and code, as those
provisions may be modified by ordinance.
         b.   Plan Commission Review: All documents of the final plan shall be
transmitted by the village to the plan commission for review within sixty (60)
days of receipt of the application and supporting materials, and a
determination that they comply with the requirements of this chapter. The plan
commission shall review the final plan for its conformance with the approved
planned unit development preliminary plan and other requirements of this
chapter. The plan commission shall recommend approval or disapproval, and
provide the reasons therefor, to the corporate authorities. The plan commission
shall not make a recommendation on the final plan until it has received written
notice of approval of the final engineering plans by the village engineer.
         c.   Final Engineering Plan Procedures: The final engineering plans
and accompanying documents shall be submitted to the village administrator with
the application for approval of final plan. The village administrator shall
forward the final engineering plans to the village engineer for review and
approval or revision based on all applicable ordinances. The village engineer
shall send written notice to the plan commission, corporate authorities and
village administrator within forty five (45) days of receipt of the final
engineering plans that they have been approved, approved with modifications, or
disapproved.
         d.   Final Action: Provided the final plan substantially complies with
the preliminary plan and satisfies all other requirements of this ordinance,
the corporate authorities of the village, within sixty (60) days of receipt of
the aforesaid findings and recommendations from the plan commission, shall
approve the final plan. If approved, the corporate authorities shall pass an
ordinance approving the final plan or phase thereof.
         e.   Final Plan Recorded: The approved final plan shall be filed with
the appropriate recorder of deeds and all recording costs shall be paid by the
applicant. No permit allowing construction of a building or any other
improvement shall be issued until the final plan is recorded. No final plan
shall be recorded until the final engineering plans have been approved by the
village engineer and the required security for the improvements has been posted
by the developer as set forth in this code. (Ord. 2000-597, 3-23-2000)
   D.   Changes In The Planned Unit Development: The planned unit development
shall be constructed only according to the final plan, approved engineering
plans and specifications, and all supporting data. The final plan and
supporting data, together with all amendments, shall be binding on the
applicants, their administrators, executors, successors, grantees and assigns
and shall limit and control the use of the property (including the internal use
of buildings and structures) and the location of all structures, other
improvements, and open space in the planned unit development as set forth
therein. All proposed changes to the planned unit development after approval of
the final plan must be approved by the corporate authorities of the village and
may be handled as follows:
      1.   Major Changes: Major changes include the following:
         a.   A change in the uses and/or character of the development.
         b.   A change of ten percent (10%) or more in the maximum floor area
ratio for a phase of the development.
         c.   Any increase in the units per acre, total number of units, or
total number of any type of units in the residential areas of a development.
         d.   An increase of ten percent (10%) or more in the units per acre,
total units or total number of any type of units of a phase of the development.
         e.   A reduction in the minimum approved distance between structures
or in periphery setbacks.
         f.   Any increase in the percent of land covered in an entire
development.
         g.   An increase of ten percent (10%) or more in the maximum percent
of land covered in a phase of a development.
         h.   Any change in the height of buildings, street location, open
space plan, subdivision structure, or changes in landscaping that alter the
overall character of the landscaping for the development, or any change in
structures and/or structure locations that increases the total square footage
of all structures approved in the final plan for the development.
         i.   Any material change in the construction phasing schedule or
association agreements, declarations, and other documents.
         j.   Other changes determined to be a major change by the corporate
authorities.
Such modifications may be approved only by submission and reconsideration of a
new preliminary plan and/or final plan and by following the preliminary plan
and/or final plan procedures. If the major change is inconsistent with data or
evidence submitted during the preliminary plan stage, then the resubmission
must begin at the preliminary plan stage unless the change is requested by the
plan commission, village staff, or corporate authorities of the village or the
corporate authorities waive this requirement. If the major change is consistent
with the data and evidence submitted during the preliminary plan stage, then
the resubmission shall begin at the final plan stage.
      2.   Minor Changes: The corporate authorities of the village may, without
public hearing, approve minor changes in the planned unit development. Further,
a minor change is any change not defined as a major change. A minor change
shall include the change of location of any structure in a nonresidential
portion of the development so long as such change of location does not affect
any of the other criteria which would be deemed a major change set forth
herein. Such change shall be reviewed by the village's architectural control
commission prior to its approval by the corporate authority.
      3.   Application: An application for a major change or a minor change may
be submitted by the owner(s) or duly authorized agent(s) of the owner(s) of the
property described in such application. In the event an application for a major
change or minor change is submitted to the corporate authorities for only a
portion of the property within the planned unit development, any notice which
is to be published or other procedure to be followed shall be based solely upon
the legal description of the property which is the subject of the application.
(Ord. 2007-828, 8-9-2007)
   E.   Submission Timing And Reversion Clause: The final plans must be
submitted for approval in accordance with agreed scheduling. The first phase
final plan must be submitted not later than one year from the date of approval
of the preliminary plan or within the time frame(s) set forth in the approved
phasing schedule, if greater. Construction, as authorized by the issuance of a
building permit, must begin within two (2) years of the date of the approval of
the final plan dealing with such construction, or within the time frame(s) set
forth in the approved phasing schedule, if greater. If the developer fails to
comply with these requirements, the corporate authorities may initiate a
revocation of the preliminary plan as hereinabove provided. (Ord. 2000-597, 3-
23-2000; amd. Ord. 2022-1336, 8-11-2022)
